reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of people have been asking my opinion on LiF- so I figured I'd go ahead and write a lengthy review on this game and lay down (what I think) you should consider if you're going to drop the $40 for this game in its current alpha state.

First off, if you are someone who expects to be slaying dragons, fighting other people fully decked out in plate armor with a war horse and a golden lance within 30 minutes, and destorying them in 8 seconds with Mount and Blade style combat- do not even remotely consider this game.

At the exact time of this review I have sunk about 7 hours into this game (and of course plan on playing much more) and have managed to JUST NOW build myself a small shack and obtain a little iron to POSSIBLY create into tools. Mind you this was done with the help of around 6-7 other people who were working in extreme cooperation with one another. Just to give you a little sense of how hardcore" this game really is when it comes to progression. (I was also playing on a server with hardly any skill multiplier
date:
there are servers where you can level things much faster and thus progress with greater speed if you're looking for a more solo experience)

Now down to picking out the major aspects of the game people wish to know about:

1. Combat: Being someone who loves the fighting aspects of games
recommended: I will admit that Life is Feudal's alpha combat is nothing to write home about. 3/4s of your swings WILL miss until you get the range of your weapon (which is different for each weapon) and once you've actually got the combat down you will still have difficulty hitting. It is /not/ Mount and Blade combat. Is it close? Yes- but it is not M&B. Trust me. However
hoursPlayed: there is only alpha and it will likely get MUCH better and I can certainly see a fantastic combat system coming out of this. All in all
voteText: the combat at the moment is basically an unpolished combat of what can make a great system. 6/10\n\n2. Crafting: Crafting is definetly one of the stronger aspects of this game. It is rich and complex
helpfulPercent: certainly has massive potenial to be added onto. Even in its current state there is quite a lot to do. However I have been met with some pretty strange bugs that cause me to crash (which is totally to be expected in the alpha testing phase
votesHelpful: but I am after all reviewing the alpha) and some recipes are implemented but do not even work
votesTotal: for example the bow and torch. Overall
votesFunny: crafting is going to be very good when it is refined and expanded on
commentsCount: and even in its current state it is very useable. 7/10\n\n3. UI: I am bunching UI and Mechanics together due to the fact that there isn't much to talk about regarding them. The User interface is clearly in an early stage
column16: but much like the crafting
column17: very useable. There is a bit of a learning curve when you first get into the game (trying to figure out how the hell to do anything basically) but once you over come this
column18: you should be able to experiment and figure out everything else on your own. Don't expect this game to spoon feed you
column19: and honestly after 7 hours
column20: I'm sure there is stuff that even I haven't figured out yet. 6/10\n\n4. Skills and Mechanics: The skills system is still very much a work in progress
column21: I'd say about 1/4(?) of the skills have still yet to be implemented. However

The skills system is definetly going to be something to enjoy once it is fully completed. 8/10\n\nNow my final thoughts on whether you should drop the $40 or not: As you can see in a lot of what I said

reviewText: The following is a personal anecdote taken from my experiences playing on Role-Play Community: Life is Feudal (RPCLIF) server. In this community heavy RP is enforced and any event done otherwise is punishable.\nDay 1: I have finally made my way into the realm from a nearby beach, it has been a while since I have visited the Isle of Maldath. I gather berries and herbs and begin to train myself in the ways of the gatherer. Day 2: I have located a nearby settlement surrounded by tall oaks and green grasses known to the natives as Woodhurst. Upon signaling the guardsman at the towering iron front gate, to my surprise, I am greeted by an old friend of mine, Arnaas of Valencia. We reminisce for a moment and I am soon offered a position among their people as an herbalist in training. Of course I accept, and then am put on a trial period to prove my loyalty.Day 3: Whilst gathering in the nearby cattle-fields of Woodhurst I notice two men approaching the front gate of the town, one in what seemed to be a religious robe and the other in sturdy plate armour. I am urgent about greeting them, in hopes that I can make a few friends. The two outsiders reveal themselves to be Solith" a priest of the Blood God and "Korn
date:
a fellow mercenary. They are spreading word that the southern faction known as Dominion has fallen and is being rebuilt by their cult. Once again, I am offered a position. Strucken by promises of gold and power... I am torn.Day 8: After days of training, I have begun to mix potions for Woodhurst as they have accepted me as their full time alchemist. I covertly keep in touch with Solith as I am still partially swayed by his tempting offers. I am introduced to the town bank as I am now added to the pay roll.Day 12: A raid has taken place on the nearby settlement of Mercia in which the pope of Woodhurst was slain by no other than Korn and Solith's Cult. General Felipo of the Woodhurst army immediately drafts me into their military as a recruit and I undergo extreme combat training. My specialty being Pole-Axes and Scale Armour. Day 20: Serving for Woodhurst has now become grueling work with little pay. One night at my post, I decide to leave the town in search of Solith's lair, hoping that his offer still stands. I am greeted by their cult and am offered training and safe haven if I leave Woodhurst forever. I state that I must go back to fetch my items. As I am leaving, a squadron of Woodhurst soldiers stops  and sees me conversing with the cult. I am immediately interrogated and claim to be seeking revenge for our pope. General Felipo decides to take matters into his own hands and challenges Solith's mercenary, Korn to a duel. Korn is decapitated. I make an effort to ride back to Woodhurst.Day 30: My quarters have been under lockdown and I have been suspended for suspicion of treason. One night I successfully subdue my guard and make my way into the inner town square. I make my way for the bank. The blackmith's, the queen's, carpenter's, everyones payroll now mine. I have stolen a horse and made my way back to Solith's lair. I am now wanted.Day 31: The combined forces of Woodhurst and her allies have surrounded Solith's Lair and are demanding that I be handed over for execution. We wait them out after exchanging some volleys of spears etc.Day 34: The heat has cooled off and I leave the lair in search of a plot of land to buy for my own, one that is away from all this conflict. As I make my way to a nearby village, I make my way into the town inn and have a long conversation with the bartender. A long enough conversation in order for their messenger to send word to Woodhurst of my location. I hear a farmiliar voice call my name. As I turn, I immediately draw my weapon. Then as I see all the other farmiliar faces start appearing, I dash for my life. I make it just in time to grab my horse and ride all the way across the island evading every single horse archer and lanceman they sent after me. I am now forever an outcast among these lands.
Conclusion:

I'm going to let you all in on a little secret about this game.  Like many others of its kind, this game and its famous hard-core RPG elements, are very closely tied to the servers you play on. This is because to be a Grandmaster Hunter" or even a "Famous Axe-Man" means nothing unless you have a community that depends on you. So what I'm trying to say is
recommended: don't jump into this game by yourself or even with a few friends on a private server because most of you will not get your money's worth. You don't want yourself to end up like everyone else in the negative reviews section who got sick of digging holes and grinding for levels. Instead
hoursPlayed: find a meaningful server. One that cherishes heavy RP
voteText: constant PVP
helpfulPercent: or even both. That being said
votesHelpful: I highly recommend RPCLIF as your server of choice for the adventures to come."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely love this game. I am on a non PVP server and we are usually close to full every evening. I was unsure about the game the first hour or so. I'm used to Rpg's where you wander around killing stuff to level up and craft when you get tired of leveling. This game is completely different. It's all about building and crafting. It'a about wandering around a beautiful country looking for the things you need to make food, tools, armor, houses, keeps, weapons...basically anything and everything.
On our server we have like three separate communities or villages. Since PVP isn't an option on this server, we are friendly to one another. On my second day of playing I had made a crapload of mortar and pestles so I shouted out that if anyone wanted some of them for free, just come to my village at the base of the smallest mountain in the northeast by the sea. (There are no roads yet, although they can be built with certain skills so we use landmarks like lakes and mountains to guide people to where we are). So some stranger shouts back asking me why don't I put my stuff in a chest and I respond that i don't have one or the skills to make one. So he yells back that he'll make me one and he lugs this huge chest on his back all the way to my village just to be neighborly! This is the kind of community I like to play in and the majority of the players on my server are like this! Then the guy sticks around a bit and gives me tips on crafting and makes me a blacksmith hammer when I ask him what skill is needed to make one.
The crafting is what makes this game fun for me. Gathering my materials and skilling up to make better items is simply a blast once you figure out the mechanics which aren't very hard. Right now, I'm enjoying making tools. Yesterday I tried out hunting. Low level hunting was fun as heck. You're too weak to kill big game, but the game makes it enjoyable in a very unique way for newbies. A noob hunter has a couple od fun skills One is a crafting option to make small animal snares and the other is called small animal tracking. When you activate tracking, an animal's footprints appear and you can see where he likes to travel. Follow his trail and place the snares you make out of materials along the way ( plant fiber, a tree branch and an apple) which are all easy to find, then come back in an hour or so and empty your traps. I got chickens and hares and I put them in a coop in my village and they laid eggs and had babies...totally awesome. You can also track aggressive animals once you learn to defend yourself. I've seen bears and wolves. There are no monsters yet and I'm okay with that...it feels real. Supposedly they will be added in the future. Bear in mind this is alpha.
There are PVP servers if that is your thing, but I can't comment on that aspect of the game because I don't like pvp.
If you choose non pvp, the game is about building a community. In my village everyone chats, they ask other for items and sometimes we trade stuff or even just give it away. Today a new person logged on and asked us how to get a house, so we told him to join our village and everyone helped to build him one. Since I was too low to actually help build, I helped gather wood. I felt good about it and it was fun to see everyone helping a complete stranger. I've played MMO's for many years and frankly outside of guilds, you meet so many rude obnoxious people in MMO's anymore but so far it hasn't been like that here.
I'm really excited. I found it difficult to even take time away from the game to write this post, but I wanted to get the word out. I've got big plans. I'm raising my healing skills and making my own plate mail so i can kill bears, and I'm learning to fish. I'm even going to build a keep which takes 15000x rocks and 4000 shaped stone among other things. It will take months and it will be so much fun to watch it grow into a fortress for me and my friends.
Let me be clear on one thing. if you're looking for action packed adventure, the non pvp server aspect of this game is NOT for you. This is laid back...serene music in the background, birds twittering in the trees, the sound of your neighbor chopping wood, a hike up the biggest mountain on the island to watch the sunset and get back home before the wolves come out. It's about meeting people who don't yell, I PWNED YOU!"

reviewText:
I have played this game a lot. I know almost everything about it, currently. I have built everything that there is to build, been a king, a farmer, a warrior...  so when I write a review, know that it is quite balanced. I am no fan boi, and will let you know all the pro's and cons of this game.

Pros.
1. You can tailor your characters skills to match what you wish to do in the game. Depending on the server skill cap, it can mean you can ONLY be a farmer and a bowman, or a smith and a swordsman, to being able to do everything.  Pick the server that best represents what you want. RP, pvp, rp/pvp, high skill cap (recommended for new players) or low skill cap.

2. crafting system requires a lot of steps. You want to build a small house? Alright the you either have to have a supply of trees nearby, or have forestry to plant saplings and wait half a week in real life for trees to grow enough to harvest. Then once you get the timber, you or a friend better have herbalism to get enough flux to make steel for the locks and mortar needed for doors. Then you better know enough materials prep to make glass for windows... which requires carpentry as do the doors. Oh, and smithing to make the locks... while you make clay tiles. So, you need 1. forestry. 2. logging. 3 carpentry. 4. smithing. 5. materials prep. 6 gathering. 7 herbalism... just to make the smallest house in game.  On a low skill cap server, this will take the combined efforts of 3-4 people. Now imagine what a castle takes.

3. harvesting is indepth. Need leather? Go hunt, make coops to harvest hares, and barns for animals... oh you need to actually trap those animals, or tame them.  Food is grown, and harvested... then a cook is needed ot make it into actual food. All raw resources need to be manufactured into goods.

4. giant battles. I have participated in a 64 man judgement day battle. Took hours of non stop fighting, with trebuchets flinging rocks, bombs and arrows everywhere, people murdering eachother and sometimes friends on accident.

5. Small battles. Nothing is more intense than a 2-3 man vs 2-3 man fight, where every person is needed to hold their own to win. Takes hours and hours of training to get decent, and I mean just decent, at pvp

6. You literally create your own town from nothing. You scoop every bit of dirt, plant every tree, move the world to create a settlement that you can be proud of. You can make a hovel in a swamp, or a giant fortress in the mountains, it all depends on the time you invest.

7. community and roleplaying can be a blast. Politics, intrigue, back biting... all fun.

Cons.

1. server wipes. put 200 hours into your place, and its gone, instantly, start from scratch.

2. lazy or no gms. LEaves you at the mercy of the griefers if the server you choose doesnt have active gms.

3. SLOW DEVELOPMENT. And I mean SLOW. I have played for quite some time now... the ONLY thing added to the game since I have played (I played in beta) was advanced weather. That's it. Most people dont even use it as it can lag you. Oh and the dx11 graphic upgrade... which didnt actually add anything to the game. They have been promising horse drawn carts for MONTHS.

4. broken features/bugs will drive you crazy. Wait till you die 20 times in a row, losing a ton of skill points that takes  hours to get because of a bug.

You can't play the game by yourself and expect to win. The fun is in groups. Dont buy this game if you dont want to join a group.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really love what this game represents. Real feudal life. Hard, unkind, and taking effort to eke out a living. You get to experience struggle. But then, that's where the dream goes horribly wrong. I understand that they had to make concessions with the interface becaue they wanted to keep the servers from getting loaded with crap on the ground and have it crash. But the methods they came up with to deal with that aspect are painful to work around. Please note that *my friend and I played* this game with the server set on default settings. I wasn't solo.

Let's go from the experience of making a house. The first little hut that you can make at the begining. So how would you make a house/hut in real life? Well, first you'd get some tools. Then you'd use the tools to gather the resources. Then you'd use the same tools or other tools to refine said resources. Then finally you'd assemble said refined resources in some fashion to construct the final product. Also I should include the reality of dealing with the terrain by preparing it. This is both an acceptable convention and a logical one. However, the developers of LiF:YO have decided that they wanted to do it their way.

The LiF:YO way. First you start off by gathering the tool components. I'm with them at this point. You grab some branches, flint, and plant fiber and away you go with your tools. But here's where it gets convoluted. You don't now get to walk up to a tree, small or otherwise, and start smacking it. You have to know" how to cut this tree down. So start learning. So grab some branches off a tree and other things to learn. Ok
date: you now know how to cut the tree down

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are some things about LiF that are really neat: the crafting, the graphics. Building your own medieval town is really such a wonderful idea and I was eyeing this game for ages.

But as a single player (and this game is being marketed for single players as well as multiple), this game has been nothing but a disappointment.

- For solo players, the grind is really the only thing there is. There's no danger and no purpose really to play: any wildlife that may attack you is easily avoidable. There are no other mobs. I had read before purchase of intentions to create quests and mobs, but it seems that those ideas have been abandoned in favour of keeping LiF:YO as a game that relies entirely on PvP for non-crafting content.

- The grind is real. It took me over thirty RL hours to flatten the land and collect the mats I needed to build a small shack. This was after tweaking settings so I could have a chance in hell of creating anything on my own. As much as I love crafting, it's going to take absurd amount of time -- hundreds and hundreds of hours -- to build anything. But with no danger present in the world, there's no purpose to build other than aesthetics.

- Some of the cool features in the LiF video are -only available for the MMO-. This is not the MMO. There are no crafting games here. The island you get is small and not likely to get bigger. No quests planned. The only thing in the world is you. And the tedious grind of creation.

- Speaking of the MMO, that's where the devs are focused. Buying LiF: YO isn't giving you a version of the MMO: it's giving you the redheaded stepchild of the family. It's sickly, underdeveloped, and simply not getting any of the attention that they are lavishing on its brother. Reading the official forums makes it clear that this isn't likely to change. (Seriously. Go look at the list about the differences between YO and the MMO. You may find that the feature you're purchasing this for doesn't exist in the YO version.)

Don't get me wrong. I really want to like this game. I'll keep my eyes on it and see if maybe the devs have a change of heart about the PVP-only content. But LiF is too much effort for very little pay off. Even if you are a solo player -- especially, even -- I'd highly suggest you wait for the MMO when it comes out.

If it comes out.

reviewText:
I began my life as a simple peasant with no particular skill. I woke up on the shore of an island and soon found my place in the world with a small tribe that will one day be called the Southern Veil. We become allies with the neighboring town of the Sweetcottons before we are even able to erect a palisade wall. Soon after we gain these close allies we are rode upon by members of a place called Killian's Keep. They tell us that we must pay them a tax of straw. We refuse and militarize ourselves.

Not soon after the taxes are imposed we erect a wall around our small settlement. I become the town blacksmith and I am known as one of the most skilled blacksmiths of the land. We then begin construction of a wooden keep surrounded by stone walls. Once these walls are complete we are invaded by the Huns. They used our wooden walls as cover from the arrows fired from our stone walls and soon created a ladder over our wall and slaughtered us. This was not the end.

We grew larger, gained another close ally known as Ciderwood, and began to raid them back. We first struck Killian's Keep, coming in through a weak point in their wall and killing masses of them, then we come back again and again and we successfully slaughter them every time. Every time we raid the Huns they are never home so we wait and slaughter them every time they attack us or one of our allies.

Now we are a huge militarized force with all of our allies only a moment's notice away from aiding us in combat, and we are the same for them. . . I began as a peasant and am now a warrior. Life is Feudal

10/10 would blacksmith again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent my first day fashioning crude tools and scavenging for anything edible.  By nightfall I had yet to get a fire going and had no food left.  Across the bay, I could see another player's campfire flicker into existence.

Worried that he may become technologically advanced and threaten my survival, I decided to sneak over to his camp in the middle of the night and club him to death with a tree branch.

I now have fire and a handful of tasty berries.

10/10

reviewText:
The early access version went through a lot of ups and downs, but it was pretty solid. Obvious issues like infinity piles/tunneling and some getting stuck on terrain/etc but generally speaking it was a 'good' game.

Then something odd happened I've never seen an EA game do before... They released a different game than what we have been testing/playing these last few years. I don't get it, you have us test this game for early access so you can work out the bugs/etc. But on launch day you change dozens and dozens of things that basically no one has tested. Why would you do this... The current version is so incredibly broken with bugs and glitches dedicated servers won't even run in a stable fashion.

For whatever reason the devs had a 2nd version of the game they were developing on the side and released that instead of the game we've all been playing this entire time. What happened??

Early Access Review

I brought this game about two days ago, I thought I'd give a day prior before playing to get a fresh start. I started by spawning near a lake, I found a person fishing by the lake fishing, I asked him whether I could help, so he got food and I started making tools and gathering some logs to cut. 2 days later we now have a small village with 10 or so people contributing in different professions, we have armour and weapons on the way, a general, mayor and we still have so much more to do. This game is honestly amazing, you could see it at a first person age of empires from the villager’s perspective? Or even a Minecraft / mount and blade sandbox. Honestly, it's worth the buy the alpha is steady & this game is proving more and more amazing for the future.

reviewText:
Life is Feudal is a complex sandbox box, with a very open world. For those of you that remember it, it's VERY akin to the old Star Wars Galaxies (pre NGE)

Pro's:
-Complex Crafting system.
-Fantastic system to socialize, as it is impossible to pick up every skill
-Complex skil system that allows you to try new things, grow into new skills, and forget them if you don't like them.
-Fantastic challenge rating for skills: Easy to pick up, time consuming to master. You can grow, loot, and craft high quality materials.
-Great graphics. Really nice visuals on higher settings.
-Terraforming: Push over minecraft, you can literally level landscapes, dig siege tunnels, and build ramps. Or just flatten terrain so you can build a city!
-City building: Akin to SWG, you can drop down pre-generated structures, tools, build roads, claim ownership.
-Nothing is worth doing that doesn't take time to do: This whole game takes time. It's not a fast paced, get your guns in a day and rule the world. BUT... it is fantastic, and well conceptually well designed.

Pro&Con:
-This is an MMO Sandbox. It is what you, and others make out of it. If you want to be a trader or bar keep, you can actually craft resources, make food, sell high quality foods, trade for better resources, and even pray for absolution from your sins. However, for every peaceful choice you make, someone out there will want to be a rampaging psychopath that will run into your shop and wreak everything...

Cons:
-Right-click-simulator: The game is fantastically in-deptch, but in order to make it EASY to manage, it uses a right-click system. Where you end up openning that menu... A LOT.
-It doesn't like it when you alt+tab. Seems to work better on windows 10.

TLDR:
This game is a fantastic open world complex to the likes of SWG Original Release. It's got a deep crafting system and really encourages social play. So build your character, find new people, and start carving up your plot of land! Because this IS the sandbox game you've been looking for!

Go check out the life is feudal website and notice how similar their 'selling points' are.
HotRise's review has no ACTUAL cons. This is a typical market tactic. Look constructive and modest, yet, have no ACTUAL downside.

The developers aren't well known. And while this DOES NOT mean they shouldn't be trusted, it DOES mean to be careful.
How do we do this?
By monitoring their First impression practises"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not do reviews on games.... But this one I owe a review to.

First off, most of all the negative reviews are from players that have not put in the time that is required to enjoy this game. It's really sad that a lot of the negative reviews have given this game a Mixed review status. I have seen one review 0.4 hours invested and they said the controls are broken....

So before you start playing this game, please go to youtube and search for LiF Basics 101. You will learn A LOT of invaluable information. There is a learning curve to this game and you really never stop learning simply because there are a TON of details about what's going on that you will discover. This will make you more valuable to the community of players which is I believe what this game is about. Playing with others!

With that out of the way, this game is amazing. They have come along way since the beginning. The graphics are fantastic. (When you start the game is automatically on low settings you need to adjust it!) Sure, just like every single game out there, room for improvement, is a valid complaint. But in the end, this is one of the best sandbox games out right now.

Hard work pays off in this game. It will take some time to gather, build, level your way to what you envision. The reward is great once your done. Do not come into this game thinking that you can just gather a ton of stuff and instantly build stuff. It will not happen. (Unless you take the time to find a server that has high leveling etc.) You most likely WILL need help to do things. It is the way this game is supposed to be played, get it in your head. Sure you could play solo.... But it's going to be a long road.

TLDR:

Gritty, grindy, sandbox that will have you showing off what you build and accomplish to your community and friends. Excellent graphics, skill system, crafting and just plain fun if you put in the time. Highly recommended if you like the huge reward behind the grind!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 400 hours of playtime, I think i can inform others about the game. First of it all: It's still an alpha, but the most developed one I've ever played. Combine Minecraft with War of the Roses, and you got your game. The game is, although some mechanics are highly repetetive, very addicting. It's not a game for a few hours a month and without the necessary endurance you will give up soon. If you like crafting, fighting and role-playing with other human beings, then get it and check it out. Otherwise: Don't.

On the positive side you got very good graphics, a great variety of armor and weapons you can choose from and a crafting system that highly supports team gaming. You got a lot of different building, the map is large enough for 64 players and every 2-3 weeks comes an update. The sound is ok, as long as you don't put tanning tubs aside your house..
The skill system is fair and interesting, because on most servers you can only skill 1-2 skilltrees to the max, and it is possible to deskill every time. It is like in Skyrim: With doing certain things, you get better at doing so and with rising skill level there are some other options you unlock. The fighting system is a bit sloppy, but also very detailed. For example: The damage you get from an opponent is the result of the weapon you use, the skill of your weapon, the armorskill of your enemy, the location of the hitbox where you hit and if your enemy is defending with a shield or not. Conclusion: Good mechanics, very high potential overall.

On the bad side you have no game-goals, quests or whatever. Your experience with the game will highly depend on the server you play on, considering if your serveradmins are fair or not and how other players fashion their role on the server. The first time, of course, you will be motivated by building your town with others and learn how to work, but after your village or castle is built, you have no other option then to fight and roleplay.

Considering this, there are also some broken mechanics that must be fixed soon: Since every digged tunnel on the server delays the login time of the players, it is impossible to run a 64 player server over a long time without getting a slow server. Some players on my server have login times beyond 6 or 7 minutes, and when you come to that point it will be extremly hard to get new players to join your server. Others may quit due to this and.. you get the idea, over a longer time your server will get more and more abandoned. There are some fixes to this, but nothing official is implemented yet, a server wipe is in most cases the only solution to get a fresh and playable server.

Another problem is the erasing of buildings: Once built, you cannot deconstruct anything without admin help. This is also highly annoying, because you have to plan really good before building your own town.

So, my conclusion: Don't start this game alone, pick one or two of your friends, start an own server to test things until you feel ready to play on a bigger server. Try to get to a server with active and friendly admins. You may wait until the tunnel-digging is fixed, but if you like crafting & boxing bears, then give it a try.

reviewText:
Life is Feudal: Your Own Review
8.5/10

I bought this game last week as I wanted to play with friends, and had just tried ESO and it was not scratching my itch. I watched some review videos, and LIF caught my eye as something I would be into –after all, who doesn’t want to be a peasant and eek out an existence in a bleak wilderness setting? As long as my aspirations of Knighthood remained viable, there should be reason for optimism…or so I told myself.

I hit the server with my buddy, Drek Stonebrow, and after several futile attempts to find each other, we finally hooked up –two disheveled figures in rags, hugging each other atop a bluff as night settled in. We marched to a location Drek had noticed on his way to me, and we settled in under the stars with our newly fashioned sleeping mats.

On the first day we spent several (Real) hours crafting primitive tools and experimenting with them. Yup this new shovel will lower and raise the terrain…oh wow, did I just spend 2 hours digging a ditch for the fun of it? Yes. That only took the crafting of five shovels.  Hey, how about this axe? It does chop down trees…oops, broke that too. Oh well no worries, I’ll quickly break off a few branches from this nearby oak, rustle up some plant fibers, tie it all in to this shapely piece of flint I discovered, and voila, I’ll have a new axe to play with.

And although I know these activities aren’t for everyone, I found it thoroughly enjoyable.

Over the next few days we hammered out several long sessions where we:
1. Learned to fish and hunt
2.  Built ourselves peasant hovels
3. Gathered stone to pave a small road
4. Raided our neighbors for their goods at night
5. Whistled peasant tunes and looked at our feet as a Knight in full plate came to stare down upon us from his mount and enquired about recent robberies
6. Created a guild and managed to talk three other friends into purchasing the game so that we could keep the Knight off our backs (Shout out to: Thulgar, Moe Poon, and Fung U)
7. Booted one of our friends from our guild for turning on us -he now has his own property. We don’t ask how he keeps the Knight away, and we don’t want to know …on a side note we should have been suspicious with a name like Fung U
8. Chopped wood, dragged wood , and piled wood for 20hrs (real …agonizing…hours). The pain of this was offset by the discovery of each craftable item we produced. Oh the look of pride on Drek’s face when he finally had his forge up and running.

And then it all came to a crash two days ago with the release of a new update. For whatever reason, the server we were playing on hasn’t been online since. Fung and I tried to entertain ourselves by creating new characters and raiding on several other servers, but after numerous bans, we are left scratching our heads and feeling like we have been ousted from our homeland.

With nothing to do but start on a new server (Or create our own) we are left with the impression that Life is indeed futile. Despite the somewhat bad taste in our mouths, Drek remains optimistic as he claps me on the back and says:  “Damned if I am giving up. Somewhere out there, a knight is looking for a peasant to bully.”



UPDATE:
We made our own server. Find us at 2NerdsRaging

reviewText:
Edit2: 700 hours in.  Woah.
Edit: 300+ hours in.  Still great.

I'm writing this review because some negative reviews led to me almost not buying it.  I am sincerely glad that I did.  This is the game that I've always wanted.

Let me tell you about my first night on LiF.  I logged into an RP server and was almost  instantly greeted by experienced players who were not only willing to help me with every question that I had - but also fillled me in on all the political happenings that were revelant to that evening.  the community, if nothing else, makes this game worth playing.

Before I knew it, they outfitted me with a basic sling and some sling ammo and I was marching off to battle.  We arrived through the woods to a small fort in the north which seemed relatively empty - I was disappointed at first: This was it?  Little did we know that the enemy was crouching behind their walls equipped with heavy plated armor and bowmen galore.  After about 20 minutes, two concussions, an arrow through the chest, and general astoundment that I was still alive - I heard that the enemy king was knocked unconscious and his nobles lay dead around him.  Opposed to killing the enemy king, our king inisisted that we let him regain consciousness so he could role play his reaction to the embarassing defeat.

While waiting patiently around him, celebrating our clear victory, we were ambushed by almost a dozen of the fallen king's allies from the west.  They streamed in behind us and we fled with our tails behind our legs.  By the time we hobbled back home, bloodied and broken, we had only lost one ally - a clear victory if you ask me!

Since then, peace has been negotiated and I've decided to make a pacifist character. - dedicating  my time to building a religious school on top of a mountain.  That's the best part of this game, you can literally do whatever you want.  Want to be a cook? Someone needs you in their guild.  Want to be a warrior? Someone wants you for their realm.  Want to dedicate your time to stacking wood, mining deep into a mountain, watching wheat grow? Well, you're probably going to have to do it anyway.

Admittedly, I've only been playing LiF for 15 hours (and that is not much for this game!) but i felt like it was my duty to defend it at least a little bit.

Yes this game is still in development, yes there are many features that haven't been implemented yet.  But I promise you that if you connect with the right people in-game then its not something you will regret contributing to.  There's a steep learning curve but once you get a hang of it everythings really intuitive and well thought out.  I can't wait for final release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is very interesting, and if you're dedicated and have the patience for this game, then it's for you. It's a nice medieval game full of crafting and adventuring, although, here's where you'll have to be patient: You could work on getting all of your stuff built and grown for 100 hours and some random people could come over, do something stupid, and then all of a sudden BAM. You're back at hour 1 again. The server could restart too, and BAM. You're literally at hour 1 again. You can't just spend 30 minutes to build stones walls and gates around your little village, no no... It can take about 10 hours to finish of none stop gathering. Oh and is there a little clift that you need to expand to get more land? No problem, as long as you got a couple of weeks of nonstop playing, then you'll get about a couple feet of land out of it for sure! And then there's the fact that you'll most likely be told that the server will restart in a month or so right after you're done. So if you got a lot of time on your hands and you have the patience to start all over again, even if you spent 300 hours on it, then here's a game for you!

(sorry, I tried to write it positive, but I wrote this right after a rage quit so.. All I'm saying is that you should maybe wait until the game's finished so there aren't as many server restarts. It's actually a pretty fun game, though.)

reviewText:
At 90 hours in, I have to say I'm really enjoying this game.

I joined it as I love any type of world builder game. I'm a crafter at heart.  This game doesn't disappoint on that front. The crafting system is extremely deep and can be complex, with long item trees.  Farming, to animal husbandry, to carpentry, etc.  I'm definitely in my element there.

What I wasn't expecting was finding myself on a server with a very robust social game. Kingships and Dukes, and wars, and strife and witches in the bogs.  It's been great watching and being a part of what really feels like a living breathing world.

I'm looking forward to seeing what the next few months bring to this new game!

reviewText:
Now let me get one thing straight, this game is not for everyone.  This game is one of the very few honest to god hardcore games I have ever played (You can attribute this to a lot of the negative reviews).  Playing solo is possible on modded servers, but if you want the REAL LiF experience by playing on vanilla, you WILL need a group of people.  This is boderline non-negotionable, this is where a lot of new players make a mistake and thus ruin the experience for themselves.

Now to get on to actually reviewing it...Let me start off by critiquing it.  The game does have some honest issues.  Animations are stiff and unnatural (Which normally wouldn't be a huge issue, but this effects combat so I have to point it out), game does have some performance issues, and can be VERY tedius.

But onto why I recommend the game, even though the game has it's own set of problems and isn't exactly perfect I still have to give this game a big thumbs up on it's core design philosophy.  If you enjoy a game that punishes you, a game that is unforgiving, but pays out when you work your ♥♥♥ off to achieve something....This game feeds this desire better than no other in my experience.  End game isn't achieved with ease.  It takes the combined efforts of you and your group working hard to achieve your goals, which gives you a sense of satisfaction I have never felt in a game before.

So in conclusion, if you are the type of player who can't and won't dedicate all their free time to a game, a player who wants things handed to them on a silver platter, or a player who just might not have the time in their lives to play this game.....Please don't buy this game, the game wasn't made for you to begin with.  But if you are like me, someone who enjoys the feeling of putting in hours of work and grinding into a game to accomplish things other players don't have the stomach for, this game is meant for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game has tremendous potential, it is nowhere ready to play.  This is not pre-alpha software, this is in the developer unit testing stage.   In a few months of hard development I think this game could be something pretty awesome but at this stage I wouldn't recommend spending your money to assist the deveopers testing their code.

The user interface is clunky at best, the game is completely unforgiving but also gives no assistance to the player, the crafting lines, although intricate, make no sense and EVERYTHING takes way too long.   I continually get a deadlock error that crashes the game and then when I trie to restart it tells me to wait for the game to close.  It takes 5 minutes for the game to close so I can go back in and find I lost my last few actions.

Myself, I can't sit and play a game that tries to mask frustration as entertainment.  For example, wolves that are nearly unkillable to a brand new player, but spawn in your chosen settlement area, When you die you loose everything plus stats and skills.  To top that off you spawn in one of several points around the island and you have to start all over again, trying to make it back to your grave.  When you arrive there you are killed again by the same wolf.

I don't necessarily disagree with the concept of requiring multiple player/crafters to progress.  But to be able to make a steel sickle to harvest (yes i know you can use a flint one) you must have a prospector/miner/smelter/forger of appropriate level.  But you also need to have flux to make steel and to make flux you have to have an alchemist.  But for the alchemist to have a better chance of finding herbs they have to have ... you guessed it ... a steel sickle.

Frustrations like this make the game feel like the developers making it are figuring things out as they go.   I don't believe it is unreasonable to expect a developer to have figured out how to fill in a tunnel while they were figuring out how to dig one.

I don't recommend this game at this point, however, in 6 to 9 months it might be playable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't know where to start with this review, but. Life is Feudal is a big open-world medieval sandbox game, i liked it as soon as i saw it, had my doubts about it but so far it is just as great as i expected it to be.

You WILL feel its an Alpha game, that is unavoidable of course, but for an Early Alpha it's really awesome.
It might be known as crash-simulator 2014, but after some tries with sick taming skills you will most likely get it working.

The game is positively builded up in a way which makes co-operation important, which is realistic considering most games like these are filled up with players who kill on sight. It features a high range of skills which mainly makes you focus on some hand-picked individual ones.

Overall some amazing work done by the devs, can't wait for this to get fully developed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all I would like to state that in comparing the reviews you should look at how many hours the player has spent. You will notice that most of the negative reviews have less than 100 hours in game. Many of which hardly spent more than 10 hours. A lot of the sudden negativity came since the game when on sale and all the kids bought it.

I am not going to lie, to truly unlock the fun in this game you will need to be dedicated. This isn't a game that you play a few hours and be done with it. You also need to make friends or have friends play with you, as this game was not designed to be played solo.

Make sure that if you intend to purchase this game that you have a decent computer. It is graphic and so it takes a lot of power.

The devs have been very active in releasing updates at least once a month. Sometimes with a minor patch in between because of some new bugs that suddenly appeared. In each update, they keep releasing new features.

As to the price of early access. To be honest I have seen a lot of early access games that aren't nearly as playable at this game. In fact I would dare to call this game LATE ALPHA as it has a lot of features already implemented and the devs do a pretty good job at testing before releasing so running into game breaking bugs is rare. I did purchase this game when it was on sale, however now knowing what I know and having played it a lot. I wouldnn't have mind paying $40 for this game.

AS I STATED BEFORE. This game isn't for everyone. If you plan to play solo? Don't get it. If you don't plan to be dedicated? Don't get it. If you don't like Medieval time settings? Don't get it.
ELSE, GET IT.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life Is Feudal is a hardcore sandbox MMO('ish) game with great potential. You'll be able to build villages, farms, castles, craft armor and weapons. And not to mention - kill people with those crafted weapons. There's an arsenal of weapons waiting to be crafted, both ranged and melee, but not all of them are implemented yet.

The game is still in alpha but you can already get a feeling of what the released game will become. It can sort of be described as a mix between Wurm Online in gameplay, and Rust with it's graphics. There's a couple crucial bugs at this point (for example the server browser freeze) and the servers go down alot, but once you get on a server and start playing there's hardly any bugs bothering you - which is pretty impressive for a alpha build these days.

One thing that's important to mention though, is that this is not really a singleplayer/solo game, you would want to gather your friends or join someone else in-game when you set out to build those small, big and gigantic settlements. And you and your friends will need alot of patience in the process of building your land and skills. The world is available for you to shape and form as you like, but like the real world it's going to take lots of time to shape it.

I would definetly recommend buying the game for the sandbox fans out there, but there's no rush in doing so. I would guess the most crucial bugs are getting fixed pretty soon though, and when they do Life Is Feudal will bring you tons of hours of fun even in it's alpha stage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First things first. The game has a very steep learning curve. Much of it does not make sense at the outset. It is not intuitive and you will not enjoy the time you lose learning hard lessons - for example, that you need to figure out how to make a primitive hammer in order to make a blacksmiths hammer to make other things - oh, and that same hammer is sitting next to the forge thingee but that's just stickering, you can't use it.. Oh - and you can't even use the forge until you learn how to mine, etc.

Looking at the negative reviews, it looks like most of those people did not get past this point. If you want fun and whimsical out of the box then stop reading now. If you're looking for something gritty and unique, keep reading.

Once you are past the learning curve and get confident with the interface, it really opens up. There's no AI enemies. Just people. People will be friend or foe based on how you treat them and how you respond to their treatment. People will lie and cheat, People will steal from you and take your hard work. People will break or ignore the rules to shortcut themselves at others expense. People will bully you and exploit weakness.

People will also believe in you. You will meet people. You will trust them and in turn they will trust you. You will build bonds and with those bonds grind out amazing things that you never thought possible. You will be there for them and they will be there for you.

You will get addicted. You will find yourself staying up way too late or getting up way to early to care for what you've made in some foolish video game you almost didn't figure out.

You will be afraid. Someone you do not know will suddenly approach you and your heart will race as you struggle to figure out what to do. Those that make is this far are all experts - skill counts for little advantage and all that will matter is how you've treated friend and foe.

It's just like life; it's what you make it. Game on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First, I would like to say that you will either love or hate this game, and you will know it within the first few hours of playing. I dont see anybody that just sort of plays this game here and there for fun. This game simply does not work that way. However, I will dissagree with other reviews in regards to playing alone. I play alone, and have my own little medieval farm tucked away surrounded by forest. It took me many many hours to get to that point, and the server does not skill cap anything, so people can level up as much as they want. Those types of servers, one can go solo and thrive.

With that little background, the game is for the most part realistic. Almost everything in this game is time consuming, and Im not going to lie... perhaps a little too time consuming. I have a small hut, back yard garden with wattle fence surrounding it, and that literally took me three days to build. However, during the time of construction, I had to stop and go looking for food because the last thing you want to do in this game is die.

So what is the goal of this game? What ever you want it to be. My goal was to simulate a nice little medieval farm, tend to it, improve it... etc. I am very pround of what I have built, and this game has some lasting rewards. Some may strive for control, the amount of weapons and possibilites in this game is ridiculously huge thus allowing them to control by force is neccessary. However, you will not really find players like Reign of Kings, just running around killing people. You dont do that in this game because their is just too much to lose, too much progress, and too much hard work being put in by people. With that being said, the community is awesome, very mature, and helpful.

Buy this game if you......

1. Want realistic medival simulator
2. Are a dedicated player
3. Willing to actually learn the game, because the learning curve is huge!

Do not buy this game if you...
1. Are a casual PC gamer
2. Think progress in Rust, or Reign of Kings is too slow
3.  Cant deal with a little bit of bugs, not game breaking... but complete lack of understanding for early access games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game description for Life is Feudal: Your Own refers to itself as a realistic medieval multiplayer sandbox". Sadly what has been delivered so far is a grind intensive RNG experience in frustration. While I have quite a few criticisms about this early acces game
date: in this review I will cover my initial thoughts
recommended: focus on my attempt at making a torch
hoursPlayed: and present my conclusion for the game in its current form.\n\nThe player starts off with a small amount of food and some clothes resembling a cloth sack. From there it is up to you to start living your life any way you want. I was initially surprised by the depth of options presented in the tool tips. I could prospect the ground for ore
voteText: strip the bark from a tree
helpfulPercent: collect sticks
votesHelpful: search for edible food on the ground
votesTotal: and much more. I could already picture the village I would build in my mind
votesFunny: bustling with life and promise. How wrong I was.\n\nMost actions in Life is Feudal are painfully slow or based on random chance. Each time you search the ground for food the action takes a significant period of time and often turns out no results. If you don’t find food you don’t skill up. If you do find food you gain a skill up
commentsCount: yet seemingly don’t increase your chances of being successful in future searches. My friend and I tried with default settings and with skill gains set to high with the only benefit being additional skills unlocking faster. The only things in the game that are close to realistic are extremely frustrating. Digging a tunnel  or terraforming takes a very long time and requires you to go drop all your dirt in a different location after every 5 or so digging actions.\n\nOne of the most pointless grinds I have experienced is trying to create a torch. Torches are often one of the first items crafted in a sandbox game and usually one of the most simple. This is not the case in LiF:YO even though only two materials are required. The first material
column16: a stick
column17: is easily gathered from a tree. The second
column18: naptha
column19: is synthesised from herbs. The process is as follows:\n\n- Create a sickle
column20:
- Search for herbs
- Gather the herbs
- Discover their properties by combining random herbs
- Gather more of the herbs that have the correct properties
- Create the naptha

While this initially doesn’t sound too difficult it is important to note that all the herbs look the same. You are given a random herb each time you gather so you cannot focus on collecting a certain type. Each herb was taking around 10 seconds to pick up and there are also a lot of different herb types which makes the odds of geting a specific one a lot worse. Due to poor inventory management/UI it takes a long time to combine herbs to discover what properties they have. After devoting more than half an hour to nothing but gathering and combining herbs I had not found the correct ones to make torches. In comparison It was far easier to build a house.

To conclude
column21: my biggest problem with LiF:YO is that the developers seem to equate realism with random chance. If the game were more realistic a player would be able to identify herbs by sight before gathering them. Players would be able to locate berries and mushrooms visually instead of having to click on a tile hoping for the RNG gods to award them something to eat. While the idea of the game has merit and the future of the game does not look entirely grim it is my hope that the developers shift a focus more towards something that is more user friendly and gives rewards based on work and skill rather than random chance."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off let me say that I LOVE THIS GAME!!!!

This is probably the most fun sandbox game I've played, ever. I initially opted to start solo on my own locked instance; just to learn the ropes, learn the UI and the crafting. I figured that would allow me to survive more easily when I moved to a PVP server. I expected it to be a learning experience, not a fun one. Actually it turned out to be so much fun that I got all carried away in the crafting and forgot to check out the multiplayer experience.

I've now restarted anew 3 times, as the server I settled on recently migrated. And one of my favorite things about this game is the leveling system. For one thing it makes it easy to start anew; no more spending an entire month of long grinding hours just to get back to level x at which you can finally do fun stuff. Nope, in this game you can train the basic combat skills in minutes and start to have fun. You can train your crafting skills in a couple days and hit the ground running on building. That is just great.

The game is barely half way done and already it offers and amazingly rich, deep and compelling experience. It sucks you in, but in the same time it allows short gaming sessions (which few MMOs do). So even if you only have 30 minutes to play you always have something you can do.

The Devs are very passionate about the game and are very active; they offer regular updates and even provide a public roadmap showing their progress on upcoming features.

I've fallen head over heels for this game, it has destroyed my Battlefield 4 career. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an Early Access title at the time of writing this review.

::TL/DR Version::

Single (solo) players - Game is overpriced and not worth the purchase. Development is too focused on the MMO that is being built from this funding project.

Multiplayer/Co-op Players - Game is still overpriced, but somewhat enjoyable with the right server and players.


:: The LONG Version ::

After a little more than 50 hours of playing this game, I have to honestly reject recommending this game. The videos and screenshots look great and I could not help but be very hopeful about this game. While that hope is still there for the potental of Life is Feudal and most of it's features, it has dwindled very rapidly. The fact that this game makes you work for everything, instead of just handing you everything like Minecraft, is the strongest reason why I was so interested in playing. With that said, this game feels more like an unenjoyable job than an enjoyable game at the time of this review.

Life is Feudal: Your Own gives the impression of being the fantastic single-player little brother to the anticpated MMO version to be released later. I bought into the dream, and watched it crumble as soon as I tore into the wrapper. There is no single player experience to this game.

Er, wait, what? Yes, you heard that correctly. The only way a person can play this game and enjoy it, or progress, is by using boosted server settings (skill rate, tunnelling rate, skill point limit) and GM commands. I tried this route, and the game had no enjoyment for me because I didn't feel that I had accomplished anything on my own, regardless of having a house and some walls. I started a second server, to play solo, with all default settings and found no enjoyment for a multitude of reasons.

Life is Feudal: Your Own has no NPCs, other than wildlife. For a solo player, this makes building walls and gates for your settlements pointless. And while there are the combat skills, they are pointless against wildlife. I found myself killed by a boar several times because I was lacking any combat skills to be able to land a hit on them with melee or ranged weapons. Utilizing the GM commands, I gave myself some armor and boosted my skills, only to still die after just a few hits (usually 3-4). If there is no difference is survivability with armor, and no increased chance to hit with better skills, then what is the reason for attempting combat with wildlife? I guess the only thing left is to just be a Lumberjack and a Farmer, right? I will say that the Lumberjack role is about the only role that seemed to work for me. You can strip trees of their branches and bark, and even a few saplings. Sure you can cut down those trees, and even turn them into boards and building logs. However, you can't do anything with it without the supporting crafting skills. Most everything requires some form of metal component to build, so you also need those supporting skills. Suddenly, the skill cap is looking smaller and smaller. Farming is a mixed bag of ideas. The system to find random plants (crops) works to help you find food that you can cook on a campfire to keep you alive or plant to start your crops. That part of the farming skill system works great, but also leads into my issues with the server side of the game.

The problems that do not work for me as a solo player, is the fact that the server has to run almost 24-hours of real time before you are able to harvest those crops that you have planted. Planted trees also require the server to run for an extremely long time period of real time before they have grown enough to be of any real use for the player. The server side is a mixed bag of confusion. The systems used to determine decay and time of day (in-game) will progress between the time a server is shutdown to when it is restarted. This takes place even if the server settings for decay are set to 0 (disabled). A person that is not able to play everyday, like myself, will find this to be quite annoying. Monuments that are used to protect your items from decaying, are not able to be managed while they are damaged. (See Update Note 1) If the monument reaches the end of it's hitpoints before the server is restarted, then it will be deleted upon server restart. This is the same with any other items (dropped items, campfires, snares, etc.) that are not protected or held by the player. Systems such as the growth of crops and the growth of tamed animals will not progress or update while the server is offline. It must be ran non-stop for these to progress. The slightest amount of items will overburden your character to the point you can not pick up anything, or even swap equipment. While there are storage options in the game, the storage limitations on the smaller, yet easier to craft items make them almost pointless. The larger storage options are impossible to obtain for a solo player, due to their increased material requirements, skill levels to craft, and the rate of decay for the numerous dropped items while collecting the other components. This basically adds up to the single player being a lot of the let the game run
date: while I go play something else" type of scenerio. For these reasons
recommended: I have to warn all players looking for a single player experience to avoid this title at this time. Especially for the overpriced tag of $40 USD.\n\nI found the multiplayer side of this game to be just as much work
hoursPlayed: with a lot more frustrations. I tried several public servers and found the combat against other players to be just as annoying and unbalanced as my single player experience against boars. There is also the inability to progress on public servers (in my experience) because you are constantly being murdered and robbed for usually crappy primative tools

reviewText:
Day one and a farmer stopped me and pointed me to the village of Applewood where the inhabitants offered food and clothing in return for labour. Void of anything of worth, I took her advice and made my way to where a builder was hard at work, building a great wall around the village. We greeted each other and soon I was invited to join the village.

---

Day five and we are tracking down a group of bandits. My sword skills are undeveloped due to helping finish the wall yet I join my new brothers in the hunt until we corner our heavily armed quarry as they leave a major settlement. The stand off is tense, neither side wishing to draw first for fear of the reprisals. The sound of steel rings out as a sword is drawn, the melee is one of chaos, tactics go out of the window. My sword feels feeble, my bare chest exposed and my iron clad adversary unstoppable. I manage a glancing blow on his left side, a more meaningful one to his right but his two handed axe is unrelenting, it's great arc of death formidable and I am hewn to the ground.

10/10 would draw my sword again.

Island of Elli is in my opinion the best RP server (199.102.79.66:22685) Heavy RP with no tolerance for griefers. Come join us

reviewText: I'll be honest, I absolutely love this game.  It's fun, deep, immersive, has great RP value, and has great potential to be my personal favorite game.  It has one major drawback though, the server providers for this game are not very versed in how to fix database issues, at all.  The official servers lack GMs (which is necessary because the game is still buggy) and have very low multipliers so very little to no player base on them.  All of the other servers are ran by regular players.  So while the game has some great potential for the MMO (if they get all the bugs ironed out) playing on a privately owned server means you are left to whichever ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you choose to follow.\n\nOut of 11 different servers now, we ran into griefing all day every day, ban happy GMs that ban over cutting a loud fart, GMs that didn't play at all, server rules changing every day...  All in all, that wasn't a very good experience.  So my group and I tried our hand at running our own server.  We eventually had a server through every provider listed on the LiF website except for PlugPayPlay.  What we found, was that none of the server providers really offered anything in the way of DDOS protection aside from a low end firewall.  Only Bluefang had prompt response times. (I'll give them an A+ for response time)  All our other providers ended up taking forever to get back with us, we had two tickets with Gameservers.com that ended up timing out on their own after 48 hours with no response.  NONE of the providers seemed to know how to handle technical issues, it was all just oh reinstall the server and start from scratch".  Also
date: none of the providers offered automatic backup setups.  Long story short
recommended: LiF all your providers (aside from the mystery one that I wasn't about to spend more money on) suck.\n\nThe game itself is great though.  The core mechanics of the game are very engaging and if you are into these kind of games
hoursPlayed: will keep you engaged for a very long time.  I would recommend it to players that like hardcore survival and building games as long as they don't care about GM abuse.  Also

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bearing in mind this is infact an alpha (which many gamers are forgetting nowadays means there will be bugs and issues).

This is a really fun and addicting crafting/survival game. It relies on teamwork to go beyond having a small hutt in a forest. You need a cook, a miner, a blacksmith, lumberjack, farmer, etc. You can't be all at once, so you actually need to be a part of a group to get anywhere. You can build everything from a tiny wooden hut, to a spawling castle with its own village inside massive stone walls.

Playable? Yes. Though there are optimization issues. FPS isn't amazing unless you turn your settings way down.

Enjoyable? Definitely. This is an amazing concept for a survival game. Every update adds more features to the game to make it more addicting.

Total recomendation: Great for survival/crafting game lovers. Has more realism to it than most. There are many bugs and missing features, but this is also nowhere near being released, and updates come frequently enough to keep you interested.

This is probably the most balanced sandbox builder I've played to date.

Your skill tree is complex without being OP as you don't just gain ridiculous typical MMO quality stats. For example
date: if you want to build something

To get your forestry levelled up you need to inspect trees/take bark/branches from them (which you can use along with stone you gather from terraforming to make tools) and then when your forestry is high enough you unlock logging which allows you to begin on chopping down trees. Early Access Review

I want to like this game and want to recommend it, but, I can't.  There are too many design issues that get in the way of playability.  For example, I tired to fight a wolf twice.  a dialog appears and puts me in cursor mode and I die before I can clear the dialog and get back to the fighting the wolf.  In fact a  lot of actions seem to drop the player into a cursor mode which is a pain and complicates even the most menial task in the game.  And this game is full of menial tasks.  Raise and lower the ground at a snails pace.  After 10 swings of trying to dig a tunnel and seeing no tunnel I gave up.  You have to raise and lower a bunch to raise your skill to dig tunnels which allows you to finally get stone to make a simple cooking pot to cook anything.  You can't put rock, marble, or clay into a dropped items bag to clear out your inventory.  I've played for hours and can't even build a basic shelter yet.

I like the premise fo the game and it has potential, but the game needs a lot of work in playability for me to continue playing.  At the moment I truely feel I just wasted $40.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First let's get this out of the way: This game takes time and is quite a slow paced game. And expecting otherwise and getting this game will be entirely on you, because it's very much said to be right off the bat :P

Now, with that said, we can talk about the game itself. I think this game is at a great start for early development, and the potential is phenominal. I've easily no lifed this game (No really... I got the achievment and everything.) and am still looking forward to playing more. It mixes RPG and Sandbox surprisingly well, making them both interdependent on one another. You need to level skills to build, and you need to build to level skills. Then there's the fact that other than using prefab structures, you get to design everything else to your liking. You decide how big or small your settlement or even castle will be, given if you're willing to put the time and effort into finishing it. This game won't be for those who like to get right in on the action, and if that's your cup of tea, I don't advise expecting it to be so. Though I will still suggest it, because you never know. This game makes you feel like it's the simulator that it is.

If I could change anything about this game, it would be the green bar. But I'd change it to something they already plan to replace it with, metagames; something to keep you occupied and alert instead of staring blankly at a loading bar. There are a few bugs here and there, though I can't remember examples since I haven't played in a while, but I know there was. And that's to be expected, it's early alpha. VERY EARLY. It really is obnoxious to see how many kiddies whine about bugs or the fact that it's not done in some areas, because it's exactly that; early alpha development. It's like wanting a diamond out of graphite; It's not, but in time it can be. But I digress, this game is still fairly polished compared to other alphas, some even that are near beta.

You will also find this game is NOT to be played alone, for extended periods of time. While it can be done, it's soon apparent that you'll need friends to aide you in your endeavours. So, get your guild/steam group/clan ready and get to work!

So concluding my review, I'll rate it on categories:
Bugs(Expected to change as it's developed): (few crashes, nothing else that's game breaking) 7/10

Graphics(doesnt effect overall rating, but some people play for graphics): 10/10 (If you have the rig to support the graphics on max)

Optimization: 8/10

Replayablility: 9/10

NewUserFriendliness: (Not going to lie, this game requires out of game sources to actually get the ball rolling.) 5/10

Potential: 10/10

Update Frequency: 7/10

Overall Rating: 8/10

*EDIT: So I forgot to take into account the sheer price of the game. If this is your kind of game, it will be worth every penny spent. However, if you don't know what you're getting into and don't like it, then you may find you're out $40.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game enough now that I feel comfortable to put my seal of approval on it!

It has a lot of potential, and I can't wait to see how it turns out as an MMO.
Sure it's grindy, but at least the grind makes sense. You aren't grinding XP points" or stupid tings like "pixie medals" to spend at vendors like in other RPG's. In fact
date: there are no vendors! EVERYTHING is player run and all work is done by hand. You want make 30 swords for your group of friends? Better invest in smithing related skills and buildings and go out and mine and/or barter for the metal ores. The map is 100% terraformable. Everything down to the grains of sand you walk on can be harvested and has a possible industrial use. The game is still in development
recommended:
so combat is a bit wonky and it currently lacks critical things like horses and siege mechanics. But the player skirmishes and the building aspect are already a lot of fun.

A few things that annoyed me:
- Claims system: I won't go into detail here
hoursPlayed: but the forum is full of it. This mechanic needs a lot of work!\n- Terraforming: This is the least enjoyable part of the game. If you are a builder you will spend a lot of time leveling the ground. There is an observer mode
voteText: but this cannot be active during the actual digging. Also
helpfulPercent:
mining leaves very ugly unrealistic "minecraft style" block shaped holes in the terrain and locks those cells for future terraforming. So digging tunnels is a perfect griefing tactic which permanently ruins someone's village/castle.
- No NPC's other than wild animals. I wish we could let NPC's reduce some of the mindnumbing tasks like terraforming or to man the walls of your keep. What human player wants to spend their gametime playing guard on a watchtower? It would also make the villages feel a lot more alive.
- Strange skill requirements: I understand the 600 skillpoint cap. Every society needs specialists if it wants to be more than a tribe of mud people. However what I don't understand is why I need to become a farmer and progress through several other professions in the same "line" before I can become a tailor. Especially when there are such harsh limits on the amount of skillpoints I'd like to have more precise control over how I invest them. I also don't understand why I need to train a skill to even equip a sword I looted off a corpse. Why can't I just be far less effective at using said sword  without formal training? That would make it a lot more realistic.

I've already put hundreds of hours into this game
votesHelpful: and I'm hoping to continue to add many more in the future!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

LIF:YO - my first review after 18 hours gameplay...

look carefully => it's an early access, alpha...

this means bugs, missing content, crashes, compatibility issues, server wipes etc...
but for an alpha, the game is pretty good developed (compared to other alpha games out there).

the idea / concept is great and has a huge potential, even more if modding will be properly supported!
skills / crafting is not fully implemented, for some this could be a CON...


my PROs:
runs smoothly on highest graphic settings on my Lenovo Thinkpad E530 (!!!)
the game forces teamplay (imo something which has been missing in alot of multiplayer sandbox games)
huge skill and crafting system (reminds me a bit of Star Wars Galaxies)
skill dependencies
increasing, freezing or decreasing skills
crafting dependencies
nice variety of materials and crafted items with quality indicators (related to your skill lvl)
NO ZOMBIES (I'm tired of all these exodus scenarios...)

my CONs:
graphics (gladly it's not as bad as minecraft / wurm online)
alot of servers available, but only a few are highly populated
server connects (between 3-7 mins, maybe more?)
recurring server-lags
alot of time wasted by watching the green progress bar filling up (gathering materials etc.)
fighting is very unwieldy / lumbering
hud needs more attention, i.e. lock inventory / chat etc. on one side of the sceen...
alot of bad reviews on steam (mostly incomprehensible - it's an alpha not a fully developed game yet!!!)


i've read alot about crashes (CTD), but so far this has happened to me only once as i've tried to change my graphic settings to max... so i can't add it to CONs (yet...)

further i can't comment on the patch frequency nor the contents of patches, as i haven't experienced one yet!

and unfortunately i didn't find many servers with high player amounts - i hope this changes over time...

overall...
graphics => 4/10
gameplay => 5/10
skillsets/progression => 8/10
fighting => 3/10
fun => 3/10 (alone), 7/10 (group)
server availability => 4/10

i do recommend this game for people who are long-lasting sandbox/roleplay gamers with a strong drive for teamwork!

cheers and have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm in a valley. It's dark.. possibly the middle of the night? I've been digging all day. I'm trying to stop the dirt from falling in to my man made hole. Creating a shelter is difficult. My hole is half complete. I light my camp fire with the little resources I have left, take a swig of water and get back to work. I'm pulling out my pickaxe when all of a sudden I hear a snap of a twig behind me. Before I can turn around, a man wielding a large club has knocked me out cold from behind. I collapse in to my hole and he starts pouring dirt over in to my shallow grave. When he has packed the dirt solid, he sits on top of my grave and feasts on a chicken leg that he cooked over my camp fire.. and all the while I'm wondering, devs.. where is the 'Gary' DLC?

9.5/10 No game is perfect.
