reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has offered me hundreds of hours of entertainment, and some of the greatest gaming experiences of my life.

This is not a review of the contents of the game itself, but rather the effects of playing the game with a large community of players.

Playing online on a server with an active community forces you to get into diplomacy, which is a first in any game for me.
Other similar pvp-oriented games do of course offer diplomacy, but never have I had to ride up to the gates of a great kingdom and ask for assistance, and end up a vassal for a kingdom much larger and powerful than my own.

When starting a conflict or a war, you have to pick sides, maintain alliances, choose whether or not you're strong enough to sustain vassals, that in return will provide you with their military strength.

You have the option to display your strength to neighbouring kingdoms and risk war to prevent being attacked, or just lie down belly up and hope they take pity on you.
The allies you choose, can result in major server-wide conflicts escalating, and breaking alliances can have the same effect.
The choices of one kingdom affects all kingdoms.

These are all features created by the community itself. Not because the game rewards it, but because the game allows it. And it's something that really puts Life is Feudal apart from other similar games.

I give this game a big thumbs up, and I'm looking forward to the finished product.
voteText: 38 of 46 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Welcome to Work Simulator: 2016

That is what this game.  Work.  You work at getting raw materials.  You work at building structures.  You live.  In a medieval setting and as someone who has done medieval re-enactment I can say LIF isn't terribly far off the mark duplicating life in that era.

The game itself is certainly picking up speed as the dev team seems to be working harder and harder on the game.  Updates are becoming more frequent and issues such as the blinking sky and invisible trees seem to be dealt with.  At least as of this date.  The graphics are excellent.  Even on my potato computer the visuals are lovely and my fps stays stable around the 20 mark.

I know for many of you a game must be 60 fps but games in early access rarely come close to that mark.  ARK did not see an improvement in fps until late in its dev cycle.  Just as an example   Also, this is a very social game.  Playing it alone or on a dead server will bore you to death.   Unless you are truly dedicated.

A few tips for new players:

1. There is no rush to settle down.  You can live nomadically for quite some time living off of wild apples from apple trees.
2. When you do decide to settle down look for an area that is fairly flat and is reasonably close to stone, clay, iron and water.
3. While a variety of crops are nice, the two most important are wheat and flax.  Wheat for taming animals and flax to make clothing and rope with.
4. Plan your settlement in advance and get your claim monument up as fast as possible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Feudal life is NOT for the faint of heart...

This game is best played with friends and groups, it's one of the most intense adrenalin pumper you can find, but only if you put in the hours of play required to grasp it's depths...

This is one of the most complex game I ever played, so immersive and diverse.

Yes the grind can be overwhelming if you play alone, but when you play as a team with others it truely shines.

Ignore the bad reviews, specially if the reviewer doesn't have more than 100 hours, I know that at close to 200 hours I still have tons to learn about this great game. Thinking ahead, the MMO part due in 2016 will have a great potential in my point of view, allowing so much opportunity to roleplay.

Right now you need to play on a good server with very active administrators as it will influence greatly on your experience, if you are new to the game, don't be a loner and ask for help from other players or at the least do consult YouTube videos and Guides as the learning curve is bar none the steepest I have ever encountered...

I advise trying a server with 10x Experience acceleration at first in order to figure out many of the basics without having to spend tons of hours doing so, when you are comfortable, then, maybe switch to a more RP based server with more realistic restrictions.

In regards to the developers, from what I have seen in my 9 months of owning this title, they have respected the community, their roadmap is established and also followed. They are a small team but have done very good work in my opinion.

The price when not on sale might be a bit steep, encourage them and buy at full price if you can afford, otherwise wait for a sale at which point I think it becomes a great investment...

Alpha rating: 8/10 (some bugs are still present, but that's normal)
Potential Rating of MMO: 9/10 (to be released in 2016)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game that you've been waiting for! It is reminiscent of the MMO's / multi-player games of old that we all got hooked on (Ultima Online, Mount & Blade). It's creative, challenging, and extemely addictive!

The innovation in the design focuses on group play, and requires you to be part of a team in order to survive, much less succeed. The equipment is centered around crafting, in fact everything in the game is crafted. Want to be a blacksmith, with your own forge, furnance, and anvil? Great! But you better make friends with an herbalist so you can trade for flux to make steel from those iron ingonts you've been hoarding or you'll be left in the stone age!

LiF: YO is the little brother of the expected MMO version that's still under development, and to be released later as a much more massive game.

Even though this game is still in Early Access / Alpha state, it is very polished and worthy of support. A big thumbs up to the Devs so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review, because I feel that I have to recommend this game, but also warn you:

Life is Feudal is still in Early Access, but currently offers a lot of different mechanics. Finding yourself washed ashore on an big island with nothing on your body except for something to eat and some rags, you have to create everything in the game from scratch. You build your own tools from branches and stones, find some roots to eat and create your first Tiny Shack. All this building, crafting and planning (terrain flattening alone is an art/skill) takes unbelievably long time, which may annoy some people. If you are extremely impatient just skip this game - it's nothing for you.

On the other hand it is extremely satisfying to create your own buildings. Until I had a forge (which is needed for nails, for example - so a rather basic building), I spent around 20 hours in the game. When the forge was finally done, I was just proud of myself.

One reason it takes so long to achieve process, is that many activities take a lot of time: snapping a branch from a tree? Around 2 seconds. You need 20 branches for a building? Click 20 times on the same tree and simply wait each time 2 seconds. This can be annoying with the time, so better get used to it and watch TV on a second screen.

Having friends that play with you is not only nice, but highly recommended. With on character you aren't able to succeed in the various skill trees (or if you try you end up as a bad jack-of-all-trades, who is able to some jobs a little, but nothing really good). The strange server structure (everyone can host a server) leads to a huge variety of servers, leaving the public" servers rather deserted

reviewText:
Been playing the game for 14 months now and still enjoying it a lot. If you like a medieval sandbox game with survival, crafting, combat, building, etc. then this is your game. It's awesome to play in a group and form a guild, get a big city going, see a community grow and grow into a large kingdom.

The devs of this game are working hard and are dedicated to their players. Lately we have had weekly updates fixing bugs and adding new features of the game. They are listening closely to player suggestions and feedback,

Be aware though, the game is not completely finished. It has bugs and unfinished features. Don't expect a fully functional game, you will be encountering issues regularly. If you don't mind this, then go ahead and buy the game!

A last note, a YO copy of this game will give you a free slot on the MMO next year. So if you plan to play the fully functioning MMO (Summer-Fall 2016) buy it now with a 40% discount!

reviewText:
I'll start out by saying that the game has massive potential.  The skill systems and crafting are wonderful.  But there are a few problems that have been present for extended periods and make the game nearly unplayable for extended periods.

The method the game uses for saving changes to the terrain is very inefficient, which makes it very difficult to maintain a server for extended periods of time.  And if you terraform below the elevation of the water anywhere on the entire map, it causes corruptions in the game database which results in ongoing lag.  Leaving tree stumps after cutting down trees also causes server lag, and so does having too many trees on the server.

Each of these issues don't seem to be terribly important on their own, but they have all been present for an extended period and the game developers continue to add new features and have moved on to working on the MMO version fo the game rather than addressing existing bugs.  Until the developers give the game the attention it needs, this game is not worth playing.

From what little I have played, this game is quite enjoyable. Only played by myself for now, to learn basics. It can be a bit hard to get into at first, in regards of how to control your character etc, but once you get the hang of the basics you're set. LiF has it's issues, but that is to be expected in an early access game, and will hopefully be fixed quickly. This game has a lot of potential, and down the line, if it's not abandoned, I can see it possibly be very popular. My best comparison would probably be a mix of Mount&Blade and Minecraft.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do not recommend this game, because it can actually be very fun. Odd reason to not recommend a game right! See the problem is... Enjoying it means obnoxious lenghts of time doing things. Oh want to make a farm, clear an area, teraform area, plow the ground, plant seeds, and harvest crops! Sounds easy, but each step is its own huge grind. On top of that, crops take (usually, but depending on server settings) a real life 24 hours to be able to harvest them. Worse yet if you arent online when they are harvestable, they wither.
Fighting is fun enough, its laggy and glitchy but fun. It feels like a bad connection mount and blade, but dumbed down extremely. The hit detection is off, but not too bad. Combat is absolutely just spam click, however some things like shield bash knock you over and stun you. You can chain this with multiple people. The combat needs a lot of work, its geared for bad players in droves.
Its also not really a solo game, you must find a group. Now several people will argue this, but understand that these are adults who can commit 10+ hours a day to a video game. Are you able to do that? Exactly, me either because we arent shut ins. The game takes huge huge gaps of time, splitting the time load with other players is the only way to survive. Unless you play on a PvE server I guess, but I cant imagine doing that.
It was extremely fun for 4 or 5 days, playing with 3 RL buddies, then it kept getting more and more lame. Building weapons and armor takes REAL LIFE gaps if time. Like 24 hours for flax to grow, then 24 more hours to turn it into rope fibers... Oops not enough to make a full rope, 24 more hours to grow more, 24 more hours to turn that into rope fibers. I wish this was an exaggeration, but this will happen to you. You have outrageous time sinks to get skills to the level to do the next thing, like plant certain seeds, make rope or tan leather. All the while there is inevitably some huge 20 person group of euros who is pretending they are back in their countries hayday, griefing everyone mostly when they are offline. Its so weird and socially awkward.
Short story long... Its just simply not ready yet, its a fun little medieval simulator, but im not willing to grind on an alpha game, maybe you are who knows. Try it, its not the worst game ever, its just currently a hot mess.

Early Access Review

Life is Feudal is a weird game. The interface is kind of garbage. The way you interact with things is more obtuse than it needs to be. The teraforming system could really take some lessons from other games.

But I enjoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of it.

Everything you do is hard. Everything takes tons of time and effort. So when you finish, when you and your friends have built a massive keep from the ground up, it really feels like an accomplishment. And that's not something I get from many other games.

If you're adventurous and not afraid of learning this game's very unique way of doing things, by all means, give it a go.

reviewText:
TL;DR AT THE BOTTOM

Life is Feudal is an extremely grindy game (on non-boosted servers at least). If you can handle the grind, however, it has to be one of the most rewarding, fun, and interesting games out there. It puts other medieval survival games (looking at you, Reign of Kings) to shame. Still very unfinished but, in my opinion, it is definitely worth the money.

Pros:
- The game is very rewarding later on. If you can get past the first difficult cliff then you'll be set for a while. It's not like Rust or Ark in that you can wake up one day with everything gone.
- If you have a large group of friends it's a ton of fun. 10 friends in a group could create an entire empire if you work together.
- Very in depth skills. You can level just about any skill you can think of.
- Many, many paths to build your kingdom. If you want to build an underground kingdom, you can. If you'd rather a castle with massive, indestructible walls, you got it. There are infinite numbers of ways to play this game.
- Roleplay potential is crazy. I don't mean roleplay like Skyrim where you level up skills and talk to NPCs. I mean roleplay like SAMP or Project Reality. If you want to get very immersed as the king you are, you certainly can. Check out Mr Moon on YouTube for good examples of Life is Feudal roleplay.

Neutral
- Takes a ton of time to get into. You can put 50 hours into the game without getting anywhere if you swap servers frequently. On games such as Rust, you can get a decent establishment up and running within a day. On Life is Feudal, you need a good 5-6 hours of gameplay for 5 days straight to get something resembling a base.

Cons
- The combat is still pretty meh. It was significantly worse when the game was launched. It's not as good as other medieval combat in games such as Chivalry, but it gets the job done.
- Weird protection systems. In order to protect your items you must make some kind of totem/idol thing and give it frequent sacrifices of herbs. It takes 1-1.5 hours of farming in the first place to make it however if you miss one day of sacrifices then it gets destroyed and your stuff is gone.
- Playing solo is impossible. Well, not technically, but you can't expect to get anywhere in any reasonable amount of time if you dont have a few friends to help you out. Hell, at least one friend will make a huge different.

Please note that quite a few of my personal issues with the game (time investment, mainly) is made null by servers with increased farming rates.

I will edit this review with more pros/cons as I play the game more.

TL;DR - The game is very in depth, tons of fun, and very time consuming. Bring your friends. If you don't have a lot of free time play on an increased rates server. Over all, I'd give it a 8/10 based on my personal enjoyment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I honestly think that a lot of the negative reviews towards this game were written without considering the game's spiritual predecessors: Wurm Online, Haven & Hearth, and whichever others gave way to inspire the mechanics in LiF. This game maintains the same level of grind as Wurm, assuming a 1.0 skillgain multiplier, while making every last accomplishment feel wonderful. When I got my first tunnel dug to ore, it was a great feeling, and then smelting the ore, and so on.

The only agonies I face in this game really come from trying to play solo, terraforming (even with other people I imagine it's dreadful to flatten out a cliff face, as it really should be.) the occasional bug and probably loss of life and items from PvP encounters. I don't quite appreciate the way the skills work, with the prerequisite skills and all that, due to the fact that A: there's a(n) (adjustable) skillcap, and B: some of the sequencing doesn't make sense. IIRC, use of chainmail is restricted to after you reach level 30 in warhorse training, and other armor skills are thrown after other random combat skills. It just doesn't feel right. Lastly, if you're playing alone, just absolutely forget about making real progression with the skillcap at its default settings, because nearly every skill is required to make a nicely functioning settlement.

Is this game worth the price tag? That's debatable. At this state, I'd personally say yeah, but I understand others that aren't as seasoned to the type of game this is might want to hold out for a sale or for more content to be ironed out and implemented. At the time of writing I've had ~40 hours in the past few days, and I've got to say, nothing feels more satisfying than seeing what all I've managed to accomplish on my own.

reviewText:
Title: Life is Feudal: Your Own
Genre: Action, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Early Access
Developer: Bitbox Ltd.
Publisher: Bitbox Ltd.

“Realistic medieval multiplayer sandbox with terraforming, free preset and modular building construction, rich crafting (smelting, forging, farming, animals breeding etc.), survival, no target physics based combat, original combat formation system and numerous other features.”

**Do note that this is an Early Access game, things will still change.**

Overall Experience:
My first impression when I tried the game is that the way the game is presented is very good. It's set in a medieval environment, your character starts off in a woodland area, the land is a mix of untamed forests, grass and water. The buildings and tools represent this era very well, a lot of effort has gone into the background. I like the realism behind the crafting system too, like if you go to fish, you won't always catch a fish. It's relaxing as well when you're not getting attacked every five seconds by the wildlife, which gives you time to do things. The game starts off with you having to explore, forage and prospect the land to find and gather materials. From these materials you craft primitive items that allow you to fish, chop trees, dig for ore, and from then on you can choose what you want to specialise in as well. There is a limited number of points you can pour your points into, which means you will end up focusing on one or two skills more than the others. For example you may choose to build a farm, and learn to cook and tend to animals. Or maybe you want to learn how to build a house and design it with different architectural styles. Perhaps you want to create potions. Or learn to forge armour and weapons. So you choose to focus on the desired skill tree until you are able to make the higher end materials.
This is good because with each player specialising in an skill tree, it means there is more chance of cooperation happening, for players contributing to build a village or a working clan, rather than running around killing people straight away. You can adjust the max learning points from server to server, but limiting it persuades people to work together for the greater good.

Gameplay:

This is one of the things that lacks, and I feel the need to say it. The learning curve in my opinion is really hard, and it's difficult to get into the game if you don't have any friends that play it, who can help you to learn it. I liked the fact that the game requires you to be patient. It's not the kind of game where you can mindlessly run around and get everything you need in less than an hour. It's the kind of game that will require a lot of time for you to be able to get even some of the things you need. It's a slow paced game, but things are sped up when you do it with people - which means once again the game is encouraging cooperation.

Controls:

The controls are ok, but the main problem is that you need to tab for virtually everything, which gets pretty annoying. I would prefer the viewing and gathering to be different than needing to tab for it each time. The screen freezes with wherever you tabbed so there isn't much free roaming/observing. The movement of the character is good and quite smooth, but the rest is clunky.

Sound:

I really liked the music in the game. The game is very slow paced, and the music fits in perfectly in the background, nice and relaxing for something that you will end up spending a lot of time on. It changes when you go into combat as well.

Learning Curve:

I think the learning curve is really hard, and this needs to be mentioned for players who may not have so much patience with this. There's a lot of things you need to do, with your inventory you need to point and click for everything, and each action takes time to process. With the character creation menu as well there is no explanation of the skills you'll be putting your points into, which is a shame because these will affect the outcome of what you do in the game. For example one of the skill trees just says Forestry"
date:
but with no detail as to what this means. What will forestry allow you to do and craft and how you can do it within the game. This would benefit enormously from having a small description underneath for each skill and talent.

Verdict:

The game itself has a LOT of potential. The game is well detailed
recommended:
and the crafting system is very in depth and gives you a lot of options. However the game will take a long time to learn - it isn't for anyone who doesn't have the patience to keep at something.

6.5/10
Why 6.5? Because this game has potential
hoursPlayed:
however it has not reached the potential I think it can. But then again that is what Early Access is for.

Want moar?
Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!"

Early Access Review

LiF is one of the games I've been playing since starting my break from a different game earlier this year so I'd like to share my views on LiF as well.

Overall:
As others have said, it will not be for everyone, and the MMO version (LiF) vs the private server version (LiF:YO) are two rather different beasts.  Having been in the alpha for LiF, the biggest difference between the MMO and personal server versions is simply the size of the map, the lack of the claims" mechanic (think of this system as a combination deed and guild/nation mechanics in Wurm Online)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is Feudal... indeed! The amount of time you can spend to build a single house is.... horrendeous. You need building logs? ok go chop trees, easy! you need windows? go melt some sand to make glass, easy! you need doors? even better, you can get wood planks from the trees you just chopped. A lock for the door? oh ok I'll just smelt some iron... wait it has to be steel? how the F do I do this?? oh you need Flux, a compound found in plants, and you can acces it via Herbalism skill. Wait I just reached my skill cap? oh jeez. I'm out of this game......
Someone comes to help you build your village? They want to be a part of this? Great!! they get the flux then!

This is an example of the complexity of the game and how dependent you have to other players. It might be scary for newbies but if you get into it with 2 or 3 friends, you can really achieve something marvelous, or at least so I have seen.

Minecraft is for kids, Rust is for teens, LiF is for adults who want to achieve something.

At your own risk.

reviewText: Singleplayer Review:\nCompared to most games I've played, this openworld game takes a lot longer to get into. Things take far more time to build, the terraforming is different than most, getting things organized can take a great deal of effort. I wasn't really able to get into the game as much as I'd have liked to. The trailers showed off more of the late game functions than early game. You'll have a hard time trying to so much as construct a hut to start. Visually, it's delightful, conceptually, it's fantastic, the drawback is that it takes as long to cut down and carve out lumber in the real world as it does in Life is Feudal. If you're patient unlike me, you'll get a kick out of this game. If you want to get into the swing of things as quickly as possible, you'd be better off looking elsewhere.

Early Access Review

Is this game worth 40 dollars? No. Not quite, will it be? Yes, without a doubt. This game is very addicting, it is so fun, you will wonder why you find it so fun; and consider that something may be wrong with you. Primarily because you stare at things for hours on end.

First you look at grass, then trees, then ground that you flatten, then you look at ground you are digging into, then you look at ore you are mining, then the furnace you are smelting it in, then the leather crafting equipment, then the forge, and finally; you look at people running away from you, before you catch up to them and kill them with weapons and armor.

11/10 Would fail to communicate with peasant thief because of Alpha Build, then kill him and take all his rocks, rags and apples.

EDIT - There seems to be a LOT of confusion about combat in this game, rightfully so. People say it is broken because they attempt PVP VERY EARLY INTO THEIR PLAYTHROUGHS, and try to beat each other to death with tools mostly, iron and primitive.

reviewText:
This game is all about long and deeply involved construction and crafting processes.  It requires teamwork and patience, if you do not have these traits you will not enjoy this game.  However, if you do, this game will be horribly addicting after you find a group to work with.

There are still a large number of game breaking bugs in the game, and while I understand the developer's choice to pull the game out of early access, it wasn't ready.  What works, works great.  What doesn't, well...

If I hadn't spent 200 hours in the past 2 weeks on this game I'd probably be more willing to give it a negative review, it's just so damn addicting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really enjoyed learning and testing Life is Feudal: Your Own. Even though it's current content is limited, this game has absolutely AMAZING potential. The concept is truly awesome. However, there are some pretty serious issues with the game.

Aside from exploiters and trolls, the engine the game runs on is utterly terrible. The engine cannot currently support 64 people (or even 20 very active players) without a substantial amount of serverside lag. This isn't something that can be fixed. It has to do with a memory limitation of the 32 bit process that the engine uses. Until they remake the game on another engine, an MMO with 10,000 people per world will be entirely unplayable (no matter how much they break up the world into individual areas with their own server).

Secondly, the combat system, while very interesting in concept, is horrible. I understand what the developers were going for, but what they designed is too clunky to be enjoyed.

Lastly, the developers are doing an excellent job smashing bugs and fixing other errors. Even if they can fix the exploits and remaining game-breaking bugs, it is still difficult to recommend LiF:YO for $40. The server and engine issues cannot be fixed without using a different engine. The only exception would be if someone has ten to twenty friends to play with and are willing to wait a few months for more content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to recommend this game.  As a longtime fan of open sandbox games going back to MUDs I love hardcore sandbox action.  However good the idea though, don't think this one is going to be the next Ultima Online or EvE:online sans spaceships.

You can read alot about the gameplay and unfinished state, but really the developer is small and needs funds to make anything happen.  I won't knock that.  I for one was willing to invest a few dollars in the idea.

However upon playing for quite a long time it’s my honest opinion the game is structurally flawed.  Read that as I do not think their current engine and code is capable of being ported to an MMO framework and from what I have seen so far, I'm skeptical that it will even be stable as a Minecraft style dedicated server game - EVER.

Many others have detailed problems so far, but I can say that this game currently (NOV2014) does not support most video cards and you will spend around 5-10 minutes loading into most servers only to have no sound and quite probably crash within 1 minute of dropping in.  This has something to do with the terraforming and other stuff I know nothing about.

This is not the review I want to leave.  I love the idea.  Hope this company can make it happen, or another larger developer can buy it and make it what it should be.  There is a demand for hardcore sandbox action in this environment and as an MMO it can be profitable for decades, just look at the EVE:Online model that has thrived even with internet spaceships which turns alot of hardcore RPG'rs off.  But cannot recommend this game now and unlikely will for quite some time going forward.

reviewText:
We asked the admin on a server if he could help us out by spawning us some bones for our monument, since the server would crash if we killed an animal. (this has since been fixed)

The admin spawned a bear right next to our camp, in which the bear decided we looked very tasty.
The bear stampeeded across our nice neat rows of houses, attacking us and killing us mercicely.
Eventually we chased the bear down the coast and beat it to death with shovels.
After my team mates and I killed the bear, we proceded to all stand around and argue over who would get it.

A fight ensued during which my character fell unconscious.
My team mates then decided to either A) kill me with a shovel and save the effort or reviving me, or B) beat my broken bones back into place with a hammer.

11/10 would listen to my team mates discuss how to torture my unconscious body again.

ACTUAL REVIEW:

GAMEPLAY
Okay so this is a bloody fantastic game, you start out on an island with absolutly nothing. Combat is really fun and reminds me of Age of Chivary. There are so many options it is absolutly insane. They all work together flawlessly and end up making for a great gameplay, be it bloody combat or building yourself a settlement with friends. Key point about this game, YOU NEED FRIENDS OR YOU WILL DIE. It is very hard to solo this game. Almost impossible, I have not seen someone do it unless they steal/kill for their possesions.
GRAPHICS
D11 just got released two days ago, and already all of the graphical glitches I have seen have been fixed. This game runs very smoothly on ultra with my gtx 970. High settings I was running it at almsot 100 FPS. Even at high settings however the terrain looks absolutly beautifal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Type of Game:

First person or Third Person Multiplayer Medieval Survival Sandbox Open World Simulation

Version Played:

Early Access PC version through Steam

Similar Games:

DayZ, Rust, and to a lesser degree the Mount & Blade series

The Good:

An epic game world filled to the brim with content, whether it be things to craft or items to use, the game world has no limits on what you can do.
Everything you see is reachable and harvestable.
A very strong medieval aesthetic, which makes the game stand out more so than the competition (i.e. DayZ, Rust, etc…).
Multiplayer is this game’s strong suit with a great enjoyment to be had by exploring the medieval landscape with a buddy or two.
The crafting, building, and surviving aspects of the game are much more exciting when experienced with a friend
There is a level progression system, which you typically won’t find in games of this nature.
I only say this because a progression system is much more fun in a survival type game and brings with it a sense of urgency that you would find in a PDL genre-type.
The map is always present, which usually isn’t the case for these games. This makes coordinating a rendezvous with your friends much easier and drastically improves the multiplayer experience.
As you’ll find with other game’s of this type, the relationships with other players is a fascinating experience. For the most part other players typically pursue a Lord of the Flies mentality and will often exert their power over those that have a weak footing in the game’s hierarchy. However, when you encounter other players that are helpful it makes the game much easier to digest and enjoy.

The Bad:

Life is Feudal is very clunky and not polished at the moment. Menu and interface options aren’t intuitive and present themselves as overly complex.
Complete lack of a tutorial, which is understandable for an “Early Access” title, but you should be aware none-the-less.
Single-player is difficult to swallow as most other players will just grief you over and over again. Playing with your friends is the only way to currently guarantee a good time.
Outside of the medieval aspects, this game is more of the same if you’ve played Rust or DayZ. I would argue that the features are much deeper than what Rust has to offer and Rust is Life is Feudal’s closest likeness.

Can you play it while the children are awake?

Due to the nature of multiplayer shenanigans, I often had to play without my sound on. Other players are often rude and mean, which can lead to profane language and crude lingo. There is also combat and violence, but I felt as though the graphics weren’t grand enough to matter in that regard.

Did I make time to complete it?

As a multiplayer game there is no completion per say. I did build a number of structures and survived for a number of hours.

Redlight or Greenlight?

This game is currently at a redlight.

The content that is currently offered is just not worth the asking price of $39.99. If you were a gamer that REALLY enjoyed Rust, then you will be getting your money’s worth in this title as the content is better. Outside of that demographic, I just don’t see the appeal of paying a large amount of money to experience a lesson in human nature (i.e. griefing) and confusing gameplay (lack of tutorial). This may change as the game updates, so please check back here for any changes in my preview.

Reviewer:

MisterS42

A Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buy:
http://www.gamersglance.com

reviewText: Life is Feudal is a medieval fantasy MMORPG set in a sandbox environment. The world is massive and immersive, allowing players to control almost every aspect of the physical environment. Build everything from huts to homes, to outposts and even villages. Or, if you’re feeling ambitious, you can create your own mega-castle! Work the land for natural resources, craft weapons and armor, and gain valuable player skills in order to stay alive. Life Is Feudal is an excellent game, it's in a early stage with obvious bugs but highly playable and already has a lot of content to offer. Devs have been tackling the bugs and fixing things as they arrive, and are very active on the community.\n\nSo far this has to be one of my all time favorite Sandbox game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ignore all the bad reviews. People have no idea what they are talking about.

1. Game developers are very active and interact with the community constantly.
2. Each patch makes massive strides forward towards full release.
3. The game mechanics are spot on. Gathering, crafting, mining and combat feels great.
4. The game LOOKS and SOUNDS beautiful. This is quality.
5. It takes me a minute to load into a game. People are not looking at server ping when connecting. It's not the game that sucks, it is their ISP.
6. Learning curve is not steep -- game-play is very logical, just requires time and dedication.
7. I can see this game being out of Early Access by the end of year for sure.

I've spent MANY hours playing this game and can honestly say this is one of the best games on Steam. But, a lot of these negative reviews are coming from people who have no idea what they purchased. Here are a few helpful hints and tips about Life is Feudal: Your Own!

1. Gather plant fibres from the ground. Useful flint front the mountains/hills, and branches from the trees.
2. Craft primitive tools be right clicking on a branch. A primite shovel and axe and you are well on your way.
3. Find a fairly flat piece of land and terraform just enough to build a little hut (4 x 4). Do this until your terraforming is at 60; then you can make a primitive pick-axe and use it to dig tunnels.
4. This is not Minecraft.
5. You can not enter a terrority that is claimed by someone else unless it is judgement hour.

Buy this game. Especially now since it is on discount. WELL WORTH IT!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is Feudal: Your Own is a incredibly interesting game, in particular in regards to gameplay and multiplayer. This is something personal, but in my eyes it is the most promising indie game for all of 2014 and the first half of 2015.

However, everyone who is thinking about purchasing this game should weigh pro's and con's and decide for himself/herself if he/she really wants to have this game, since the complexity of some game mechanics and the large amount of time you need to devote to achieve a decent understanding of the game, probably scare a lot of people off only after a few minutes of playing the game.

For those who absolutely adore games that need some time to get used to and to get started, this is for you. Unlike in a few other games, such as the infamous 'The Stomping Land', the building is not restricted to only a few buildings and objects, but it takes quite some time to reach the stage of actually constructing something big, so if you look for a game where you can build a castle within ten hours, then you are wrong with LiF:YO.

I would also highly recommend only to play with a few friends, the more the better, as the unique skill system prevents one individual from learning all the skills that are out there, meaning that specializing on a skill tree (e.g. logging or terraforming), as the max cap of skill point will only be enough to absolutely maximize one skill tree.

In general this game is great fun when you are with other people, but it is only a glimpse at the size and massiveness that LiF:MMO will bring in the third quarter of 2015.

reviewText:
***This will be my first review on any game from Steam/in general, so if I miss anything out, please forgive.***

I only have 60 hours or so of play-time recorded, but around 55 hours of those 60, I had been playing Life Is Feudal with people I never even gamed with before. By this, I simply mean that while at first not knowing/understanding much, I came across one person, then a couple more people, etc, until eventually (my favorite moments in the game) this group of ours had owned a small farming/fishing/trade village. Needless to say, the very first 6 hours or so of game-time was quite unfamiliar and I had a lot of help. But from that point on, I realize now that there are probably slim-to-none other games that can replicate what Life Is Feudal is about. What do I mean? How can I say that (with only just one review/little experience)?

This game boils down to having patience and having the ability to take in advice/learn from others. If you have no patience or have no interest in taking advice or learning from others, you won't enjoy this game to its fullest potential!

The grind can be offsetting, the in-depth complex skilltrees can be confusing, but the learning and level of detail put into this game... I have not found one in this similar era/style, to be better. And I am still looking till this day for one to top it.

You start off with basic character customization. Couple different race options, hair-styles, facial hair; you get the jist. From then, you either have no idea what to put what points into which stat/skill, or looked up a general guide and understand. If you didn't, which I didn't (at first), you'll then load into the game and be off to your new 'life'.

The very first thing I can say that differs from most games: the controls. The way in which you switch in and out of different modes. Then, the way in which you interact with your environment. Not sure since when, but luckily now, you can Mass Produce things, which makes (incoming tip) gathering something such as Plant Fiber, so much easier. Now, you can follow the Tutorial, which guides you to making Primitive Tools. There are a plethora of them, each correlating with different crafts/skills. Once you have the Primitive Tools, you start to attempt to build things. You need resources of different types, in order to construct certain things. So you branch out to other skilltrees. Long story short, there is so much to do in this game that you could sit for 12 hours straight on this and not realize how long it's been!

What I will not do is list pros/cons. I feel this game has enough positives in its arsenal to warrant at least a try. Hell, I was on a certain server or two, got really far in my skilltrees, then said server or two either would wipe their servers, or would be inactive/shutdown for a bit of time. I just recently got my gaming-motivation back and not even a few days later, I reinstalled this game and might even log back in after completing this review.

Will you enjoy it? I have no damn clue. I think if you have a reasonable amount of time, a reasonable amount of patience and learning skills.. I *think* this game deserves a shot on your computer. Try it. I would also suggest something else, in terms of how you can get the game, but I will not say on this review (message me 'G). What I do think, though, is that if you are a person who enjoys a challenge; maybe even possess a taste for Medieval Realism, then I am confident you will enjoy this game as much as I have for my not-so-lengthy time spending (60 hours, to me, is quite a bit >.<)...

Feel free to add me on Steam if you need any advice or help, I'll gladly play as well if time permits.

Hope this review helped, even a little! Now get out there, ya 'Bloody Peasant!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Remember:- life is feudal!

Positives:- LiF:YO caters to a wide range of interests.  Ever wanted to be a town planner in medieval Europe?  Love farming simulation but kinda feel like a cheat sitting in a John Deere?  Fascinated by the history of feudal times and want to live it just a little?  Know the theories of Marx, Durkheim, and Weber and are interested in the sociological concepts of individualism and collectivism and want to try living in an age with a whole other mindset?  Or just love gearing up in metal stuff and hitting people with swords?  You will enjoy this game.

Negatives:- This is where it gets hard.  Having played over 1000 hours before making this review.  just about all the things that I would have seen as a negative have improved or been fixed altogether.  The dev team has been brilliant, and if they keep delivering like they have, LiF:YO will go from being a great Alpha to a fantastic release.  Anyone who wrote a review not recommending the game essentially because it is Alpha should do the honest thing and try the game out again, then adjust their review if the problems they experienced have lessened or gone away.

Gameplay:-  The most important thing to get right playing this game is to play it with other people.  Seriously.  If I had a thin leather for every player I've seen try to solo this game, and after a day or three depart forever leaving nothing but a tiny plaster shack, a furnace, and some unfinished wattle fencing, I'd have enough to armor 100 novice archers.  Remember, life is feudal.  In feudal times the average serf lived within spitting distance of at least a dozen other average serfs.  Ah!" I hear you say; "serfing isn't for me
date: I'll be a Lord or at least someone rich enough to own flanged mace!".  Sure
recommended: in which case you'll need to be around even more people.  Coz heres the thing ok

reviewText:
A brief summary of my experience of Life is Futile.

1.   Got conned into buying by one of my friends.
2.   Joined the server he was on, with high expectations.
3.   More friends joind in, we started to have a merry band of men :D
4.   Collected wood, plants and grass (enough wood to start my own version of Ikea and enough grass to fuel the whole US cattle industry for a decade).
4.   Worked as a collective to build our own vision of Utopia.
5.   Some guys in Knights armour turn up and try to bully us.
6.   Spent hours learning skills and crafting our own weapons and armour.
7.   Find out the King has sent his trusty Knights, also find out the King is a bit of a cretin...
8.   Got together with others on the server, who dislike the King and plot a treasonous rebellion.
9.   Usurped the King and declared myself ruler.
10. Find out the King is friends with the admin and get our whole group banned from the server.
11. Repeat step 2-10

If you are happy being a peasant and working for others, this game is for you.

If like me, Hitler, Pol Pot, Stalin, Saddam Hussein and Barack Obama you want ultimate power, rent your own server!

When the devs implement bridges, I will claim one and guard it like the Black Knight from Monty Pythons Holy Grail...

Until that glorious time comes, Life Is Futile will be a bitter sweet memory.

P.S. Lost count how many servers we got banned from...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is clearly still in early alpha but even so there are a lot of solid game mechanics. The multiplayer is what really makes this game, the ability to group up with friends on your own personal server and to then start your own little village is really fun.

There are multiple professions for you to pick and choose from. The range from farming, to mining or to even hunting. If you can think of a profession that is vital to a Medieval village then, it is in there.

There are a few headscratching moments like having to learn how to wear leather armour before being able to use a bow. I don't really understand that to be perfectly honest. If it wasn't for one of my friends being a tanner then I'd never be able to become a Archer.

Overall, the game has a long way to go before it meets it's goal but with buying this game in early access, you're supporting the devs in reaching that goal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great sand-box multiplayer game. With a overall great community and interesting and engaging building/ crafting mechanics. Easy to learn and very hard to master. If you like medieval times, and working for what you get I recommend this game.

If you are the type of player that wants to run around killing people without putting any time in, I would recommend you look else were. Not to say your play style is not welcomed, but game mechanics make players wait days, and weeks before they can craft their first sword. After that you have to wait a few weeks before you can actually use any good gear. Simply put if you want things to be done instantaneous you will not enjoy this game. It is very slow paced, but personally I like that aspect.

If you enjoy making friends, and working together with other people, or to role-play heavily then I would recommend this game. The game mechanics forces players to work together to create any mid to end game buildings or gear. All skill trades intersect with each other, and all of them need each other's help. Because of this set up you will have to group up or trade if you want to create end game gear.

devs are very good about updates (even if they fall behind) and are constantly listening to feed back and improving the core mechanics. The game is a bit expensive but I believe that it is worth every dollar.

reviewText:
I have played this game since the original alpha-- and i gotta say its great and just gets better! It can be both exciting and relaxing in turns. It is sort of....Rust, meets base building, meets Knights of Chivalry.

Pros:
Constantly being patched with fixes, updates, additions, and improvements - (game has come a LONG way from alpha)
Good controls
Nice graphics
decent background music
nice character creation
the ability to build just about any kind of structure, regardlless of shape or size.
deep crafting system
deep skill system
great terraforming
farming, fishing, hunting, and taming of a large variety of wildlife
Seasons change
RP mods available
the ability to host your own server - w/ customizable settings for just about everything from trees, to skills, to animals

And....
-- It was mentioned at some point if you buy this game before the MMO launches you might get a copy of the MMO for free!

Cons:
No party system - you cant see your friends on the map (better be good at giving directions!)
People who skip the tutorial and dont have anyone to teach them how to play are gonna have a bit of a learning curve

reviewText: I was reading some of the negative reviews for this game at first and after playing it wondered why it's received enough bad reviews to get the Mixed" designation on steam. As you continue to play the game it becomes apparent though. Most of the "survival" genre fanbase is looking for something they can call "realistic" without having to put in the effort this game requires. Most gamers these days are all about instant gratification with minimal effort. Everything in the game takes time to build and to become proficient at. Couple that with a fanbase where 1/2 or more of the players come from games like DayZ or Minecraft
date: where important items are found at random on the ground and crafting is simple
recommended: and it shouldnt come to anyone's surprise that there would be enough bad reviews on steam to turn heads.\n\nAll that being said

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far it's great game that has a lot of potential if it gets fixed up a little more. Most content is not in the game yet as you can see on the devs roadmap, but they're getting there. Slowly. As of right now resources are exhaustible and performance is decreasing rapidly with more players and more customizations to the world. After you built your keep, walls and city and gotten your high-end quality equipment there isn't much to do other than bash someone elses face in. Which is fun a few times, but it get's repetetive real fast.
As of right now I do not recommend it, if they bring more content into the game and increase performance drastically this might change to yes though. It does have potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't know where to start! Life Is Feudal is by far one of the BEST sandboxes ive ever played. Its got unique systems and mechanics for crafting, forging, cooking, alchemy and other things like terraforming and logging. ALL of which have their own skill sets and levelling so you won't progess skills the same way twice, or find the same items & ingredients in the same place which is a nice touch. Depending on which server you are on, there are also variable stat & skill caps this means that if you specialise in a certain skill it can determine how useful you will be in building settlments, and once reach the leveling limit of one skill, thats it Reach the stat and skill caps and leveling up will be a distant memory as they will become rare occurences. This means prople of different skills will have to work together and pool resources and skills, especially if a battle takes place in nearby settlements/towns and repairs have to be made quickly. For example, one person of your group/guild might be a master blacksmith, while another will be a master Logger, so choosing which skill to level completely is CRUCIAL.

You basically start the game with nothing but food scraps and rags for clothes, so your first instinct is to create primitive gear which can be done quite quicker than you would expect. As you start to meet random people in your travels, you will also start to learn of the surrondings more and where developments have been started. I remember one time where I spawned into the world and I basically turned right and saw an ENTIRE FORTRESS built far off into the distance on the other side of an island, and as I explored around there was the odd camp/shack then a small town where groups have formed a guild. It cleary shows the sheer scope of how important working with people is in this game.

Another strong point is the combat mechanics, if you have played the Mount & Blade games you will feel right at home here with the directional movements and there are even group formations to be used in a battle! Formations like shield walls, phalanx/wedge, and defensive circle formations can be applied and changed on the fly in mid battle, VERY useful for when 2 armies or more are battling it out.

The final thing you will notice (and the most notable when you start the game and spawn into a world) is the graphics. At the moment there are Direct x 7 and 9 graphics, DO NOT let the discussions and reviews fool you! This game is a visual master piece considering the DX7 and 9 graphics closely resemble TES4: Oblivion's graphics, but with the fast approaching release date the Direct x 11 graphics will make this one of the most beautiful medieval themed sandboxes ever made!

Overall i give this game a 8.5/10 and thats just at an EARLY ACEESS point of veiw as Bitbox are at the moment of smoothing everything out for the release and beginning to implement future features upon post release. This has been one of the most comprehensive, immersive and challenging games ive played to date. Looking forwand to more!

11/10 would recommend this game to those who have never played sandboxes or similar themed games like MMORPG's as it is worth the experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

( wrote this before release )

Lemme' tell you this.
I am currently in actual testing of this product.
This is LiF: YO, not the actual MMO yet. This is a very much scaled down version for continued development. You will have the ability to do many of the things coming to the MMO, some much sooner than later, some not for a bit of time yet.
No, I am not at liberty to share much info, being a humble test guy, I will say this.. this is going to be the 'must have' of Medieval style games. No magic, no orcs, no elves, just a pretty much true to life feudal world, where you can be literally anything by striving for it. The game has open PvP but with a price. If you feel the need to be a bandit then thats fine, but every action will mark you, killing an innocent will cost you until your a marked criminal with no coming back, and if you die, you lose massive skills, whereas being a highwayman and just robbing people will only mark you as a thug. Meanwhile fighting and being a hero in the warfare will gain you status, along with helping out folks. So its pretty much set like real life, you can be / do what you want, but actions have consequences. It also requires you realize your not alone in the world. You cant do it all. Everyone serves a role, from the butcher, the baker to the candlestick maker, even the village monk / priest, or gaurd. IE I am not a fighter myself, so I really rely on the combat guys, but they rely on others to cook for them. etc.
This is shaping up to be great!

reviewText:
If you want an in depth experience with an incredibly deep crafting system, this game is for you. If you are looking for a quick fix, easy to play, low commitment game, then you are probably looking in the wrong place.
Not sure why there are negative reviews popping up for this game during release. Are there issues? From what I have seen online, sure. Are the developers working to fix these issues, absolutely, just go take a peek at the news feed. I must be one of the extremely lucky ones that is only having a few minor texture issues, and the developer is aware of that and is working on that as well.
This game is one of the best looking, most in depth games I have come across in a long while, and I'm extremely happy I stumbled upon it. If you are concerned about the issues they are having at launch, just keep an eye on the news feed and they will let you know when they have come upon a fix for them. Other than that, this developer is actually listening to the community and working on player suggestions to add to an already pretty amazing game.
The reality is, this was an early access game that made it to release, and that in itself is a rare and amazing thing, Bitbox should be commended for the time and effort they have and continue to put into a game that they are clearly as passionate about as a lot of the people who play it are.

This game is increasingly difficult to review when you take into account certain factors that have affected it. Firstly, something I must of course say, the game is early-access alpha. It is still in development and so I appreaciate this and will not comment on the large amount of bugs and other early-access" esque issues that the game has.

I think that the paramount issue with Life is Feudal: YO is the simple fact that the advertisement for the game is misleading. Not on purpose mind
date: I simply feel as though the developers struggled to catagorize the game they have begun to produce and so consumers who stumble across it are not entirely sure what they are purchasing. I myself am very much into the Mount & Blade franchise and when I stumbled across this game I (and friends from my gaming community) expected it to be like a much larger open world RPG version of the mod for Mount & Blade: Warband
recommended: Persisitent World. The game showed pictures of an adventurer moving throughout a completely player made land. This gave me and my friends the misconception that the game was a Skyrim meets Mount & Blade meets Runescape/LOTR Online - what sounded like a perfect compliation.\n\nIn actual fact the game is rust meets minecraft. It focuses on the survival aspect far more than the roleplaying rpg medieval aspect. This should be advertised FAR more clearly as survival game fans would appreciate it much more than Medieval role-play fans. Let me try to explain in a DayZ way

reviewText:
Age of Empires - in the first person! --Reviewed at 18 hours--

If you are in doubt about this game, I urge you to just jump in and YouTube & Wiki willing you will enjoy this game!
There is little to no tutorial and things may frustrate you, I would urge you to push past this and open up a world of possibilities

Not many games get 15 hours of straight play; Life is Feudal did it for me.

The game based in a medieval era urges the players not to play as a simulator but to think logically and forward think for your new character and live in the world grinding out skills to reach the next skill type that you need to progress your settlement. (So yes it is a simulator but not to the level that we have previously known it, you get invested in your players as you roleplay out their lives and complete many, many tasks)

As a SP game it will be hard to manage your land and its needs along with other players in the MP realm...
You may choose to be a travelling tradesmen specialised in your skill trading for what you need or you might choose to join a group and move forward in leaps and bounds for the greater good of the group... However be forewarned, as you grow into a large group the needs change and your supply of food and mining rewards may begin to find a low and risk everything that you have so far worked so valiantly for!

The depth of this game is astounding, the devs listen to the gitch reports and actively seek to fix them with frequent patches. Yes glitches do occur and there are other things that just don't match up; this game has come a long way from its alpha release in many ways and its current gameplay today proves just that.

The question is are you willing to fork out your own investment into a character and help etich them them into history.

10/10 for such vast gaming ideas
8(9) for current game state due to some stability issues
8.5 for graphics - this game is beautiful, however Nvidia uses may struggle; the Devs use ATI.
8 for sound - mesmerizing
10 for the right server and community input

Buy the game if you are on the fence;
buy the game if you doubt the glitches;
buy the game if you like medieval games;
buy the game if you like want minecraft with REAL graphics;
buy the game if you like Age of Empires, it's it in first person!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoy ARK, minecraft, KSP, and Neverwinter. (Just to give you an idea of my preferences.)

This game *does* have some bugs remaining. I had some sort of memory leak (or other compouning problem) and sound issues after playing for awhile. It became unbearable after something like 5 or 6 hours (but my system is pretty high-quality, so your mileage may vary). However, a simple restart of the game solved the problem and only took a minute. This is not game-breaking.

I love this game... but it won't be for everyone.

Some things to note:
A) Most servers use conservative server settings that are pretty close to default.
B) At default settings, things in this game can take a long time and a lot of effort to achieve. You'll have to earn it.
C) With default settings, you almost cannot survive alone. (Farming/nature lore can both allow you to forage for food, but cooking requires multiple skill sets that will almost undoubtedly require multiple participants. If you plan on jumping into the game with no friends to help you and with no idea what you're doing... you will probably fail.
D) Some servers have much more newb-friendly settings... look for high level/stat caps and high resource gather multipliers/exp multipliers.
E) Part of the appeal of this game *IS* the fact that it takes so much effort to be successful... reaching a milestone can be very rewarding. I'm looking forward to getting my first shack built.
F) There's a lot to learn about this game, the wiki is your friend.
G) Something that I had to find out through experience and lots of looking online: Many abilities require advanced skills with a skill level of 0... but they must still be unlocked to be used, and many require lots of skill levels in a prerequisite skill to be unlocked. IE: cutting billets for cooking fuel requires lvl 0 carpentry, but carpentry doesn't unlock until lvl 60 logging.
H) Working with terrain is tedious and very time consuming... don't plan on getting in here and levelling mountains like in minecraft... you'll be digging the rest of your life... it's just implausible.
I) The skill system is very detailed and random events can occur. I cut my hand while trying to forage and it bled for like 10 minutes. Not life threatening... but interesting. This game feels kindof like Neverwinter or D&D meets ARK set in medieval times.
J) There's no magic (although prayer can have supernatural effects [including teleportation]).

So far this is just a description of the main points of the game as I see it at the moment.
Now for the good and bad.

GOOD:
-Devs are pretty active.
-Plenty of servers with a variety of settings.
-Very playable, few bugs.
-Very unique.
-Highly replayable. (partly because of how limited you usually are in character development)
-Very conducive to roleplay. (Though it's often not required/expected)
-The music. (I love it, totally my own opinion)

BAD:
-A little expensive for an alpha game.
-Graphics are very mix-n-match. (IE: character model looks amazing, but the hair models look atrocious... kinda weird)
-I love the focus on team-play... however, there *needs* to be a single skill set that will allow you to survive in the wilderness on your own. Sure, you won't be eating cake... and it's likely you'll spend most of your time hunting/fishing/gathering to support yourself... but it seems unrealistic that you can't have a single survival skill that enables you to build a simple campfire, hunt/fish, and grill up a bit of dinner. This could also make for a new skill tree leading into scouting" skills.

"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I am really enjoying this game and from the different posts, reddit's and everything else this game seems to have some awesome features still to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After spending quite a few hours straight since I bought it, I think this game is a great game. However, there are flaws that I must state in the current version of the game.

Pro's:

The game is very community friendly. You don't have to worry about getting non-stop attacked or killed. Most servers don't allow random and no reason killing. Where as in games like DayZ, or Rust you have people who just constantly kill for no reason.

This game is very relaxing. Those nights you get off from work and don't feel like just running around and gunning people down in FPS games. This game is great as to where you can just sit, listen to the very relaxing and beautiful music, and build while maybe watching a movie or something.

Can do and build what you want, and how you want. If you want to take a week or so to build a huge underground fort, you can. If you want to build a stronghold, you can. Or perhaps a beach farm, you can. You can pretty much do what ever you want in this game, if you have the time and patience.

Great and beautiful graphics. They are just stunning and beautiful to sit and stare at. Very fleshed out as well.

-----------------------------------

Cons:

Optimization is not great. If you run it on medium or low, you can roughly get around 20-30 FPS with a mid tier PC. If you want to run anything above that, you'll need to have the most modern and updated gaming computer. Even then, there's no telling if you'll get anything above 30fps.

Worlds are just dead, and rely too much on player to player interaction. The servers are not dead, just the world feels really empty. There's hardly any wildlife, and the map is so big, you'll rarely come across other players, even on 64 player servers filled. The building feature even revolves way too much on player interaction, because how many items you need to build certain things, and how long they take to aquire them.

Obtaining weapons take a very long time. You can almost immediatly get tools, and a sling with rocks, however if you want to use a bow, crossbow or sword it, takes a whole town to wield them, because first you have to build a smithy, which requires all these other objects that require skills, and the skill like contruction take a very long time to level up if you're by yourself.

The requirement for a friend/s to play with you. If you want to get anywhere without taking a few weeks to build a small town, you need atleast a friend or two. The length it takes to collect items from things like tree's, rocks, ores, and even food is so long, and most items you get is only 1 every 15-20 seconds, which is not a lot seeming as how you need around 10 things you may or may not get from searching for a simple fence.

Some skills like fishing is very obsolete because of how they were implemented. I spent over 45 minutes trying to catch one fish, because somehow in 1,000BC fish are so rare. Then when you get a fish and cook it, your campfire somehow gets broken, and the fish only gives you about 20 hunger regen, when something like an apple which is pretty common and you collect around 23 in 5 seconds gives like 17-20 hunger regen.

Hunting is also pretty obsolete because of how hard/long it takes to get a bow and how little wildlife there is.


------------------------------------------------

Anyhow my total ranking is, 7.5/10. There's a lot of potential here, and I hope we get more patches before the september release.

reviewText:
I've played plenty of survival games in my time, and this is hands down my favorite.

The overall feel of a server's community entirely revolves around human nature. Some people want to be barbarians, some want to be bandits, a lot more just want to coexist. In the end, your experiences depend on which you choose.

Barbarians (people who run around naked screaming obscenities ad decapitating deer) tend to add a bit of comedic relief to the trying environment that is LiF, but may also come and burn your house down and steal your chickens.

Bandits come in two flavors. They either roleplay and hold you up much like a common highwayman, or run around in packs of 4+ and just kill some poor naked ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ under the illusion that they have gear worth taking.

Coexisting countrymen constantly care for each other like cousins. The core concept is to cooperate in a calculated campaign of carpentry, construction, calipers, and cooking. This competing collection of corroborative characters can, and commonly do, cause caustious- ok enough with the alliteration.

tl;dr If you aren't a bard or bandit you typicaly form a group and make friends through helping each other build a small settlement. If you are like me, you tend to do this with around 15 other people, the majority of which are on Teamspeak. The few times you get attacked either end in everyone dying or some lone wannabe bandit getting chased off by a dozen angry, heavily-armed and armoured peasants weilding the fruits of their labor as weapons of death.

To be fair, i have had my troubles wanting to play this game but this is for personal reasons. I can not handle stress due to a medical condition I have. This being said, you will stress a lot in this game. (Is that naked man on a horse really a bandit with his armour deequipped to lull us into a false sense of security, or is he some scrub fresh spawn that got lucky and found a horse already?) These are the questions that can get people killed, or get people killed. It is very rare for most people to trust one another on a server with known bandits and barbarians as they recruit more as the server grows. In the end though, this game is a delight to have in my steam library and I'm happy to have spent $40 on it.

Please read the comments to get a more updated look at my experience with the game as it develops.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very interesting. While yes it is one of those survival sandbox" games which has (until 4 days after this review) been in early access
date:
it is also one of the most original and expansive of those on offer.
The game itself has managed a wonderful feeling of immersion in its own world/lore. When you play it you can be quite content with the feeling of actually being in the world your character is surrounded by. I will now break this review down into a few sections:

Gameplay:

This game takes a long time. That is a key point
recommended: do not expect to have a massive medieval castle and town within 5 hours of playing the game. Large parts involve effectively grinding (!FLUX! - players will know) to find the resources you need to construct/create the buildings/items you want. However teamwork is amazingly useful because it reduces the time needed to perform many actions. Such that imagine 1 person takes 1 hour to perform an action
hoursPlayed:
2 people would then take less than half an hour to do the same action.

Also as this is a survival game you need to gather food to survive. This is relatively simple if you have found a few reliably good quality apple trees. You will also need to 'rest' your character occasionally if performing tough work such as terraforming or construction etc.

This leads me onto another important point regarding skill progression. The game is designed
voteText: as I've said previously and as you will hear through this review
helpfulPercent:
for teamplay. A limitation imposed by this is such that you cannot be an expert at everything! You have a limited number of skill points to distribute around the various skills (which unlock in a skill-tree type fashion). As you perform actions these skill points will be added to your skill in that action up to your limit (you can 're-spec' by downgrading your skills if needed). Because of this you will need a group to play with unless you set your game/server to have custom (default is 800 I think) levels of skill points.

Graphics:

This game has looked absolutely fine throughout its development but its looming DX11 release looks incredible from what we've seen thus far. Other than this I cannot comment much on this point other than it runs very well without many framerate dips etc. so seems quite optimised.

Music/Audio:

The sound quality is great with well recorded clips for all actions and a nice atmospheric background soundtrack
votesHelpful: although if playing for many hours at a time it can get a little repetitive.\n\nI'm not used to writing reviews (this is my first so I know I will have missed a lot) so please don't hate :P"

Early Access Review

I bought and played for a 2 hour test and found it very in depth and the community very friendly. It requires a lot of time however, and can be very grindy.

You start off with a small amount of food and some rag clothing. From there it is up to you to start developing your character how you want. You can prospect the ground for ore, get the bark off a tree, collect sticks, search for edible food on the ground, etc

However, actions take quite a bit o f time and do not always increase your skill.

Here's one example. When you search the ground for food the action takes some time and often turns out no results. Tha's because action success is based on random chance.  If your action is not succesful you don’t gain skill. If the actions is successful you do gain skill, but you don’t improve your chances of being successful in the future.

I posted on the fourm that I wonder why games like this are so mundane when they could easily take place in a much more imaginitive world, and within 5 min the Dev banned me with no warning.

Here's the post that got me banned: https://sites.google.com/site/thebannedpost/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One word.  AWESOME.  This game is being designed to be effectively limitless in possibilities, realistic ones at that, and the current limits, considering it is still early access, are constantly being expanded.  Great appearance helps as well.  PvP is fun.

The one note that I will make is that this game is not for the weak of heart.  To be successful takes a LOT of time and effort as well as a group of friends.  It is incredibly difficult to setup a successful community with a cooperative group of 10 people, and even more difficult to do on your own, though it can be done.  This isn't the result of a game flaw, this is how the game is intended to be.  Forest disappears very quickly once you start constructing even small buildings, as the materials gained from harvesting things like trees is pretty realistic.  Unlike other games, new trees don't just sprout up in their place, you need to plant more.  Planting is easy, but even with ideal weather conditions it takes real life days (up to a week I think) for the trees to mature into a useful, harvestable material.  This is just one example.  This game is difficult, and it is meant to be.  One HUGE advantage from this is that there are far fewer ♥♥♥ hats that just run around abusing people for the sake of doing so, and most of the time if someone does that they are banned.  The rationale is that if you want your character to be a bandit and steal from others, that is fine.  But if you're just going to grief people, that drives players off, resulting in smaller/fewer groups building on a server which ends up in server death.  The requirement of cooperation really encourages players to respect one another.  Players are also less likely to risk losing things, such as weapons, attacking other people unless there is a good reason, as replacing them takes a significant amount of time, work, and help from other people.

If you truly enjoy survival this game is for you.  You can always setup a local game and adjust the difficulty to be easy to do on your own, but most servers do NOT do that.

Definitely a great game with a great future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Developer's financing shenanigans aside, LiF:YO isn't all that bad by itself.
The game world is somewhat nice and immersive and there is a rather large range of occupations to be had.
In-game progression is however really REALLY slow (though I find it make achieving one's goal all the more rewarding).
While social interactions are mandatory to advance, (unless you have multiple accounts) I found I could get fairly high in the progression tree by myself.

Where the game ultimately fail for me is in the painfully slow rate of development progress or I should say lack off combined with the high price they ask for it.

Combat system which would give an incentive to attack/defend resources is mostly broken, decay system has not really been addressed properly, UI is terrible, there is no natural way (short of an admin intervention) to fill trenches and holes dug by players and as of yet, no officials servers. Which mean all that unless the server is yours, there's no guarantee your hard work will still be there tomorrow or the day after.

With hindsight, I feel my time and money would have been better spent somewhere else.

Early Access Review

This game takes a lot of patience. Don't buy it if you aren't prepared to put time and effort into learning the complex crafting and combat system. The wiki does a fairly good job of helping you to understand the game more. All in all, I have spent 1000 hours of my life playing this game. I love the free build system, love the Guild Claims and thankful I can actaually play a female character now instead of only being able to play Baldy.

This game can be confusing as hell when you first start, and it takes a little while to get used to the grind. Definitely a game to play with a guild rather than alone if you want to get anywhere with it. Love the communities that grow on the servers. Would recommend this game to anyone that doesn't mind a couple of annoying bugs and wants to have fun working things out and muck around with mates.
