reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by saying that for more than 10 years, I've been waiting for a sandbox that would rival Ultima Online. Nothing could ever quite match up.

I seriously think this might be the one. And that's a big statement for me. *fans self* I'm getting a little emotional here.

What struck me about this game is that it is a challenge. I appreciate that in order to get somewhere in this game - to accomplish anything - you must really pay attention. You won't find random epic loot in chests. You won't get neat armor from killing a bear. Bears don't wear armor. It just makes sense.

I also really love that you can spend your time doing whatever it is that floats your boat. You don't HAVE to do anything to have a fulfilling game. It's a true sandbox.

Right now, I'm playing on a fairly small server. There are usually 3 - 5 people playing at a time. But already, there is community. I can imagine that it will only improve once there are more players coming in. Because there are SO many skills, and so many jobs to do, trading and building alliances actually has meaning.

Obviously because it is in alpha, there are some bugs and improvements to be made. I'm confident that they'll be coming in time.

There are some things that seem overly difficult, although it may vary from server to server. For example, on my particular server, apples never grow back. We must plant and replant. Food is quite difficult to come by. Foraging for edible plants almost never finds anything.  A disproportionate amount of time is spent trying to find it, and hunger levels grow quite rapidly. I spend alot of time catching my breath, and waiting to be able to play again. After all that mining and lumberjacking, I would have thought my character would be fit enough to run for 20 seconds! :P

Overall though, I really highly recommend this game. After just a few hours, I was hooked. There is a steep learning curve, but there are many resources online that will answer your questions.I'm very optimistic about this game's future, and I will definitely be spending a very large chunk of my time playing it. Goodbye, social life! :D

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI got in the game, didn't know how to move.  Imagine that I hit Escape and see that pressing Tab turns off my cursor. DUH! Now I can move.  Now what? Well pressing keys randomly, theres TONS.  A skill tree, a backpack, a paperdoll for my equipment.  A stat List, all lockable and raisable/lowerable.  You need to start at the left and work your way right to do stuff in the skill tree.  Before long I chop down trees, stack them in piles.  I dig a copper and an iron mine, build a forge.  Then a Kiln.  Before long I have a Blacksmithy and Anvil.  WHOO Metal weapons and armour!  Woman seen me play, ohh noes! Now she's farming! Growing crops / tending the stables.  And Sir Noc is Born, riding his warhorse, armour and weapons.  Who dares trespass in MY village I worked so hard for.  Heres some apples pesant, now beat it!

reviewText:
WARNING!!!! This is not a game for lazy people xD
First of all! The bad reviews of this game are for two reasons: 1-on alpha the game had some bugs, low fps and low graphics; 2- (most of that bad reviews) - people who dont like games that you have to work on it to get something.

There are two types of games: games like CSGO,Battlefield,COD,etc  (games where you start with all of your weapons and you just have to play it) and games like this one ( games where you have to work hard to have your stuff).

This game is for the people who loves medieval era, roleplaying, pvp, and work like maniac! Dont get me wrong this game is amazing and with a lot of potencial, but for you to have sucess you have to have a lot of time invested in this game and playing with your friend help a lot too.

So what you need to know. . . When you creat a character, you can choose what you want it to be (stats, professions, looks), when you log in to the game you dont have any tools just cloth and some food but you can get tools from the nature arround you and then starting to craft and raise up your stats and professions.

Crafting system: very complete i must say, you have a lot of things that you can create but you need to have the skill to do it.

Combat system: is kind of diferent that you should expect, it takes a little of pratice but for this game it works pretty fine. When you are try to do some damage every things counts, lenght of your weapon, quality and combos that you use.

Pros of the game: really hardcore miedeval simulator, roleplay, community, crafting and combat system, graphics are most better then the alpha version.

Cons of the game: Optimization, the devs are still working on this subject. If you want to run this game on ultra... well you can dream about it xD You need a really good graphics card for that, but in medium that what i use and i have a gtx760 i run the game at 130 fps +/- depend on the server, so its getting better.

I advice you to see some youtube videos, tutorials, streams and studd, if like what you saw, buy this game, its a really good game. Is that type of game that i was looking for so many years.

Tip: 1- If you can wait for some sales and buy this game always save some money;
2- Buy the game before MMO is realease, because when it realese the game porbably will be more expensive and if you have bought this game before mmo realease you got one character slot for free on mmo.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my opinion, very very good.....but follows the pros and cons. after that see my comments in general:

PROS

- Good graphics, good fps even with a reasonable not top of the edge machine like mine
- Almost no bugs for me!
- Free world to do whatever u want.....build, train yourself, kill etc
- Not hard to learn (lots of stuff in wiki etc and easy game mechanics)
- Good ppl base
- Lots of skills.....learn as you go and perform....but ppl abuse the chance of getting that easily cause the company allows it (see below).
- Can build tons of stuff and they do have a purpose (like protecting your stuff, getting better
weapons, doing better gear for pvp) etc
- Amazing easy, crafting that has a purpose (I guess I said that)


CONS

- Servers created by players. For me this is bad! Specially when the devs give them the right to change a lot.
The servers colapse a lot couse its too much or dont load......Alpha or not, its anoying
- You can create a server with 100 multiplier on skill gain....What? Maybe de devs didint wanna have the label
of grinders in their game, but a sandbox should have some.... You shouldnt max out your forestry skill in 1 hour.
I tried to create the server myself...no luck........hours on end waiting....but it might be the day or the flux of ppls.
BTW I choose the default which is 1 multiplier for skill gain and thats it.....No one would join me but I dont care. Games like this shold be a process, specially in community......It takes time and effort.....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Game is great! I have over 400 hours for a reason and likely to put on a lot more.

Things to remember: its early access and not the finished game, you play on player owned servers currently and all have their own sets of guidlines and rules, also different rates and maximum skill leveling abilities. The game is very craft centric so expect some aspects to be a long grind.

So far the game is very craft centric. You can blacksmith, build homes and castles, farm, tame animals, mine and log, if you can think up a craft in a fuedal era more then likely you can do it in game. To do this you need to collect resources or work out a deal to have others collect them for you. All of this and every aspect takes time. You will spend a lot of time building up to the point you envision your character to be. This is very grindy and definetely not for everyone. If the thought of spending a day or so moving dirt to level off an area to build your cabin makes you ill then you should move along. I never thought I would enjoy it as much as I do. I some how find the game very relaxing.

I am not sure how I feel about combat. I havent done much PvP and have not leveled up those skills significantly. It however feels a little floaty to me at the moment. It however has a more urgent feel to it then other games, as death or unconsiousness bring permanent penalties, whether its just loss of property or loss of skill and attributes, you wont want to make defeat a hobby. I know seige warfare is coming if not already out and that sounds very fun.

Claiming property is relatively new. It protects your land from intruders by making it so that tresspasers can be punished without any of the negative affects associated with murdering neighbours occur to the land owner. Also gives some penalties to the tresspasser. Its a nice touch.

The graphics are beautiful, yet not otimized. I expect further improvement with that as it gets closer to a release. Some animations and sounds still require work, however the game still does an excellent job at being immersive and mostly natural.

All in All this games is very good and definetly deserves a positive rating.
voteText: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First of all lets clear a few things here. One of them would be that this game is not everyones cup of tea, with that said this review will be for those that actualy like these kinds of games and don't mind the grindy and hard aspect of it.

The game is mostly relying on teamwork.
It doesn't mean you cant play it alone, you can and its loads of fun but to a point.
That point being that the game is designed in such a way that makes you feel like you are a part of a medieval town or village or even a big castle. You can only feel that if you have people with you playing.
Another design of the game is to seperate the work load of those pve jobs from geting food to just about anything.
The PvE aspect if you will, as in roleplaying and village developement to farming/hunting, making armor, tools or anything a medieval village needs is very imersive and very versitile and complex.
There are alot of videos and guides out there to help people with the learning curve since its a bit steep.
PvP aspect is very harsh at first glance, BUT its actualy very fun and very fair if you know what you are doing and have allys. The combat system in the game is somewhat similar to some games but not the same.
There are siedges that work quite well and all that.
One problem with the game atm is that you can somewhat leave a few things like choped logs or boxes or other movable things bit floating in the air. With that said, some abuse it to get over walls or other things, BUT still with a decent guild you wont fear any invasion specialy those abusers" since they are allways few in numbers.
The community is different from  server to server
date: but there are a few guilds out there including Vanir's Krigsmen wich im from and some other allys of ours that have been playing the game since the early alpha and are still strong. So my opinion is don't let those bad servers or bad people bring you down keep searching for a group you will fit in."

This game needs a warning. It is mostly grind. You will grind to get resources, you will grind to move resources and you will grind to build. Pretty much most of your time will be grinding. If you don't play this game with other people, then you probably will be burnt out.

I would say that if you enjoy Minecraft and working with other people, then you'll most likely enjoy this game as well. The sense of accomplishment from building a castle or large keep is pretty great. If you say, I did this." Then people will realize how awesome you are

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bugginess/state of the game:

I've spend a few hours on the game. And it's occasionally buggy and not well optimised. But hey, they're not hiding the fact it's not finished. It's playable, that's the most important thing.

If you can't handle a crash once in awhile, don't buy it.
I haven't had much issues, but some friends have had it worse than me.

Gameplay:

I personally love it. But if you're an impatient man, do not buy this game. Doing things takes time.
In most survival games you have a full fledged base in maybe a week or even less.

Here 1 weeks worth is having a small house and furnace (if you play alone) or a village with wooden palisades (if playing in group).

Now this game is not meant to be played solo. Many server have the recommended level cap.
This effectively limits you when you play alone, as you can't have all stats maxed. You can do everything decently, but not perfectly.
There are server where the cap's been increased, so you could technically be a one man powerhouse.
But more often than not, expect there to be roles. Towns tend to have a dedicated blacksmith, carpenter, tanner, etc...

This game takes time, especially being a bloody herbalist..... there's just so many freaking herbs.


If you don't have patience, don't buy it.
If you like a community and working in group building up a medieval society, go ahead. Expect to shovel a lot of dirt leveling out land though.
Watch out for bandits aswell. People still love free goodies.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game with lots of promise. It takes a while to build things and level up which is great for longevity. My only problem with this game is the MMO aspect. Everyone on here bangs on about how great it will be when there are thousands of players running around. Umm ... great ... so all my hard work will be undone in the style of Rust. Can't wait. I've heard there will be more things to do if you want to play solo, but I'll see how and if that pans out. I can't not recommend this game - it doesn't have dragons or spells which is refreshing. Don't get me wrong I play solo which is still great as I love all things medieval. Only issue is they've made a fantastic game but without singleplayer, which seems to be the norm these days. I'm sure it's great with a team of you but not everyone wants that. I just wish there were more games like this but in singleplayer. But this is the best so buy it and go solo - and hope more NPCish aspects get added. The rendering on the buildings look wonderful and the cities people have built look amazing. I'd quite happily spend days or weeks or months building it all on my own - just wish there were a few (just a few) NPCs to say hello" to. At least there are animals to kill I guess."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played 1,017.9 hours of this Alpha game i am still not disappointed . even with all the hickups and problems i have experienced along the way. I am pleased. Support has been quick, regular patches - implementations of game material and fixes.
it should be noted for new players there is 1 modification to a steam file that will significantly improve your game experiences.
. In my experiences Since purchase i have played across many servers . Raided , constructed , terraformed, farmed, hunted alongside many players who have had alot, if not the same playability concerns . though once you work a few bugs out. this game is awesome in its open ended gameplay. Which encourages players to work together. Ive found most of the ♥♥♥♥♥ing and whining to come from players with high expectations who are expecting a polished out of the box RTR version, or players who are generally not up to a hard grind type game to achieve anything and just want to troll around killing and not working towards anything.
Of the playability problems this game has a few, and most of those problems vary from player to player .  most can be sorted with a little bit of fiddling with settings and such. What else can you expect of an alpha.. well worth the $40 i spent. but be prepared to put in some hours to enjoy this game to its full potential.. you wont be running around decked out to the max overnight . or even in a week for that matter . you need to play the game for what it is to enjoy.
ive since started a server of my own and we are setting up community's and infastructure etc . planned events on a scale we havent been able to achieve before .. currently the only server that isnt dead from what i gather from feedback from players. goodluck i hope you purchase and would like to see you in game . if you are from australia .. all the best

reviewText:
(eng) (рус)

This is basically your collective farm simulator, an online 'Crazy Farmer' time management game enriched with something like 'Mount&Blade'/'War of The Roses' fighting system. It's got nice interface, comprehensive tutorial and decent engine, and as an old 'M&B' fan I felt myself almost at home here right away.. until I tried game hunting. Man, all the animations are so clunky it's painful to see in 2016! I've been playing 'M&B' since almost 10 years ago (alfa) and now I don't see any substantial progress in that respect. Stupid horses and then that elk.. I feel pity for them. Ok, I'll take a deep breath and tell you how it was.

The tutorial said I should select a patch of soil and choose 'search for peaceful animal tracks'. There was nothing. Being a city dweller I still surmised to look at a nearby lake's shore. I found tracks of cloven hoof, they appeared at the ground as highlighted texture spots leading to the forest. I followed that curved line and it seemed funny how it passed right through some large trees, that's where I started to feel suspitious about the software. After a while I spotted a couple of horses.. which should be odd-toed. Eh, who needs that foolish botany anyway? I closed on them, they just lied down before me. I thought it will be an easy task, maybe a part of tutorial.

My axe hit the nearest one in the head for no visible effect, it jumped up and ran away, but not far. I started chasing it to the lake, then to the mountain, it went through trees not noticing them and ploughed into uneven ground. On our way we also spooked an elk and some geese. I switched to chasing the elk. I managed to make a slingshot while it waited for me nearby. The animals also lacked animations, as well as the brains, they seemed to follow just one algorythm - kept some distance. After I had hit the mammal for the 20th time with a stone it turned on me and horned me till I fell unconscious.. without any animation.

The game is not finished, it's totally unpolished, crude as a stone axe, and it's technological basis already feels outdated! All in all, if you are very patient I strongly advise you to go build yourself a real house in the woods instead of playing this. For others there are much more cheerful middle-age lifestyle simulators on the market.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText: Well, I enjoyed playing before the last patch. Not so much after. I know we are still considered testers...even though we had to pay for that priviledge, but the decision making process here is poor. I'm glad you think you fixed mining, but as we are still TESTERS leave the IP piles in so we can test. We can mine and use IP to get bigger projects done for TESTING. Unless you start paying ME, I'm not hauling the amount of rock required to build some of the end game structures. I'm sure the same could be said for alot of people. The result...buildings aren't getting built, your game isn't getting vetted like it should be. The amount of problems I've encountered and have seen others encounter on an array of servers leads me to wonder how much pretesting was done prior to this release. The sheer volume of reports, conflicts, bugs, and errors is staggering. At this point in time I think another 6 months in dev wouldn't have been enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are a fan of Wurm Online or perhaps have played Wurm Online and wished there were gameplay improvements that will very likely never come, this is a game to look into.

Life is Feudal: Your Own is a title which is temporary, a proving ground if you will for the MMO component which is coming supposedly in October. At 3x3 KM squared it is not a large game world right now however the developers have stated a significantly larger world will exist for the MMO in October.

There are of course glitches and bugs as well as UI issues just as in Wurm Online as the games bare many similarities but in my opinion the game is already in a better state than Wurm Online is to this day and contains far less of the major issues that I have with Wurm Online. I can recommend this game to anyone who has played Wurm Online or enjoys games in that vein. It certainly does NOT deserve the negative reviews it has and if anything it simply has a learning curve that seems to turn some people away.

reviewText:
Dont Waste your money - Devs dropped the ball big time on what could have been an amazing game

The promise of sandbox pvp has been replaced with  safezones and carebear tears-

the actual build and engine are horrible and clunky - most servers grind to a halt after a week or so of light terraforming and building - 1/2 hour load times on restart are normal on 1 week old servers - lots of bugs and glitches but thats normal for an alpha build

crafting and building system had a lot of promise

pvp is horrible - not really sure what direction devs are taking but those whoe know more about melee pvp than me have said the game will not be releasing with a good pvp system in place

devs like to delete any negative threads on the steam forums and the official forums so you won't get any real info at either of those places.


underhanded behaviour of the highest order

final conclusion from him   - DONT BUY THIS GAME

17 Nov - release day

Game has been released in an unfinished state as we all expected it would be - - End product has been rushed in an attempt to squeeze last drop of cash out of this dead horse- to be honest i think this company's behaviour is verging on the criminal and wish Valve would not give these kind of shady developers store space

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to admit that I like the game, sure it's a steep learning curve and is confusing at first but it actually gets you thinking and planning what your next move might be, I like others have seen the reviews left by people who haven't even stuck around ingame for a hour before coming on here and whinning about how the controls are broken, can't do this, can't do that etc etc etc
How about using your brain and explore, try new things learn before leaving a stupid untrue review of a game that could very well become great....button mashing sad acts.

Yes so as some of the other reviews have stated there is a lot that goes into the game itself and it probably would be best to play with a few friends if you want to get things done quicker since there is a lot of reasource gathering, skill developing, planning and building involved to progress from standing on the beach in your pants to having your own house or castle!
Sure writting a review that lays it all out for you praising it as a great game would be helpful but that's just my opinion....yours might be different.

All I can say is try it yourself and form your own opinion you never know you might actually like it, hell the first time I played it I didn't have a clue so ran about the beach for a while, eventually managed to build a fire, went for a swim and drowned! Would build a fire and drown again.

So play it, like it or don't like it just give it a few hours game time before coming on here and whinning like a total clown please.

Cheers

reviewText:
I haven't played in awhile after dropping in a little under 150 hours and most of that was spent on a private server I set up for the BF and I when I first downloaded it.

I really liked it at first, but I found the lack of NPCs or at least things to fight other than wolves a bit boring. I love the building aspects of it and the whole farming/cooking/hunting/fishing bits (which is what I played in game) but even when playing with others for a short while, I found the Role Play to be kind of non-existent, as if people thought it was silly to actually play the characters they created.

I also didn't like how, get the wrong mod, and all of your progress could be wiped the moment THEY had a screw up but I guess that could happen in any game such as this.

I'm currently getting hip to Wurm Unlimited, which I think is where LiF got a lot of its inspiration from and I find it to be a bit more enjoyable as of now. Sure the graphics aren't as pretty but there's much more to do, including getting down on an Adventure server so you're not so dependent on PCs to provide content.

I'll probably end up playing LiF again though. Like I said, it does have its fun attached to it and I'm sure if I found the right server with the right players I'd truly enjoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of the roleplay aspects. Sometimes I wonder if its just difficult for some PC gamers to switch to a table top" mentality. But all of this babbling is just my opinion."

reviewText:
This game is quite enjoyable,
It can be irritating at times and a little hard to understand,
but, I'm starting to get the hang of it now!

DO NOT expect this game to get going right off the bat. It will take time.

We set up a little camp in the valley, only to realize that we were miles away from the materials we needed.
It had taken us about 2 hours to get set up, and really all we have is a bed roll, furnace, and some tools.
So I ended up being the one to have to travel to go get the materials for everything.

Nonetheless, I like it.
It's very pretty, and the atmosphere is on point.

8.5/10

reviewText: This game is a medieval life simulator, not so much a true survival" game. It does indeed have survival elements but the focal point of the game is PVP and a very in depth and lucrative crafting system. While you may wonder why the game has some mixed reviews
date: it's mostly because it is a very hardcore game that fits with only certain personalities. Also a lot of the negative reviews were from a while ago when the game was riddled with bugs and people were upset. That's changed a lot and is now a mostly polished experience.\n\nSolo play can make the game difficult
recommended:
and jumping into the world with no friends or unable to find people can make you feel extremely overwhelmed. Most servers have a very awesome RP community with it and if you find one with good rule sets you have ample opportunity to grow your character into something special. Having a group though even if just a few people is a MUST. I cannot stress enough solo play is highly discouraged.

You want to focus on a certain few professions to specialize in as you can be a "jack of all trades" but to get the maximum reward you want to specialize.

PVE content is sparse besides game animals there isn't anything else other than starvation that can be PVE
hoursPlayed: so if you're looking for ONLY PVE this IS NOT the game for you. Understand that PVP drives the game
voteText: but crafting is really the most important and time consuming aspect.\n\nAs I said before it's more of a simulation
helpfulPercent: giving you the ability to immerse yourself in that middle age time period and reap in rewards. Crafting is top notch and is extremely gratifying just doing something as simple as terraforming to plant some trees or dig a tunnel system to mine some ore.\n\nIt isn't for everyone
votesHelpful: it is a game that requires patience
votesTotal: time for your effort to reward you but once you get into the world you will be hooked. I've loved every minute and the RP I've had is just so fantastic. Once this game turns into the MMO it will be even better.\n\nThe game is not without bugs
votesFunny: however none are game breaking
commentsCount: the inventory system isn't very friendly and the UI can take some getting used to but there are tutorials and a very good wiki to assist you throughout.\n\nWhile the price tag on this game is a bit high
column16:
you can justify it by the fact you will get a game that isn't like all the other survival games out there that end up being a waste of money and get abandoned.

Combat is physics based and if you've played Chivalry it's very similar to that so it should be familiar..

I rate LiF:YO a solid 7.5/10. If you love crafting

column19: PVP and medieval times this is a must have to your steam library."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is Feudal is the best medieval sandbox game ever.

You can build your own little hut, a big house, a giant castle, it all depends on what is your motivation level and how many friends you got.

You literally start with nothing, you got to find everything on your own from trees, rock soil, grass and animals. There is a hunger system that is not too exigent, if you eat good food you'll be statisfied for a while.

You can craft TONS of different types of armor/tools/weapons, deblocking the skills to craft and use them with practice and work.

The learning curve is steep, you'll have to spend a few hours to understand how to do relatively complex things. Harvesting/collecting materials can be a little bit grindy at some points, especially when you want to build a huge house or big castle walls but it's a guaranteed fun time.

As of now, the game is not finished, it's in early access so there's a lot more that the devs are planning to add but still, it got a lot of content for an unfinished" game.

You can be an archer
hoursPlayed: a bandit or claim yourself as the king of the land

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tried this game when it first came to steam. This is a rather my experience than a Review.

So. You came here to build a house? Okay lets start by learning the TERRAFORMING skill. Thats needed in order to become a CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS PREPERATOR.... (whatever the hell that is). When achieved a sufficient level (60 in most cases), by digging up ground for HOURS,  you begin preparing  construction materials, needed for your later home. Again, you do this FOREVER, till you achieved rank 60 in that skill. When you made it that for it allows you to learn the construction skill.... With lvl 30 in that you made it. after 8 hours of boring skill lvling, you think you achieved a point of mastery where you can finaly build a home, no, HOMES for many! But no. Lvl 30 in construction allows you to build WOODEN objects only. Well... okay. Lets start cutting down some trees you say? NO. FIRST LEARN FORRESTING (planting trees, examining trees, and getting branches from them), WHICH IS NEEDED FOR LOGGING. So, note that youve spent about 10 hours of gameplay just for achieving the necessary skills to build a house on that 1 particular server. Okay finally you can start cutting down those stupid trees you examined 50 times each. Well, some of them. THe hard wood trees are to tough for you with your logging lvl 30. After you cut down your first tree and wondered Eh what the heck do I do with that log now." You realize that you have to learn ANOTHER SKILL
date: to make something out of logs. Yea Logging lvled to 60

reviewText:
Overall: great game!
It will keep you entertained for hours. If you are a right player type for this game you may spend even hundreds or thousands of hours.
Yes it is a niche game - really hardcore one, meant for elite groups of dedicated players.
Some will not like it for been to in-depth and too grindy at a times, but this is what it takes to feel the significance of your achievement. You invest time and feel yourself proud when something is finished. This make you don’t want to lose what you achieved, because usually it will take far more than a day to restore. This together with so called “alignment system” makes players behave themselves in-game and in general  community is far better than in other sandboxes.
Some say there are bugs and visual glitches... well they were, but devs are quite fast - 2 patches in a first 2 days after release and they were fixed, at least for me. Performancewise not that bad actually. Taking that I’m playing on rather old gtx 680 on PC and not so fast 850m on laptop - avarage of 30 FPS on medium to high settings make me feel comfortable.
And the last but not least - this is not for a singleplayer mode. It is possible to start a server for yourself and tune its settings to play with decent comfort, but it is absolutely no fun at all. The point of this game is communication between people, friends or foes does not matter it will be fun in both ways!

So I highly recommend this game. Get some friends and start your feudal life!

reviewText: I love how much like WURM Online this game is. However, there really needs to be more PvE elements added to the game. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know it's in Alpha stage but this game isn't ready to be released yet not even in alpha. I wish I wouldn't have spent the 40 bucks on this. If you are looking for survivial games they're much better games in dev for almost half the price. I think in a few months this game will be absolutely amazing but for now save it.

-Connecting to a server is problematic and if you can't connect to a host you have to completely exit the game.
-You need expert computer skill to start your own server so creating a private server for you and your friends is no easy task. You can't go to gameservers.com and easily get a server hosted either. One company does server hosting but you don't get the full game experience with your own server.
-The controlls are really clunky.
-There is hardly any wildlife or things that move it's extremely lonely.
-It's like Dayz without zombies and you can craft but you need friends to help you but finding friends is a hastle.

reviewText: This game has real potential, so long as the developers keep actively working on it. It says release, but it's more of a beta, as planned features are yet to come and some in-game features are still a bit buggy. It's also yet to be optimized and suffers from crashes and memory leaks. Definitely not a game for everyone, as the learning curve is steep without joining an established guild and the chances of surviving alone are slim. Also has a lengthy skill leveling system that will make some impatient players unhappy.\n\nBefore you buy, I highly recommend looking this up on YouTube and getting an idea of what you're getting into. It's an excellent game if one can overlook the current issues - which the devs are actively working on. But, with all its cons, the medieval life you will lead in LiF:YO is extremely satisying, especially when you build your first house or complete the walls around your lands.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Summary: While this game is pretending to be everything it fails to become anything in the foreseeable future.


Yes, the game has absolutely no future except being an early access title until its distant demise. Yes, it will be early access for very long time. Take a couple of years.

It is ridiculous how with such large gameplay scope developers fail to design even basic features and mechanics. It's not even interesting to study the design of the game as it is usual with other early access games.

There are several very obvious evidences that the game is designed very poorly. What is bad about design flaws? Design flaw is much worse than even a hudred bugs. You just can't fix it without destroying some part of the game. And one design decision is always connected to the others. Redesign is a chain reaction that involves most part of the game to be reconsidered and recoded.

As it is usual happens with independent developers they pay very little attention to a game design. They jump to start coding and modelling. Well it's good if you're designing another simple puzzle or arcade game - they tend to have very short development cycles. On the other hand - games with such gameplay scope as LiF have very long development cycle - about a year. It means time needed to code a tech demo after design revision.

This development cycle we have now is already wasted. Next development cycle will be wasted too. Not just because developers are bad or something. But because the game system will be so complex that there will be unexpected results.

To prove my point, here's some design flaws.

1. Terraforming.
Terraforming system is purely artificial and is a subject to heavy changes in the future. Right now terraforming consists of too artificially combined systems: landscape terraforming and tunneling. It is very easy to see that tunneling artificially blocks landscape terraforming in its vicinity. That's just because developers have no idea how these two systems should interact.
Terraforming lies in the basis of the game so any changes to that system will result in a redesign of the whole game.
There are so many questions that needs to be addressed here. Will there be a cave-ins? Can you build a house inside a mine? Maybe a farm? Do I need light inside? What if I will dig upward to the surface?

2. Skills.
Right now there are too many skills in the game with very little logic behind them.
Let's say you want to be a hunter. Track animals and kill them to get hides and meat. Not so fast. It seems you have to learn how to plow ground first and grow crops. And only then you will be able to dry a deer's hide. That logic.
Same problem with terraforming, prospecting and mining skills.
There is no obvious way to choose some simple role. Skills are divided and interconnected in some weird and unexpected way. Obviously skill system will be revised very soon. It's just awful.

3. Skill cap.
Well, I bet developers are very proud they have invented" a such an original way to milk LiF MMO players for money. Of course you will have to buy character slots. Why else this skill cap is even implemented? You won't be able to create anything in the game without 3-4 different characters involved. That's the only reason.

The worst of design flaws are those which was made to make us spend money. Because you can't fix them and they ruin the game the most.

4. Hunger.
It is the best example of a system that haven't even been thought about. It's a typical placeholder. And yet it's the most important system. It is one of the reasons to make players settle in some place. Some place where they have created a food production chain. If you won't be able to make them settle - they will be roaming around freely to kill and destroy. Because it's the natural pastime of human beings.
Right now you don't have to hunt
date: fish or grow crops. You only need to make weapons and armor to kill someone.\n\nWell
recommended:
I'll just name few more problematic mechanics which have to be designed yet.

5. Quality migration.
6. Private property.
7. Claiming lands.
8. Criminal acts.
9. Water travel.
10. Howling-transporting goods.
11. Deconstruction.
12. Siege.
13. Off-line characters.
14. Tracking down criminals.
15. Trading.

... and much much more.

It's sad to say that developers doesn't even bothered to study some references. Like Haven & Hearth
hoursPlayed: for example. It's obvious they have played it. Yet they haven't analyzed it's design decisions and flaws. And they already trying to invent something "new". While they only will end up reinventing the weel.\n\nEdit: Fixed mistake about skinning a deer. It was about drying hides

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is still alpha in every sense of the word, exploits and glitches are found and used by some players, yes this is annoying. Game lags and crashes at times yes this does make me rage, but only cause I enjoy this game greatly.

I have said the bad above now on to the good, the game is designed to create a community, a fraction, a guild not a stand alone warrior. You will need other people to rely on to make you tools while you tend the land or have you back while being raided. Had good laugh with my clan The Mountain Men as we marched in full plate armour around the island demanding tribute or defending trade allies.

People have made some great villages and towns, fortified and locked up tight with archers posted on the walls, you start to get concerned for you trade goods as you approch, even more concerned as you walk away after the deal is done.

What is annoying is a lot of negative comments are done by people with low hours of game time, I was still learning at 100hrs. People complaining its only to fund/test the MMO, its the same game/code essentially, so kinda but not  the reasons they say.

Is it worth the $40? for me yes, very much and I am looking forward to the MMO.
If you are a little worried bout the alpha issue, wait easy as that.

Thanks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After the few months I've owned this game, I feel the need to write a review for it. So here goes..

Life Is Feudal definitel has potential, and I have very much enjoyed it for upwards of 90% of my time playing. The other 10% I was getting mugged by a boar, arguing with in-server badmins, or moving dirt.. Otherwise, it's amazing. The realism is unrivaled by any other game I've played (except maybe Star Citizen. We'll see how that turns out). There is a very tight learning curve when you finally learn how to smack a tree with the rock you tied to a stick.

With friends, it get's interesting as you argue over who will be the miner, who's gonna be the lumberjack, and who's gonna be the lazy chef who sits around until someone builds a fire. Nevertheless, whatever job you get stuck with, there's always going to be at least one small part of your job that you love, whether it be playing Human Bowling with logs, digging pits in the middle of camp, or bringing a ♥♥♥♥♥♥-off boar through a group of people.

Without friends, you will make new ones so long as you have a mic. Typing in this sort of game has always been a hassle for me... Actually, ANY game for that matter... Either way, it gets interesting when you have no idea who the other person is, and with that disconnect you actually start believing they are their character, which only helps the immersion.

As far as actual gamplay goes, it's really quite relaxing. There's no real rush to get a mountain of materials, so as long as you remember where your camp is, it's nice to just take a walk through the forest and have a look of your surrroundings. Anyone playing this game for long enough realizes it's anything BUT a good-looking Minecraft. You just have to take your time and learn" how to do things. Personally
date: I've never gotten further than a hut for me and each of my four buddies
recommended: but give it enough time and it becomes feasable to build a decent fort..\n\nLong story short
hoursPlayed: I have nothing that I truly love or hate about the game.. It's all more just put together in such a way that I can't help but feel relaxed. The music is nice and fits the mood of the game really well (it's basically like the old-timey ambience that Skyrim or Lord Of The Rings has). The graphics aren't perfect
voteText: but for open world

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do I recomend this game? Yes.
Do I recommend buying it? Not with a price tag of anything over $20.
Quick Thoughts:
-Building is satisfying
-Community and team work is a must
-You can solo, but you will suck... and you will die (make your own server for solo)
-Combat is unpolished
-Level of detail in materials needed for building is awesome
-Too many materials needed for building with out a few people working together
-Skill cap works if you have people to play with (without friends) find a server with a higher skill cap

This game is rewarding, challenging but grindy as the @%#$. To be honest though, it really works here.
There is a ton of buildings to build and it would be a shame if you could simply make them right off the bat. This game takes time, and patience and when you finally build your first home... it feels great. Although one might argue that it takes to long, that one should also understand that this game is a prequal to an MMO. So the grind is required.

If you don't like grinds, then simply make your own server with the click of a button and alter the skill cap and skill gain as well as plant growth rate, or animal feeding rate, ect. Now... about that skill cap. I personally love the idea of a person needing to specialize in something. The problem? If you pick the wrong class tree to go down... you waisted a lot of time, so go online and look up a tutorial, because none exists on game. However, as I like descovering things as I go, I ask around a lot and for the most part it's a good community.

Now, about that combat! I am garbage at PvP so it always kinda sucks when someone raids my town (without walls) every day at the same time. And sure, while it may annoy me a little, i must say it adds a sense of realism to the world. The times back then sucked without or even with walls. Raiders bring it all together though and make the world feel alive. While I trade with one town, another is pumping out ♥♥♥ hats to attack me on sight. However, the combat itself kinda feels... like trash and quite unpolished. But then again, keep in mind I am not one for PvP so it could be that I suck. I guess there is only one way to find out.

Gathering is tedious and terrible but honestly very very important. You need it to make everything. I am not just talking about gathering sticks and stones... I am talking about gathering ore (which could take forever - This is not minecraft - move along) Or gathering 5 out of the (what seems like) 50 types of plants out there so you can make one item that is needed in ALL bigger buildings... Get an herbalist people... you need them... and they are playing the worst this game has to offer so you can makes walls and houses, and maybe one day even castles.

All in all this is an interesting game that is okay. Not great but certainly not bad. I would simply recomend getting this with a group of friends. But not so much if you are a solo player.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very deep crafting. Has a good economy of players required to build a cities/towns. Combat could use some love (which the developers have confirmed is one of their first orders of business). The graphics look pretty damn good and performance is good as well (Lower detail on trees or else it'll be a slide show). With sped up skill-gains, it allows players to experiment and try every profession relatively quickly. Anything from tracking animals and setting traps to keeping the fire of a forge high tempature for smelting.

Two of my favorite mechanics: When you hit track animal, actual footprints show up in the grass and you can follow them to find your prey. When you search for herbs, herbs will appear in the vegetation around you and you must spot and gather them manually.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a pick up and play sandbox game where you will have swords,spears,bows and arrows and armor in the first 20-30 mins, then this game is not for you.

If you want a sandbox game that is a real test, that force's you to work with your friends to get the most basic things done, and that gives you the chance to not just survive but to build a community and thrive then give this game a go.

I will tell now that it will not be easy, it will take time, it will push you close to keybord smashing rage but when you start to understand the game and make headway then it becomes a rewarding experiance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, Life Is Feudal – what a spectacular game concept and with the level of developer commitment that has been displayed thus far, I am excited to see what the finished product will look like.  Let's just get the summary out of the way so you don't have to read a wall of text if you don't wish to do so.  I will detail everything later.

The Summary:

LIF:YO is a stand alone game that is being developed completely separate from another project the devs are working on (MMO).  The price tag is a bit rich for an Early Access game, in my honest opinion, but that $40 was well worth it simply due to the fact that have on record almost as many hours as many of my “fully polished” titles in my library.  There is plenty to do but at the same time, it is very possible to hit a brick wall until other features are added or tweaked.  Overall, if you like a game that simply takes time and effort to create something very cool and organic, this game is for you.

The Deets:

You start off with nothing more than the rags on your back.  It is up to you to find a suitable area to sustain and survive.  Is the game possible to play single player?  Absolutely with some tweaking of settings or multiple characters.  Is the game more fun to play multi-player?  By far!  Either set up your own server or join one to play with more people and make the game really exciting.  Build up your defenses, barter with your “neighbors,” master a skill set that no one else in the area has mastered to make yourself a more valuable asset to the community.  All of these things take time and effort to accomplish, but the reward is that you have built something to truly take pride in.  Fixing a broken down wall isn't as simple as replacing a couple blocks.  It takes mining materials and the skills of multiple trades to raise the wall again.

Resources are diverse enough to offer quite a bit of exploration and travel to various locations.  Are they a bit too sparse?  Maybe.  But for what the game is now, it feels appropriate.  Use the materials you have to refine your skills and make higher quality items for trade or protection.  The possibilities are numerous!

There are quite a few bugs... there's no denying that, but the devs seem to be on top of things as long as they reported accordingly.  There are some balance issues within the game that make it falter.  Again, the devs will surely address these before the game is finalized (hopefully by Q3 of next year as they plan).  The UI and combat can definitely feel clunky and unresolved, but over time, it will get more and more optimized to better suit the needs of the game.

Essentially, what you have to remember is that this is an Early Access game and there are going to be bugs.  But if you can past those bugs, horrible optimization, crashes, etc. and realize that the game offers far more positive ideals and possibilities, you enjoy the crap out of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yah, I played it a bit. It was OK, I guess...


In all seriousness though, I've been taking a break due to school and what-not for about five months, but I used to play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it, hence the 1500 hours. It's an incredible game. I remember the first month it was out, the sense of exploration, real people trading with others, people owning bustling shops, real landlords with real slaves and farmers, real crafting specialists, it's all player-driven, no NPC's.

It just got better and better, exploring new things, no developed Wiki to guide you through, and after a year it evolved into what it is now. They have built upon an epic, moldable foundation and the game has so much content to work with.

Yes, it can get incredibly repetitive, but that is if you deny the way it is supposed to be played, and that is with others. In feudal times, you would have to rely on other to assist you in survival, it's not supposed to cater towards people who want to bolster all skills and survive on their own. A house needs glass, for that you need a smithing craftsman, It needs lumber, so that needs a carpenter. And then finally, you need an architect to design the house. You cannot adorn all these skills alone, so it forces you to rely on others which is something really cool.

Bustling player-built cities, large-scale battles on open fields, struggles for resources and power influence, the things that happen in this game are endless.

Right now, they are 64-slot servers... imagine everything I said above on a 10000 slot server, which is what is planned for the near future... AWESOME!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

INTRODUCTION

This game is a great game. With its early access. Its still fun. Sure there is no tutorial for how to craft stuff. But the fun is going online and finding out how. You dont want to know how to do everything in one way how. You could be know the craftings of only a Blacksmith or how to build or make food and not know anything else. Thats the main fun. The other fun thing is how the guilds work. They arent like a regular MMO medival guild. Its Realistic. Come home from work, hop on the game. Say hi to your buddies and tell the new people where you from. I met a guy today from Kentucky. He helped me skin a bear. And then, after that you do your job. And do the same. The other people who play for 9 hours guard or are the Owners of the faction. The System is great, and the people are very very nice. Greatest community I have ever met. Another thing that happened today, it took 3 guys with Scale armour to kill a bear
two went unconious the other fired like 16 arrows into the bear. They said it was dangerous for me because I had Leather.
And so I went out, I found a bear and they warned me, I got knocked down sure and retreated to the water. I then slinged it and retreated. Slinged it and retreated. About 50 Slings and it ran away but I slinged it about 4 more times. It sat down and it got tired. Finally it died after 8 more slings. I got the Black guy to come, Everybody was amazed at what I had done and I felt like this was the best game I had played this year. I am waiting for more to come

REALISM
This game is trying to be realistic also. With the way the AI act to how long crafting and growing trees are. I would love it if there would be guids with huge factions with Neighborhoods with about 6 people in each house and a Kingdom with about 50 people. Men and Woman (Woman that are Girls irl would be alot realistic then Fake woman) filled in the houses. It would also be great if there was random AI bandits. the AI bandits for the Wolves and Bears are great! Sneaking upon there prey. I stalked upon a Wolf and followed it upon Miles until it turned around and tried to eat me. It ran after it saw my buddies chase upon it. That was also a great feeling! It acts like real AI! Bandits or enemy humans would be a great addon with own tents and also expanding and also coming from the Ocean sailing with ships.

ONLINE: PLAYERS AND THE COMMUNITY

The players are friendly and feel like your talking to real friends irl. They are helpful and its unlike the true internet that insults with or on your Iphone with all kinds of Drama. I only have seen a admin have to ban a player for Sexually assaulting sombody and then trying to kill him. But I then heard he was a new player as his friend joined. The new players can also be very nice. This may be my first day but this is my experince. Diffrent then any other game I played. Sometimes the Younger players that are 12-15 would do somthing like hit you but as long as you know them well and you die close to a house that you spawn at. Best is not to scream at them unless your teamates do. A man named Jacob kept killing us in our own guild. But it was fun, we all hid in a barn and Jettman the owner moved and he found us all... But we were all having fun because we all worked hard on our skills and getting Resources so what else do we do? Going raiding is fun sure but I mean real fun.

GRAPHICS

The Graphics are good. Includeing the Sun going down looked realistic not just going down instantly. It took time. I played on all Settings High and the game didnt lag or give me a bad Framerate either. Only a couple lag spikes. But I would give the Graphics a 9/10. I heard alot of people say the Graphics are good.

OVERALL

I think this game is well done and not rushed. I never wrote this big of a review besides Arma 3. But this review means more then any other of my Reviews. I think the Dev's did a great job on this. They even reply to complaints. A review complaint was a guy that was banned because he said the game was boring in Early alpha. He later was unbanned because of his Review which changed. Other Developers dont do this. Other games ignore peoples bad reviews and ban them thinking it solves it until they ban half of there game. Everybody is nice. Give this game a try. Watch broacasts also to help.

I really do recomend getting a few friends together who all want a great experience so you can thrive, because just like in real life, you are not a one man army, and it takes a village, to build a village.

reviewText:
The devs are active, and the current problems it has are the sort that money will fix. It is worth £15 not £25, in its current state, so get it during a sale.

The player community is lovely, and in a way the game's mechanics encourage cooperative behaviour through roleplay and establishment of organisations such as 'kingdoms'. Individual players have the opportunity to make their own choices in a (sometimes) violent world, so there is a balance between gaining followers through public image and power.

The 'Mixed' rating is because the game was put up for alpha in a state where most players experienced game-breaking bugs, this is no longer the case. The game is now about ready for release. It could take players directly from minecraft.
Once the game switches to being an MMO they will be re-submitting it to the store, so the rating will be reset without the hindrances and I'm expecting positive reviews.

reviewText:
Honestly, this isn't a survival game. This isn't like Rust, or DayZ, or anything else in the entire category of survival games. This is a unique Multiplayer Sandbox RPG, with a very satisfying atmosphere, a ridiculously deep crafting system, a deep skills and levels system, and at times a painstaking amount of realism. It's challenging, it's rewarding, and it's addictive. I bought it this last weekend, and then shortly after bought it for five others. We're all hooked.

When you see a decent sized group all toiling away at their various jobs, it feels like the world is alive, which so many other games have failed to do. Honestly, ♥♥♥♥ing fanstastic.

Oh and the weeaboos 10/10 would kill myself again did these kids learn to type by smashing their club hands into their ♥♥♥♥ing keyboards?

reviewText:
This game...

It's like The Elder Scrolls had a baby with Minecraft.

Totally worth buying.

Tons of crafting to do.

Tons of hours to be sunk into a digital life.

Don't expect to have armor your first week. This game takes a while to level up your skills. 40+ hours in and i still can't level up my bow and arrow skills, and I've been dumping major time into the game on a daily basis.

Some existing bugs, but none that are game breaking.

I haven't spent much time on a public server, so I can't tell you if there is a ton of KoS in this. With the limited time i DID spend in the public, people mostly were minding thier own business.

The game comes with Steam tools to run your own server on your PC! But we went the pay route and have a server, since the free server is only on if that person is playing/ leaves the PC running

Overall: 8/10

Loads of fun when you have a few friends to build with

reviewText:
Don't let the mixed reviews deter you from trying this game. I admit, it isn't for everyone, but if you enjoy more slow paced, realistic, sandbox type games, this hits that sweet spot. Yes, it takes a lot of time to accomplish things, and yes you will need at least one or two other people to play with in order progress very far, but what results is a far more relaxed and social approach to the online survival/crafting sandbox genre.

This game doesn't hold your hand and can be very difficult to learn how accomplish anything at all, but once you do figure it out, everything feels like a massive accomplishment, which is rare in games these days. As a result, the time you spend in game feels far more rewarding than other games of this type and is well worth the investment to learn it properly.

As I said before, it isn't for everyone, hence the mixed reviews, but if anything I mentioned above sounds appealing, then it is certainly worth a try.

reviewText:
This  game? This game is special. This isn't your typical mmo where you have  to use your rotate your skills or spam to until a Mob dies, nor you can  grind for hours on end, just to achieve max level. You don't have to  worry about end game, you don't have to worry about a gear treadmill.  All you need to do is interact with other players and make the world as lively as possible.

After seeing runescape turn into a wow clone in terms of combat, At first, I enjoyed it. Then I start to realize how boring the combat is. All I was  doing is going from one skill to another, just to maximize my dps. At that point, my mmo heart has turned hollow. Looking for a new mmo to fill that void. I tried countless other mmo that has the same uniqueness to runescape pre eoc. I can't. It's all the same. Every single one of them. The boring quest grinding, that even runecape didn't have that problem, The daunting gear treadmill. I just couldn't do it. Gw 2 was  pretty decent and it held me up for a while with it's more simpler combat system. The same with Eso. (Seriously, Voice acting during questing is a god send.) But this game? It has sparked my love for mmos in general  and embraced it wholeheartedly.

When I first start, I didn't know what to do, or where to go. I was kinda lost honestly. So I wandered aimlessly, not knowing what to do, or how this game worked. It was so different from any other mmos out there.  Yet, I kept going, learning new things such as making tools such as an  axe to get me started. Then I met some people building a fort. They  helped me level the skills needed to build a fort and that was where the  fun really begins. Whenever I'm with people, I always have this feeling that I was a part of something. Even if they're strangers, I think of  them of my own. And when I help them with stuff like getting wood, I felt like I was contributing something big.

And  that's what I realized how socially active this game made me. Don't get me wrong, I'm a very shy person, but it is rare for a game to make me come out of my shell like that. I want to continue being social, I want to hang out with other people in this game. And I can do that, because the game devs gave me the freedom to do so.

I  can be whoever I want. I can be a merc who help fight a war. I can be a wanderer, going from town to town. Heck, even some sort of adventuer doing something crazy. The choice is all mine, and I love it for that.

Am  I saying this is going to be this WOW KILLER?" No

recommended: for whatever reason. I promise you

reviewText:
Life is Feudal is not for everyone.  If you are completely unwilling to play with open world PvP (despite probably one of the best anti-grief systems around,) want quick action on a constant basis, want to gank people without any resulting issues, find the idea of needing other people to do much troublesome, or just don't like a slower pace where building and crafting your community is big goal... then you likely won't enjoy this game.  *Note:  you can play it by yourself and use GM commands, so if you just want to craft away slowly and enjoy the island in the :YO version... then much of this doesn't apply!*

First, the game is very crafting heavy.  In the Your Own version this can be worked around with GMs.  However, that all depends upon server rules for multiplayer.  In the MMO, crafting will likely be a large part of your content.  Crafting requires other professions, and has a little more complexity than your standard MMO fare.  It isn't something that will leave you guessing, though, like many other systems do.

Second, the game has systems for wounds, decaying gear, building decay, etc.  All these things need to be taken care of, along with food and possibly thirst.  Additionally, your character can become exhausted and need to rest.  You will have concerns other than just what to hit next.

Third, the game uses a physics based combat system.  You must aim and time with ranged attacks.  You must aim and time with melee attacks.  If the damaging part of your weapon does not make impact you won't see much for results.  This will be something some like, and others do not like.

Fourth, the game is not finalized in many ways.  It is released for this version, but more work and improvements are still being done (just the focus is now on the MMO.)

Fifth, the game uses a time basis for a number of things (trees and plants, growing herbs in the garden, raising your alignment *which relates to the anti-griefing system,* etc.)  Darkness is dark (unless you gamma adjust... which I wish was not the case but oh well.)  Dealing with good time management will get you more than working without it (although you can get around that in this version.)

The Developers are consistently on their forums, and interact with the community.  They take a lot of the feedback we provide and work on making the game better.  I highly recommend anyone with an interest in the game to look at some of how the game plays, to ask questions of the community and developers (they are on various social media as well as here,) and to consider what you want out of gameplay.  If you are looking for a long term game with social ties, building a community, and dealing with the various other aspects as talked about this may be a game you really enjoy.  If not, you may wish to pass.  The game is not for everyone, but for those who would enjoy such things I do heartily recommend it.

reviewText:
Reccommended if you wish to support the development of the MMO for the future, and you wanted a game that is Minecraft with skill trees in a high definition world.

Not reccommended if you dislike the feel of alpha games and do not wish to deal with bugs and/or crashes.

If you have the desire to see an MMO that will rival Minecraft's sandbox and overcome WoW's limits, and have the spare cash, pick this up on sale. The sandbox features are promising while the progression is self rewarding. If you do not enjoy grindy games, or not wish to risk your money on a game that is basically a proof of concept for a future MMO, no one will blame you.

I personally got my own copy from an excited friend who wanted to share with me, and I urge you to read this review in a neutral mindset instead of positive or negative. I cannot say yes or no for reccommending this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Skip to bottom for review)

STORY


I found out about this game a week before it came out, and my excitement was crazy! I cringed at the price, but knew that i was not only getting this game, but getting a slot in the MMO RPG version as well: which made me feel less nervous about  the price. Finally it downloaded, and i jumped right in with a few friends.


It was hard in the beginning because we had absolutely no idea how to play. But we got along nicely. We found a very nice European server where we joined up with the locals in making a town. I was incredibly surprised to find that i had no lag though my ping was 200. Once we got the rhythem of things, we began to enjoy it alot more.

We set up a little village in a valley where it would be easy to make a living. Farms surrounded our village, mines were started on the outskirts, and the village flourished...kinda. I will point out that it is very hard to start a village, let alone maintain it. But we did!

At this moment our village still sits in that little valley, where we live in peace and hope to one day become a flourishing city...


REVIEW

This game is a very ambitious one: the amount of things you can do is outstanding!

Everything from mining and crafting to cooking and farming: this game offers a spot for every person's interest.


There are bugs of course, but they are being resolved quickly, The developers have proven to me that they are dedicated, and show that through the patches that are put into the game, however small they may be.

The bugs i've noticed are more server side and game crashes than actual in-game bugs. In all honesty, the game as Early Access is coming along quite nicely.

However good the game may be, people still get turned off by the price.

So my advice to people thinking about buying the game is this: If you are interested in the game, by all means get it. But be warned that you may have some troubles along the way. But in the end you get two games out of it: Life is Feudal: Your Own edition, and the MMO RPG version when it comes out.

My advice to the developers is this: Please tone down the price. 40 dollars is not something you would expect from something labelled as Early Access, however far a long the development of the game may be. I understand that you are trying to fund the MMO RPG, but more people will buy it if the price is around 20 dollars. You will still make the same profit you are now because more people will buy it.

reviewText:
I had this game for ages in my wishlist never quite found the urge to buy and play it. Now after it got released me and my girlfriend finally found the time to play it. And oh boy we just could not put it down. Even though it walks the line between tedious and rewarding with mixed success it has a certain appeal and ambition when it comes to it’s huge amount of crafting that has to be praised.

It is to minecraft what the arma3 is to call of duty. Everything requires time and planning. Everything is a bit more complicated but the smaller things are that much more rewarding. And did I mention time? From your primitive tool up to your crazy fortress requires a constant combining of skills and crafting to the point where undertaking huge projects must be tackled in a group. Unless you are truly insane and your rent is payed for 10 years in advanced.

On a sidenote make sure to join / create a server that has the right settings for you and or your group. Nothing worse than building a wall only to see it go up in flames a few days later because object decay was on or to high. You also might not want to grind your teeth every time you try to level up your skills. Server settings could make or break this game dependant on what kind of playstyle you prefer. Happy building!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a great sandbox game. It will keep you busy for hours and hours if you are into slow pace RPG/social games.

Pros:
Very in depth crafting
Decently large map
encourages social interaction and RP
Very friendly atmosphere on some server ( some more like rust on others )
Very emersive...
beautiful skys and landscapes
SO MUCH DEPTH TO EVERYTHING ( the quality of the dirt you plant your seeds in will effect their quality ) Everything has a quality, the higher the better.

Cons:
Still some bugs
textures dont always line up perfectly in the landscape right now leaving small gaps that you can see through
Tunnels can be annoying ( you'll see )
Rocks are bad mmmkay? ( you cant level rocks and they get in the wya of building ) Tunneling ^^ doesnt fix it either because you cant build where you mined.


Things to think about... Do you have hours and hours to spend every night? no? then run away.. but if you do this game is so fun. Get a few friends or make a few friends to build settlements quickly. Remember how many points you get to spend is based on what the srver is set at.

I have a hosted server [EST] Impulse Gaming, there is light RP on the server and we are working on building an arena for our pvp and tournaments with prizes ( in game prizes ) we have the skills cap set at max at 3,000 which is still FAR from what you would need to max everything. So plan ahead what you want to do.

There are guides and wikis all over for help !!

Most important!!! ********* If you do not want a skill in something open the skills page ( L ) and change the skill to either hte lock to not level or the down arrow to downgrade levels.

reviewText:
At this point in development, the enjoyment you get out of this game is pretty strongly correlated to the quality of the group (guild) you play with and the server. This game is really one where you HAVE to work together, especially on servers where the settings are close to what the MMO will be (600-1000 skillcap, 0.5-2 multiplier). However, now that the guild claim system is implemented it can be very rewarding because everything within your guild monument's claim is protected.

As other people have said, it is a pretty slow paced game, which makes it realistic, but I find a lot of newbies don't seem to grasp that. You have to put in a lot of time and have patience in order to get a settlement going and get armor and weapons. And even then, if you're playing on a pvp server, you still need to put work and time in your settlement to improve your defenses or another guild is going to surpass you technologically and wipe you out.

If you're doing multiplayer (where most of the fun is to be had), I would highly recommend using teamspeak, mumble or the like for your group. Communication is essential in multi.

All in all, I've definitely got my money's worth out of this game. This style of game and the way the devs have implemented most things so far seems perfect. I can't wait for the MMO.

EDIT: Jan 2016, since I've written this review (March 2015) this game has gotten so much better. Almost everything is implemented, graphics are improved, dx11 optimization kicked in, and with horses and siege weapons it just seems so much more complete. Definitly buy this game and join a settlement. In-game or out of game. Guilds are always looking for players who are smart and willing to contribute because it is a two-way street. Everyone benefits from having more crafters/gatherers/buildiers/warriors/specialists to help them and to help out.
