reviewText:
Early Access Review

STOP!  Please STOP... BEFORE you buy this game!!

Please READ this CAREFULLY.... BEFORE you spend your hard earned money on this game!!

I remember watching the video before this game launched on early access, and thinking it looked EPIC AS HELL.

So then, the game came out, and almost every review was positive and full of great praise, and the game was a new #1 TOP SELLER on Steam!  WOW!

So I  worked hard to earn some money.  I sold a bunch of toys and my old bike at my folks yard sale that weekend.  I HAD to have this game!!

And then Sunday evening, I finally convinced my father to buy it for me, even though I was still about $10 short.

And as I played the game, my heart full of super expectations began to break slowly but surely.

See, I had been worried before the game launched that the game might not be complete enough or be a bug-infested mess.  That's not the problem at all actually.  In fact, the game feels solid, way more complete then so many other early access survival games of it's sort.

...So, why was I disappointed?

Well, watching the video ads for the game, and reading all the great reviews set me up to be disappointed.  This is NOT a survival game anything like Rust or DAYZ but just better because you can do more stuff and farm and make cooler houses.  I mean, I'm sure you can.  IF you have a group of friends all playing together and all agreeing not to pull your hair out in the insanely steep skill curve of the game.

To give you an idea, I spend three hours in the game.  I traversed a large path through the map, looking for anything or anybody on an existing server with players.  I found not a single animal to run from, attack, fight or even just watch run off.  I saw no other players either.  But I did start trying to harvest and learn the crafting system some.  And OMG.  Let's just be honest and agree that in a game like Rust, most players don't have the patience to harvest wood, ore, and other materials themselves, and instead just try to kill other players to collect their loot.  Okay, now that we understand that, imagine a resource collecting game that is about 1/100th of the speed of collecting reosurces in Rust.  Actually 1/100th might be too fast, it might be closer to 1/500th of the speed of collecting resoruces in Rust.  I mean everything just goes soooooo slow here.  It takes 20 seconds to snap a single branch off of a tree.  Then you need to spend 20 seconds to collect some plant fiber from a plant.  Then find some rock terrain and spend another 20 seconds searching for flint.  Now you can craft maybe a primitive shovel.  Another 20 seconds, and bam!  So you're thinking cool!  That's not so bad, right?  Uhhh yeah, but now this shovel and your skill at using are crappy as hell.  So even if you set your terraforming skill to max at the character creation screen, terraforming even a small square of land is going to take HOURS.  And then you repeat the process to make an primitive axe, and you start hacking some of the smaller trees down.  More time, for every single little log.  And you move slow as hell to move that log where you want it.  And seeing as how it looks to take about 1,000 logs to even make the most basic of houses, you're talking about a time sink of hours and hours and hours and hours just to make anything even half way decent.  Compare this to a game like Rust where you can find a single woodpile, harvest it in 20 seconds, and make a complete shelter three minutes into the game.  or collect a few woodpiles and you can make a nice 4x4 2 story house in 20 or 30 minutes tops.  And remember that in Rust, 90% of the players are too lazy to even do that, and instead just look for other players to killl and rob.

So sure, this game might be great when you get to the point of the videos on the store page, but after playing this game for a few hours, that it obviously so far away that it's honestly just not worth it.  I'm not going to spend 10,000 hours of grinding away in the game to get there.  And yes, I could get friends to buy the game and help me, and yay, then all of us only need to spend $40 each on the game, and spend only 2,500 hours of game time skilling up and getting to that point.  Ugh.  I hope you see my point.

Before you even think about responding yelling at how bad my review is, instead go to youtube and watch some random game play videos.  And in all of them, you'll see people doing the exact same thing I did in my first few hours.  Collecting twigs, and plant fiber and looking desperately for fun, but saying something about needing to find friends and learn more about the game.  What I mean is, people are going to be boring crap.  You're not gonna see people with awesome houses and cities and advanced armor and weapons and epic fights.  No, you'll see this same super grind of skills, collecting the most basics of resources and the videos will honestly be pretty boring to watch. Now, if all of the videos now for this game are boring to watch, imagine being in their shoes playing the game and advancing at such a super crawl in the game.  Oh boy!

The game is pretty solid, the graphics look plenty nice.  But honestly, I see about 98% of players being wayyyyyy too bored to continue to invest the time required to 'get to the good stuff' in this game.  I am a patient gamer, but playing this game made me want to break my arm to go play with the hackers in Rust instead.

Buy it if you know what you are getting people.  This is not Rust.  The game might be deeper and better yes, but realize that you are going to be the most patient of all patient people to even get anywhere.  I mean in the upper like 1% of gamers.  For over 90% of gamers, even thouigh they might like the 'idea' of this game at first, they will soon find something with a much quicker speed of game play and advencement.  Not many people will want to spend 30 hours just searching for flint and twigs and plant fiber and then realize that OMG now they need to spend 90 more hours at the next most basic stage of character skill development.

Most people complain of GRIND in mmorpg games.

Magnify that grind by about 1,000 and you have 'Life is Feudal'.

You've been warned.  Buy at your own risk now.  (I wish I had seen a review like mine here BEFORE I bought it)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

310 Hours played, a dozen or so servers.  PVP, PVE, Raiding, etc.

- $40 is very expensive for a early access game.
- Definitely got $40 worth of fun out of LiF
- Right now the amount of fun you will have is heavily dependent on the server you are on.
- There are servers with  house-rules and servers without rules.
- The skill progression of the game is completely different for each server as well as several very important factors, all tweaked by that specific server's admin to test those settings.
- You need to find a server that will play at the speed you want to play, with the amount of people you want to play with, with the rules want to abide by.
- The PVP is not broken although you will find swinging with a wooden shovel is not very effective when compared to a claymore and the hitboxes are a little iffy.
- There are currently some serious bottlenecks with how much you can do to a server before it starts to get bogged down.  Cutting down trees and leaving stumps, excessive mining and building are no nos
- Remember this game is an Alpha, and as much as you want daily updates with groundbreaking new material you are basically signing up for a testing job
- All this being said, actually creating stone walls, metal tools, suits of armor, etc from nothing but what you find and build is incredibly satisfying.  To go from a naked guy with a handfull of cookies to the proud owner of The Vault"
recommended: and the highest quality producing iron mine on the server (all while being constantly harassed by raiders) provides a sense of achievment i've not found in many other games.\n- Soloing this game is tough but i find just one or two other people is all you need on any server with a skill cap of 1000 or above.  Large groups are very fun to play with but some people are picky about which job they want to do.\n- I wont be like the rest of the reviewers and pretend to know whats going on behind the scenes with the devs but as far as my experience goes they have been great

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You find yourself alone on a beach, wearing nothing but your trousers and carrying a handful of cookies for survival. As you run towards the nearby forest you see four men in leather rush up a nearby road with crossbows in hand. You decide against your better judgment to follow them up a mountain. You watch from behind a tree as they stealthily get into position below a larger force of heavily armed people. The scene before you begins to unravel; There is a vast mountain fortress with high walls and an impenetrable gate. The defenders are raining arrows and bolts down on top of the besiegers who have chopped down the trees and used them to erect palisade walls for cover. The group you followed is allied with the defenders, and just as they are about to open fire the attackers spot them. Swords are drawn and chaos ensues. Two attackers and three defenders are ultimately slaughtered, one taking a crossbow bolt to the back of the head, and the rest falling to melee combat. As the leather archers retreat to their own stronghold, the battle ends as the injured and exhausted attackers make their way back to their Viking kingdom to count their spoils and nurse their wounds. A protracted, two hour long siege on a mountain fortress, all taking place within your first in-game day. You run to some corpses and find gear, running off into the woods to begin your own adventure, and avoid the bloodthirsty feuds of warring nations.

This is Life, and it is Feudal. The above is an example of something which happened on the server I play on, and I am sure on many others as well. The game itself is something many people have been waiting for - a true role playing game where you take on the task of a builder, farmer, carpenter, blacksmith, miner, forester, healer, alchemist, and so on. Players must work together to survive, establishing settlements and hunting wildlife, mining deep tunnels and clear cutting entire forests. Everything you build, or grow, or cook, must be made from things gathered elsewhere, bringing a sense of true accomplishment to completed tasks, doing away with the instant gratification many games provide for us these days.

Will you be a bandit? A Thane of a Viking keep? A humble farmer serving under a just and noble lord, or a wandering merchant selling his possibly ill-gotten goods to the highest bidder? The choice is yours in Life is Feudal, and for an early access Alpha game, it is arguably one of the best games to date in my opinion. Aside from the random crashing, and a few mechanics in game that one would expect to be completely possible but are not implemented yet, I would strongly recommend this game to anyone and everyone who loves medieval times and role playing games.

10/10 !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: You will put many hours into this game before you see any significant progress. The game does not instantly reward you. You will spend lots of time on the wiki and in forums getting answers to your questions. If you plan to play alone, you're choosing to make the experience much harder on yourself. To get full enjoyment of the game, join a village.

If you're looking for a relaxing game with a deep crafting system, the ability to create any conceivable design for a village (within the limits of the game mechanics of course), a challenging yet rewarding gaming experience, then this game might be for you. I'd like to first address the reasons I believe people would not enjoy this game.

1. You will not be instantly rewarded for your labors. It takes time to erect a clay hut, to construct a house, to build a wall. If you've played Rust, you're more familiar with the ability to simply gather a certain number of wood and clicking the structure you wish to build. In LiF, it's much more tedious.  The gathering process beforehand along with acquiring the skills necessary to even gather those materials are a discipline in and of itself. Once you do achieve the appropriate levels and gather all materials, you can finally build your structure, that is if it's on level ground. If the ground is not level, you must terraform. If you're not familiar with terraforming, this game is a perfect introduction. All it means is diggins out dirt and leveling out the terrain.

2. Lack of NPCs. This, in my opinion, adds an interesting dynamic to the game. It forces players to cooperate in ways they may not have before or have always refused doing. However, the amount of time and effort it takes to gather certain ingredients makes it almost advisable to establish some form of trade contract with another player to help with your experience.

3. Weak PVP system? Long story short, killing other players can be an immense challenge considering their abilities. For example, you can always run into a village in full armor and a two-handed sword and murder a player who's unarmed, and lacks armor with ease. Of course, this is assuming you have the appropriate levels to even wear armor which you have to craft and you can only craft that armor if you have the appropriate gathering levels to get those ingredients. This is why cooperation is stressed in LiF because you can have different players have various roles (blacksmith, carpenter, herbalist, etc) and you come together to build a flourishing experience. Anyway, I digress.

Assuming both players are in a consenting battle, it won't be shortly won as the targeting system is physics based meaning wherever you swing is where you'll do damage. Since the game is in Alpha it's not always accurate. Of course you can move around and block and there are even crossbows to attack at range. And the game does not reward you for killing others. In fact, in a way it punishes you. You have a prayer skill which is measured by something called Alignment. Everytime you do damage to another player your alignment decreases. This means, if you die with low alignment, you will lose skill points and the lower your alignment the more points you lose. However, you do have the ability to invite a player into a unit" which makes it so alignment is not lost during combat. You can begin to see how random death matches actually hinder the assailant and simply inconveniences the victim.

4. Bugs. If you purchase the game in this current state
date:
you will notice bugs here and there. They do not significantly impact your experience nor does it take away from the game. All the necessary components are in the game and you will be able to play it just fine.

5. Intense graphics requirements. Many players including myself have to lower the graphics settings to lowest to avoid sluggish gameplay. But I have to say even with graphics set to lowest the game still looks great.

If you can get past these points and are still interested in playing the game
recommended: I just barely scratched the surface. I recommend giving this game a chance to lure you into its creative depths and challenge yourself with a very intricate game. You may not be instantly rewarded
hoursPlayed: but the rewards you do receive are damn good."

reviewText:
Background: I have little time in survival/crafting games other then some time I put into minecraft years ago and a few hours in Don't Starve. The fact that they are all in early access for years turns me off. I followed this game since release because I liked the setting but only picked it up around March16 after they had upgraded the engine and ironed out alot of issues people complained about. I just had the itch to craft.

Short and Sweet: Deep crafting systems, nice graphics, Long building times and skilling up can be a negative to some but it makes the accomplishment SOOOO sweet. Engine still seems to have issues and doesn't run great, concerning if they are using the same everything for the MMO. Worth it if you enjoy crafting games and don't mind that it takes awhile to craft things.

Notes: I originally was turned off by the menu system, why can't I just click a bunch of times to chop down a tree?" Well you can set an action to default click the menus are there because of all the options and how deep the game is compared to most open world/crafting games on the market.

Bottomline: I spent 70 hours on a server that had speed up on leveling up your skills as well as a higher cap
date: however things still went at a snails pace. This is a great crafting/openworld ONLY if you can deal with the slow pace. Example: If you need logs for a house? You have to carry a giant log on your back slowly to your work site. Not just chop it down and place 30 logs in your inventory."

The current state of the game after 4 years of development showed that choosing the right engine before" creating a game is crucial for success. Torque3D is not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My boyfriend bought the both of us this game, and we absolutely love it.  If you're looking for a survival/crafting/sandbox/MMORPG that differs from the other bigger titles (in the sense of you really have to work towards your survival and nothing is handed to you or is easy) with medieval flare, this is definitely something I recommend strongly.  From hunting to carpentry, herbology, healing, weapon building, leather tanning, cooking, farming, fishing, war-horse training, animal taming/breeding etc. the list goes on and on and each of your skills open the door for another.  Spending the time to level them is key.  Reaching each goal is a huge accomplishment because you do numerous steps to get there.

Of course it's alpha, and there are things still in the works/being added...but hey, that's alpha in any game.  Being a female gamer who usually refuses to play a male character, xD  the fact that I'm able to overlook this for the time being speaks volumes.  I highly anticipate/look forward to the female models being added.  If you can play  this with at least one other person, you are so set.  Each of you can specialize in your own set of skills, and work together to make mad progress.  So grab some friends, chase a boar around with a pitchfork, throw some rocks at a bear, and eat ♥♥♥♥ you find in the dirt to keep from starving!  After all Life is Feudal!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This would be so good.

If only

- They'd stop turning it into some kind of soggy biscuit snotfest for village people. People would populate servers
- They made the game so solo players could play it without maxing options just to get anything done
- Stop introducing game breaking bugs every friggin' patch
- Fixed flux to be not such a grind
- Fixed the map so we don't see the ocean below my feet
- Put in more animals. Hell. Maxed equals 20 or so
- Reduced dependencies for some skills needing the same thing done over and over (and OVER) to get SP

In other words, develop LIF:YO as a -standalone- title properly and THEN worry about the MMO.

That's just the ones off the top of my head. 30 year free playing gamer here. Not some ADHD teen on Retinol.


200+ hours I played. Nope, not because it's particularly charming or game worthy, that's just how long it takes to build a small house and some semi-advanced buildings before the patch ♥♥♥♥s it all up!!

If you're OCD this might suit you. If you're anal retentive, this might suit you. If playing 20 hours straight to get one skill is ideal, this will suit you.

If you have a life.... make sure it's not wasted on this one.

6/10
Average. Hold off until it gets completed.  Recommended... JUST.

**Open for correction come September 2015.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am rewriting my review. I was sceptical about this game at first due to it being released to make money for their MMO, but this game is amazing. It so far hasn't had the issues of Rust and Dayz.  There isnt killing on sight due to most things you find on people are useless to you.  The skills you gain make the things usefull and things you need lots of like logs and such are too heavy to steal.

You MUST play this with others. Skill caps exist forcing people into professions with a few extra skills. Combat has a separate cap so you can be a farmer warrior without issue.  Finding other people isn't too hard and they could always use another alchemist due to their ingenious system with herbs.  Combat it difficult due to the extremely in depth combat system when you try to kill folks with stone sickles. You can get away every time against stone age tool combat.

This is the most filled out early access game I have seen and is worth the 40$.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So...I also almost did not buy this game. I'll admit, this is a somewhat pricey Early Access game...but it is totally worth it. I think the devs have an excellent vision, and with the direction they're moving in, this game only gets more and more promising. I've logged nearly 200 hours in only a few weeks, and it's been nothing but a blast. Since I've been here in the few weeks I've had it, there have been two patches already, fixing little tweaks and bugs as we go. We're getting updated graphics and UI soon enough, and I can't wait to see how the game runs then.

TR;DR Version:

Get this game if you like RP driven sandboxes, and find a good community. (RolePlay Community Life is Feudal is awesome!) This game is totally worth the money, and if you can get it on sale, grab a two pack and play with friends.

And DON'T go to a stupid server with 3000 available skill points. You're doing it wrong.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is designed similar to the MMO Würm.
To those that don't already know what Würm is, it is a ultra realistic medieval simulator with tons of grinding and real life day efforts to accomplish greater deeds, Minecraft copied Würm and made it into a piece of cake for newbies ( Arcade )
And today we have this game which is way more fast paced than Würm but also harder than Minecraft.

The concept so far is great and I expect lots of features/content to be added through the development periode of the next few months.

Pros:
-Great Medieval Simulation.

-Architectur / Terraforming is vital to be planned out ahead. ( No instant Minecraft houses )

-Cooperative play is highly recommended as resources is a pain in the ♥♥♥ to collect on your own.

-Bandits/PVP players gets punished by lossing more stats on death.

-Great RPG elements shown through a very neat list of skill trees which unlocks upgrades along the paths you choose.

Cons:

-Animals are almost impossible to kill since a moose can take like 150 hits with a stone axe to kill and a wolf will straight up pwn you as you will not be propper quipped for combat until late game.

-Server crashing and slow server list made the game very frustrating, however a few days ago they patched some of bugs which have caused a relative stable version. ( I haven't crashed in awhile now )

-Combat got an animation but compared how they wanted to make it like Mount and Blade hit detection, it is just a prototype as of now and it is more like throwing a dice with a very low chance of hitting.

Conclusion:

Overall I would say this is a good investment, it shows lots of potential in its current shape and for medieval enthusiasts
that wants to experience a simulation of medieval life, this is the game there is so many skill trees to make you anything from a architect to a pope.

I really recommend this game since it got patched against server crashing which allows you to play a sort of demo with limited animations but the gameplay is fluid :)

Hope you enjoyed my review, get in the game with some friends and start building!

Things to expect: Bugs bugs and more bugs.  Again, this is not a complete product.  So yes, there's bugs.  There's quite a few annoying ones.  HOWEVER since I have purchased this game a lot has been done to fix these bugs and to improve on the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well this Early Access Game will remain in unplayed set of games, even though I played it for 10 hours.  The reason is because it is very Alpha Build and not ready for a proper review - that being said; below is my story and hopefully it helps the community inform the Dev team of what needs to be fixed going into Beta.  Hopefully I can review it again in 6-12 months from now.

So my brother loves survival games and he set up a server and began playing it.  I purchased to play with him, but everytime we played - he did 10 times as much stuff as I did.

I would spent 90 minutes just gathering plant fiber, stickers, and apples - in order to make 6-7 animal snares.  I turn around and my brother built a house and had 16 logs piled up.

I would spent 90 minutes trying to level the ground to build something and I would turn around my brother has a giant blacksmith set up. WTF?

Well it turns out my life was feudal because he unknowingly had GM powers, unlimited sack, and could build on unlevel ground - while I could only carrie 180 dirt each run, carry hardly anything, and breaking a branch takes 30 seconds.

We laugh about it now, but the proper way to play the game without GM powers is WAY TO SLOW!  We don't have 30 friends to build a village and the normal way to play is a total time sink for no good reason - in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

review updated on 11/12/2014

Where to start.
lets start with crafting.
it is long and tedious and the amount of time you need to put into it is amazing. it takes a long time to make everything work. to get to that first shack, to your first weapon, to your first house and beyond.
This is not your normal crafting game. this is much more.

I would liken it to Rust ( since i have played it ) but much much better. like 100 times better.
if you drop something there is a timer before anyone can pick it up.
when you die  you have something like 2 hours to pick it up. no one else can touch it until then.

104.4 hours into the game and i'm just now getting the basic  workshop buildings up and i have a very long ways to go before i can make anything resembling a city. This is definitely the first Online game that i enjoy. considering how much i dislike these types of games, this one gets past my dislike because of how it works, the negatives other players get if they attack you.
they can't just rip you off. well they can if you have a undefended village, but thats normal.

Now this game is very much in alpha stage of development as of this review.
personally for me. i think the current cost of $39.99 is worth it.
But for a online game, i like it. very much.

9/10 rating from me.


Its alpha, don't buy it unless you wish to support the games development!!!!

update 11/12/2014

Keeping my review at recomend.
Some new info after my time playing, since i wrote the review i had 100 hours into the game, and now about 430. took my time learning more about the game.

So let's go and see what i have found out.

1. The game has bugs, but thats expected. most are of the annoying type and don't really cause any major issues in the game.

2. Game lag. this is mostly due to the trees and it not being optimized. if you keep setting down like draw distance on trees the lag is manageable. plus the lag spikes but sometimes they are as manageable and sometimes not. again, somthing thats expected in a game this early in development.

3. Servers i have played on a few private servers and had a blast. until they dropped with no warning. which sucks, lost all my and my teams hard work. I'm not normally a online player that gets onto servers so i don't know if thats normal or not.

4. Updates. there has been a couple since i got the game, last one added ability to put furniture where i wanted it. like in the house i built. so that's a plus. and sounds like more animals will be in the next one. so thats another plus.

5. Combat. crossbows suck. the range is ridiculously short and they come before bows. the simplest weapon, the bow should be first., after the sling that is.

5.1 Combat, Swords. now this can be fun, though with the tree lag it can be problematic at times. but once you figure it out it works rather well. take s a bit of time to find that sweet spot. took me many wolves and mooses before i figured that one out.

5.2 Combat Animals. The wolf, it brings a new fear as you run half naked across the sands or in the forests. you learn why humans feared this animal for eons and tried to eradicate it off the face of the planet. freaking things are deadly. until you get some good armour.. then they more of a nuisance. but if you goof, they can still be deadly. as i found out while wearing plate mail armour. wolf hit me in the head and knocked me silly, he then proceeded to chew my intestines like they was spaghetti.

6. Herbalism, the 50,000,000 million combinations thats possible. now this is crucial because you need flux to build the advanced buildings and structures. and flux.. if you're doing it on your own or with just a couple people. can be tedious to get ahold of and time consuming. but the more people you get, the easier it becomes. and if you have other camps willing to trade. then it becomes super easy.

6. Plant Fiber and coops and making of snares. this one i don't much care for in its current state. plant fiber is very time consuming to get. because you only get 1 from each swipe. even with a team of people working with you, its still a chore. especially since if you want to stock your coops to get dung. well you need a ton of snares, and making snares requires a massive, huge load of plant fiber. i think thats the one major issue i have with this game. that and that coops don't really work yet. and the amount of dung you get off it.. is tiny, and tiny dont work if you have a huge farm that requires it.

there is still a fair amount of content not added yet as of this updated review. but i still endorse this game. and i can see it just getting better and better.


and a reminder.
this is a game in development, it has bugs and issues and on some peoples computer. it either won't run or lag so badly you can't really play it.

Read the system requirements before buying!!

if you're close to the min specs. your not gonna have a 60fps, more like 15fps or 5fps.

until more content is added that is all for now with this updated review.

The release went a little rough, but in the end they've done everything promised and then some. The release day bugs that plague many folks were cleared up just a mere few days after.

The game is a great survival sandbox that REQUIRES cooperation, time, and patience. The grind is hard and long but when you finally finish a long project, its well worth all of your hard work.

reviewText:
This game is complex, and it is not intuitive and depending on the server you play on can be very slow to do anything.
At its core though it is what it says it is though, and boasts some great features buried deep within its context menus.
In some ways, I am growing to like this as it does serve as a filter that caters towards a certain type of player.

Like any game.. it has its fair share of bugs.. maybe more then others, maybe less, but it is being actively worked on and the developers are fixing bugs at a seemingly steady pace and most importantly are engaging with the community to do so.

Talking about gameplay,
This game is not fast paced, though can be depending on server settings etc.
This game is not really good as a solo player, you need to be in a group or join a settlement to really enjoy it and to progress quickly and get the most out of the emergent gameplay that occurs 'in my opinion'.
This being said, being a solo player is still viable, but you will not progress as quickly as a group of people(provided they are coordinated).
When you talk about combat, having a couple friends is always better then having to fight and fend of an attack alone so as a solo player making allies would be important.

If you are looking for a PvP orientated survival game that is complex, has RPG elements, takes time to play and learn, has a detailed crafting system and makes you look up a wiki just to chop a tree down this could be the game for you.

This game demands time and patience,
I recommend this game as graphically it is nice, gameplay it is ok once you get used to it, but I would not encourage people to rush out and buy it.
This game caters to a niche type of player, do the standard research and be sure you are willing to put in the time, and have patience to learn and play this game.

reviewText:
First of all, WHY THE **** MIXED REVIEWS?!   This is an awesome game, it runs really fast with maximum settings on my pc -- my pc is a normal pc not even a gamer's. This game includes an ininite amount of hours of variated and fun content, and it looks awesome. It's awesome, like minecraft hugely realistic and with epic^1000 graphics. When crafting each type of item it's like a puzzle itself, in an awesome way. When you finish a building you really feel proud of yourself, like if you had built it in real life.  The 'grinding' it has, it's pretty fast and you end up with awesome results. Spent 2 days and built a huge stone wall, all by myself -- Finding stones, Choping trees, getting wooden boards out of them, digging clay. Even though you might think it takes long to built only a stone wall, it really feels like didn't, because you don't built the entire wall at once. You build each section at a time and rapidly feel the awesome results of it. And not only that, there are about 30 different types of 'Wall Sections' of each tier. (Wood, Stone, Castle) Some of those are: Wall, Diagonal wall, tower, diagonal tower, gatehouse, wall with stairs... This game is awesome ! It is hugely immersive and detailed. It is slow-paced but it feels like if it was fast-paced after playing a little. I hugely recommend this game, for people who like RPGs.

To play this game really feels like being in the medieval era" 9/10

reviewText:
If you're anything like me you'll love this game.

I've desperately been searching for a community based town building game. This game has that with pvp aspects added in. It definitely has a long way to go but if you find a good server you can still get a very enjoyable experience even though everything is not fully implemented yet. The future for this game is very bright and even if you don't buy it to support it's development I would keep your eye on this game for when it hits MMO phase.

Pros: The variety of servers available really lets you choose your own play-style. If you want to go alone and keep it easy you can choose a server with high skill multiplier (you level up faster) and a higher skill cap (so you can do more things). While if you're looking for a challenge you can join a server with lower limits and slower leveling (such as Camelot). For me, I enjoy the challenge and I feel rewarded when I finally finish building that project I've been working on, or that I finally reached that level I've been training for. EVEN if this game was to stop being developed today I know that with the modding community the way it is, and the guys over at Camelot server, this game could still be enjoyable indefinitely. Being a part of community and being needed for your skills by that community is an amazing feeling and really promotes the social aspect of this game.

Cons: Unless skills are set to over 1500 max you'll need at least a few other people to play and build a community with. Some servers are poorly managed and it may be hard to find one that really suites your play style that is consistently up. The game is still lacking in may aspects, but it's in alpha and you are supporting development by buying the game like it is. If you're into playing solo or a lot of heavy action packed game-play you may not like this. If you don't like medieval settings or non-targeted combat (like chivalry or mount and blade) you may not like this game.


My Alpha review is 10/10
See you in game!

reviewText:
I will not play this game right now.. BUT I give it a thumbs up! Let me explain...

It's a great game; hours of entertainment, good mechanics, good graphics, and its really fun! Unfortunately every time I get the urge to play I am immediately turned off by one thing... flux...

It's a small issue I suppose but the requirement to grind HERBS for flux to make steel if you're like me and don't have the means to play with lots of other people in collaboration means that once you out enough hours into the game and you start needing a lot of steel for everything you end up spending weeks just clicking on herbs trying to grind enough randomly dropped ingredients for flux.. It's not immersive to me and if this issue was fixed I would be on this game CONSTANTLY!

Again this is my own personal opinion and if you have the means to play with lots of people and can collaborate as many do then this likely won't be an issue for you!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Allow me to say this first.

The game is in early access, and is by all means flawed. There are bugs. There are things you will dislike. There are parts you mind find amazing, but sadly not yet implemented. All of this is present.

But besides that, I do honestly believe that if you have ever shown a liking towards the idea of being a medieval peasant, who can maybe work himself out to be a capable warrior, skilled farmer or perhaps a prized alchemist, this might rock your boat.

Let us first summarize the pros. The game presents and open world with other players, but you must not worry about getting stabbed with a nearest stick as soon as you find another human being. Not only is this forbidden on most server, it also has negative consequences. As I mentioned above, there are several profession you can do, and freely combine if you for example want to do basic farming as well as basic smithing, though such merging will prevent you from being a master in either. The game requires you to play in groups of multiple people, which could be considered a downside, but I like this feature, since it can create a friendlier atmoshphere, forge possible friendships and makes it feel much more like a medieval town that you work towards. The various professions have quite a bit of depth in them and all are equally important to the community.
Very importantly, I find the developers to be fairly active and helpful, despite some fearing an unknown studio will fail. The updates are surprisingly common and you can also track what they are up to from a number of videos on their channel.

Now about the bad. It might be very easy for someone to find the game repetitive, as you are often required to amass a certain amount of resources before you can focus on something perhaps a bit more desirable. To add to the injury, you will see a lot of progress bars, which might be fast, but are frequent. The game is not the most optimized in the world, though it went up a lot lately, and is surprisingly stable. The combat system leaves a lot to be desired, mainly in precision. This will hopefully (and likely) be changed in a later update, yet as of now, it must be mentioned.

The recollection.

The game has an incredible atmosphere, bringing you to the harsh world of feudal times. If you ever wanted to be a medieval smith, hunter, farmer, alchemist or perhaps a builder, you will find this game quite pleasing. The long time it takes to complete various tasks such as building houses or creating complex tools can be infuriating, but if you manage to find a friendly group of people with whom to work on a village and get to speak with them on, say, teamspeak (which is very common, no worries), a lot of this boredom will dissipate, thanks in no small part thank to having people to talk with as you do your things. With all that, the game deserves your attention and perhaps further investigation.

And that is my recommendation.

reviewText: This is a game with lots of potential as well as already being a pretty good game already. The developers are quite active in the forums and are good at fixing bugs quickly. The game had a bad release with lots of bugs, but they've fixed a lot of them in the first few days, with more patches to come, which helps to show their dedication to the game. The one MAJOR thing is to make sure you have a computer able to meet the system requirements, which are quite high, as this is the one game out of the almost 90 or so that i own that i cant play on my computer, due to the high requirements for the graphics card. I would personally wait for a week or two before buying, so that they can hopefully get all the bugs worked out. The game is not for people who aren't willing to spend the first 5-6 hours just getting the very basic tools and starting resource gathering. It is a game designed for co-op, which makes single player virtually impossible due to the huge amount of time needed to do anything. I would recomend checking on the forums to find a group to join if you dont have a few friends to play the game with, as there are lots of great guilds out there to play with.

reviewText:
This game is truly a masterpiece when it comes to sandbox survival games.
It is all there needs to be to make a successful game of the genre. For one i would say the best feature is the hardcoreness and the complexity of the mechanics and how the game works. Sure the game could be even more complex which developers are working hard to deliver (new features etc), sure it could have NPCs and better AI but in its current state it's truly worth the price.

If you have been let down by the multitude of early access medieval survival games spamming this overcrowded market, you should get this one and stick to it until the end.

The game has close to no bugs at the moment, the developers are close to the community, the road map is respected by days or even hours, this is not a hit and run like many other early access games.

The graphics are astonishing, the game runs well on any PC (the only issue which is not really an issue are loading screens when joining a server taking too long if you don't run the game in windowed mode).

All in all, i recommend this game fully, if you are looking for some fun and rewarding experience.

Disclaimer : If you are looking for a spoon fed baby's first minecraft-like experience this game is not for you.

The game has is quirks but again I have play 'blockbuster' finished games that suck way more and have given me less dollar value.


Those reading this on the fence - please don't let the review above stop you from considering this game.  Know this about this game – it is a GRIND… “you want to do this, well to do that, you need to do this first, then that, then that other thing and finally you get to do ??? wait what was it I was trying to do?” – that is this game in a nut shell, if you have OCD this game will be suck you in and you LOVE it and hate it as the hours peel away… if you are looking for a quick gaming fix erh, you won’t last 1 hour.


As for this ‘paying for this supports the MMO” erh – yeah – they made that clear to me… and take any franchise and guess what… do you think more $$$ went into make the last COD better or advertising for the ‘new’ COD – where did that $$$ come from – from you buying the now unsupported older versions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is early acces, don't buy if you are not ready for some problems.
But LiF is realy good game.
Why?
Because of many reasons. I will tell you about them later, now it's time to say why you must NOT buy it.
1. If you dont't like to cooperate with people to reach the hight goal.
2. If want to get fully functional game. (Just wait a few months, boys and girls).
3. If you cant stand medieval.
In a case those 3 points aren't mettter for you - buy this game. Yeah, its not yet perfect - but its playeble, just find a party and build up your own kingdom. You can be mighty warrior and master alchemist, lazy bowcrafter or talented blacksmith, fisherman or hunter. But you can't be superman (without GM tools). So to get smth good you need a friends to co-op or just other players to trade.
Developers still working to improve engine, but after we will get huge amount of content.
But its my opinion.
To be sure that you need this game - try to watch some streams and gameplay videos.
9/10

UPD

After half year I wanna say that game is truly cool. Every few weeks new updates and patches. Hotfixes are always delivered as fast as possible. Developers are realy taking care about their game. For sure some bugs exist, but game is still in early acces, so its allright. Amount of in-game stuff is totaly amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Considering this is an Alpha stage game, it is suprisingly addicting. Despite the bugs and fairly frequent crashes, I can't seem to get enough. I bought this game expecting to play a bit to see where they were in development and really play when it was finished, but once I started... 130+ hours in about 4 days and a few groggy days at work later, I'm still hooked. Think 'The Sims', 'Skyrim', and 'Minecraft' rolled into one game..

As stated before, it's not finished, there's still alot of features disabled and many of the ones that aren't are buggy or obvious placeholders.  But the idea and style of the game are sound, and it is entertaining.

My biggest complaint so far is the server selection screen.  It is too basic. It needs filters and the option to save or identify servers you've been on.

Overall, it's very promising.  I look forward to when it's finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With only 46 hours total, i'll give a review of what i think so far.
This game is outstanding, with only a plaster shack build and a kiln to keep me company, i'm completely subdued in the environment. The mechanics of the game are good for it's state, the animal AI is good and the crafting is brilliant.
More on the crafting. The mining aspect of the game is realistic, not Minecraft like where you can dig a mineshaft 300 blocks long in the space of half an hour, in this it would take you weeks. Hell it would take you months.
The Buildings are realistic to every detail, they also take much longer compared to other crafting/building MMOs.
I cant realy comment on the PvP as i've only fought a tree with an axe so far.
The skills are in-depth and have a promising future.
All in all. If you are a hardcore survivalist that loves PvP, survival and building. This game is the one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is like the next Minecraft, but in 3D.  It's starting out just as funky and buggy and lacking, in my opinion, however I can see that it's turning into something darn great.  The only real issue I have so far is all the darn progress bars.  I don't really like them, I'd much rather have a minecraft-esque style of harvesting things.

By that I mean more live-action; if you held down left mouse button to harvest bark or search for things instead of just click and let a progress bar fill I feel it would be more engaging.  It could be something along the lines of every tick there's a %chance based on your skill and other variables that you get whatever item you're trying to get, be it flint, bark, etc.  And making it so there's little mini games for fishing and the like would be pretty great too, I feel.  Yet, honestly, that's really my only complaint.

There are a few issues with terrain generation, yet I'm sure they'll get that smoothed out.  I mean I saw seams in the terrain where there was nothing but void beneath them.  It was kinda amusing, actually.  Similarly I'm sure they'll get more tooltips into the game that explain more stuff.  While it's great to have it like Minecraft where very little is actually explained in the game, the fact that the simplicity of Minecraft isn't there makes it so that things like descriptive tooltips and the like are absolutely needed so I'm sure they'll work on that as they already have some good tooltips in the game.

I've never liked the idea of having to go to an external site or having to watch video tutorials to get even the basics of a game, I've always found that to be clunky, especially when a simple pop-up tutorial on the basics would serve the player far better.  I'm not saying that everything needs to be explained, yet the basics should at least be pointed out so the player doesn't have to stumble through the first couple of days wondering where or how on earth to get flint or rock.

Overall it's an excellent start to a truly extraordinary game, it's beautiful, it's entertaining, it's engaging, and for being in alpha it's already impressively well done.  If you're not interested in the bugs and troubleshooting but you still want to play a sandbox-builder game with surprisingly beautiful graphics and good gameplay then this is, without a doubt, a game you absolutely want to follow and keep your eyes on, there's great things coming from this, I'm sure.  If, however, you actually don't mind, or even like, being part of the testing process, random crashes, strange bugs, and all that jazz AND want to play a game like I just mentioned then this, right now, is completely for you.  You can be a part of gaming history and usher in a truly unique and amazing game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT! Unbelievable how solid this game is now... and for such an incredible lofty vision, the devs have really nailed it for the most part. This one totally changed my view of Early Access games for the good.

LIKES: graphics are actually quite nice, stable game play (no crashes in 30 hrs yet), breadth and scope of crafting, warfare, building, leveling up, etc (very robust features), the fact that you can't really play on your own - promotes team work and cooperative play

DISLIKES: long long long long long long long long long load times. I clocked between 14-18 minutes to get INTO the game.

Totally recommend this to players who like medieval themes, sandbox games, intricate and detailed skill levelling systems, laborious yet rewarding development of characters and their skill lines, have friends that like to co-op

reviewText:
Hands down the best crafting game I have ever played. The main reason I chose this game over other crafting games, like Rust, is because this game has no GUNS. In my opinion, guns ruin most crafting games because that is pretty much what the game becomes about, finding guns.
Lets play out a scenario:
-Spawn
-Create a camp
-Look for a gun
-Find a gun
-Get killed by someone with a gun
-Restart and repeat
Even if you strip back the fact that this game has no guns, and it doesn't make a difference to you, then this game still has, in my opinion, the most in depth crafting system I have ever seen. Along with constant updates to improve gameplay, the UI, and add content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is Feudal, or what my friends and I have started to call it: Serf Simulator 2014, is a hardcore survival/build it all/kill the bad guy kind of game. It has been compared to Rust, DayZ, and Mount and Blade. To be honest, it does relate in different ways to all of these. You can build forever like Rust, the combat is very similar to Mount and Blade from what I have experienced so far, and you have to well...survive, like DayZ. Except no zombies.

Life is Feudal seperates itself heavily from these in that you have to do every little thing. This can be tedious, but in my opinion makes everything worth it once it's all done. Building a simple shack is so rewarding and makes you feel like you've made serious progress. That's only just the beginning though. There is a slew of skills to learn, buildings to construct, and players to make relations with....for the better or worse. Every character in the game is a player, which makes the world either very community-like or very dangerous.

You won't be able to do everything on your own. You must either find friends online, or invite your friends to join you. Characters have a skill cap and you must master certain skills to reach the furthest depths of that skill set. You'll need friends to provide resources from other skill trees to balance everything you work on.

Anyways, I've gone on long enough. I do love this game and absolutely cannot wait to see what the devs have in store for the MMO version of this. Oh, and to top everything off the game has only been out a couple of weeks and the devs have already released three patches. That's a good sign for the future.

7/10. This is purely because of this game being in Alpha. There are definitely bugs and glitches, but the overall gameplay is not affected heavily by them. I could see my rating going up with future patches.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst time I played, I was hooked. Very realistic, brutal, exacting game. For hard core players who want a sense of satisfaction and achievment when they look at their fort and see all their hard work has paid off. However, this game is still in Alpha so very much of it doesnt work and is not implemented. Myself and three other good friends all played while on Skype for a week straight. We built a small keep, which is a monumental task as far as gathering the resources and aquiring the skill to do so. But upon completion of the keep, we found that we couldnt claim it, so the Keep provided no security and we were robbed of all our hard earned resources constantly. We then decided to seek saftey by building large stone walls around our compound, but the gate we built could not be claimed....foiled again. All the while our resources, flax, leather, iron, char coal, weapons, rope and tools were being stolen faster then we could build and/or gather them. So we built a large warehouse. We could claim that...but it got hacked and all the stuff in it was stolen. Our merchant carts kept ...walking away" with other noob players helping them.... this game is a fantastic and engaging game. but its unplayable at the moment by hard core players....no one can expect to put any time in it if all their time keeps getting robbed. SO MUCH POTENTIAL THOUGH! Keep your eyes  on this one folks"

reviewText:
One of the most innovative, interesting and exciting games that I have played in a long time. However, it is definitely not for everyone.

This game is more akin to games like Shadowbane and UO: Online of old and the more recent Darkfall. I really feel like it catches the atmosphere of living in Feudal times. One must survive in a open, dynamic world that is completely controlled by players. One can choose to live their Feudal life as they see fit.

A good deal of the game is crafting and building. Not only that but it takes a good deal of time to get anything done. For these reasons, I find that many are turned off by it. However, it is such a rewarding game for those who value creating one's own settlement and then getting involved in the world around them in whatever ways they see fit.

The combat system is quite good yet takes a bit of time to get used to. Once you get used to it, though, you will most likely really enjoy it. It takes a more realistic approach to combat, where one must learn the range of your weapon and must aim at body parts for maximum affect. It is definitely not an easy system to master and takes practice to get good at it.

The only drawback that it has is it is still developing and you will run into small bugs and issues that need resolving. I feel that it is a constant work in progress.

That being said, if you like the idea of an open, dynamic, Feudal world where you make your own way, and you don't mind having to put lots of time to accomplish it, then I can say look no further than this game!
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, do I recommend this game? YES!! I've been playing this game for a few days with a friend, so this is a review in progress. Let me start off by saying, this game, even in its current state.. is incredible. There's so much depth to it.. it's very expansive and there's endless possibilities. 9.5/10


Pros

+It takes a very long time to gather resources and alter the terrain whilst building houses, and villages. That's a good thing. It makes it more immersive, realistic, and require teamwork. It also feels so rewarding when you complete a project you've been working on. So far, after 3 days.. me and my friend have managed to build 2 huts, a garden, fence, furnace, and blacksmithing station.. even though this seems extremely miniscule, I feel really proud.. like I accomplished something.. and we're planning on accomplishing much more. The more people you have in your group, the faster you can raise your village from the dirt. As long as everyone is working together of course. You'll never run out of things to do.

+You also cannot specialize in all of the professions.. you can only specialize in 1 or 2.. maybe more depending on how you spend your points. So you will need to communicate with other players on what they are specializing in to fill that gap you need to efficently build your village.

+It takes a LONG time to dig a tunnel

+\- Combat? I'm a bit iffy on this one as I haven't had too many violent encounters. While the combat right now is in fact, buggy and the hitboxes are miles off, the concept is amazing and I think this is going to be improved. I got shot by a crossbow, in which I took off running and eventually collapsed from bleeding and then executed. This gave the combat many positive points in my book. As of right now, it will certainly suffice. But don't take my word for it, I've only beat a moose with a primitive axe and got shot with a bolt. I will update on this once I'm more experienced with the combat.

Here are some of my nitpicks, or rather, suggestions on what it would take to make this game utterly perfect.

-This is a big one. Currently, you need to specialize in certain equipment in order to actually use it. This is disappointing. You should be able to use any equipment, regardless of your expertise in it. Expertise should affect how well you use the equipment though. For example, a low level in Crossbow would make aiming shaky and inaccurate. A low level in Mail Armor would make your stamina drain faster. Ect. To not be able to use it at all is unrealistic.

-When you die, a gravestone appears. This is immersion breaking.

And here are some current alpha problems that are surely going to be smoothed out in time.

-Crashing (a lot)
-Lag
-Bugs (of course)
-Freezing
-Stuttering

These are all to be expected. But don't let them stray you away from this awesome game. For these issues to be present while I simultaneously give the game a 9.5, that means this game is GOOD. I can't explain it. It's just amazing. MANY hours are going to be spent on this game. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It’s no secret that Life is Feudal (LiF) is not a complete game.  At the time that I write this, the game is still in an Alpha release.  However, as it stands today, LiF is possibly one of the best games that I have played.   I have played over 30 hours of this game and still cannot equip armour or weapons of any sort (my skill is not high enough).  Many of you are probably wondering how this is a good thing.  It means that the game is rich in detail.  You cannot start off the game and go out lopping off heads; it doesn’t work that way.  Rather, when you first start, you try to get enough to eat, scrabble together enough resources to craft simple tools, and then slowly (very slowly) you start to expand your universe.  I have never played a game that has such depth in the crafting or skill trees.  Sure, there is some grinding that you have to endure, but it is very satisfying once you have completed it and move up higher in the ranks.

LiF is one of the best games I have ever played.  Seriously.  And it still has not been released yet.  Think of how much better it will be when it is completed!

reviewText:
So I bought this game on a whim because a friend of mine ask me to buy it too, and I did, and I did not regret.

Beforehand, I read all the review that is people deemed most helpful, saw that it got a lot of bugs here and there, unplayable graphics, etc. And you know what? The first time I ran it on my laptop, it got shutdown my laptop right away when I'm loading the world from some server. Disappointed? Very. I could run Fallout 4 on my laptop albeit getting 20-28 fps so I wonder why can't I run this game? Simple, the optimization at release is quite poor. So I did what a someone with a brain will do, play it on my PC. And thankfully, it run greatly.

No gamebreaking graphic bug encountered, which seems to be the main complain of most reviews here, no crash at all from all of my time playing this game, and I can play this game flawlessly albeit it does hit 22 fps in dense forest.

So we have that out of the way, now what will you expect by buying this game? Firstly, one thing that you can expect is poor optimization, yes I admit the graphic is quite heavy even for my spec which could run witcher 60 fps with high 1080p setting, and fallout 4 flawlessly too. But it's understandable since almost everything can be interacted with, so the game is heavy because of that. And no, if you compare it to fallout 4, that game is still light in building things since you didn't interact with most of the game, just place things on the ground, while in LiFYO, YOU CAN TERRAFORM THE TERRAIN, my suspicion is that the game is heavy because of this, but let's leave it at that. So, heed that recommended spec before you buy it, does your computer spec meet or above the requirement? If yes, you don't have to worry a thing (possibly), if no, buy it at your own risk. Luckily though, the dev is quite fast on implementing fast hotfixes.

Secondly, this is not a simple survival building crafting game, where all you need to do is know the recipe, have the material and then voila, it appears. Nope, you need to LEARN HOW TO DO IT FIRST. It got a complex skill tree where there're a few skill you need to learn first before you get to the skill you needed. Tedious? Very. Boring? Not so. Which is why having a group or making friends in-game is very valuable. You don't need to be a jack of all trades, you just need to focus on what you want to be, and ask for help for something that is outside your capability. You could learn how to do it, but it will take a lot of time, and don't forget about that skill you want too, it takes time too.

Wiki and youtube is your friend, seriously. They might be outdated but they are still relevant as much since it's still the same. The only problem I had with the wiki is, it's not very complete as I checked it a few days ago, some detailed bits are missing but the general explanation should suffice, if not, check the youtube, there's a lot of let's play and tutorial for life is feudal.

Third, The UI in this game is simple enough. There's status bar, hotkey bar, general info, chat panel, etc. You can customize their position too with F10. Also the cursor and the movement mode can be switched with tab. Like the name imply, cursor mode is used to navigate to panels, while movement mode is used for camera while moving and interacting with the world. The interaction follows Ultima/Wurm online. Whereas right click to something brings up the context menu, and it doesn't take too long to familiarize with this system. Right click on the ground and it shows a square tile which show how big the area will be affected by terraforming or what we can do with that area. It's not everything has their keybinds, but each things have their context menu, and you can set the default action to do something to the left click, so all you need to do is point something and then left click.

Lastly, this game emphasis on player to player interaction, so roleplaying is what it is in this game. You want to roleplay a blacksmith? Go ahead, level up your blacksmith skill, then advertise your service to some guilds or tribes you found. If you're lucky, they'll accept you as their own or you get tricked or worse you could be killed right away, the choices is theirs to make.  I warn you there's no human NPC in this game, only animals and such, so there will be a lot of human interaction.

tl;dr
great game, very VERY time consuming, you have been warned,
not for someone who wants a quick/easy/simple/straight jump to the action-ish game,
needs time to learn the mechanic and enjoys the game,
if you're familiar with ultima online/wurm online or the like of it, you'll feel very nostalgic,
lots and lots of player to player interaction,
heed the recommended spec,
no gamebreaking bug which I encountered so far,

buy it if you like it and it's at your own risks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like to grind, then grind your way into a medieval society!
Complete with murder, hooliganism, deep crafting, realistic terraforming, vicious wolves and lootable player corpses.
All buildings are built in-game by players, all communities are player constructed and completely different from one server to the next.

Game is great fun, but consumes a lot of time - thankfully though, it is a time consuming game that can be casually enjoyed as well as you can always come back and continue working on your skills.

I have several friends who won't play because the game isn't perfectly stable, so if you can't stomach glitches and poor optimization I would wait until the game is further updated for a more polished but I still reccomend it as is if early access issues don't bother you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First, you've got to understand this is an early alpha version of the game.  With that said, it's in a pretty advanced state and a lot of fun already. But here are a few key things to keep in mind:

- Some things are not yet implemented. Actually a lot of things, but there is still a ton to do in the game.

- This is not a quick action crafting/building game like Minecraft.  It takes hours (real time) to build a small mine looking for metal ores.  As you mine out a tunnel, you collect the rocks, you have to take those rocks and dump them somewhere or craft them into shaped stones (which are just as heavy as the rocks) so you must store them somewhere, then you can go back to mining.  It's a slow process...not for those who lack patience. For me it is relaxing, but your results may vary.

- In fact getting your skills up to the point where you can even mine takes a long time.  On the default settings, it takes hours of using your skills to raise them to the point where you learn new things.  The settings are customizable so each server can adjust them to speed things (even to the point of the rediculous).

- Single Player: There is essentially no single player (at least not in the normal PvE sense).  You can start a local server, make it private and no one else can join, then experiment all you want, but it will be a big lonely world.  I've split my time between experimenting on a solo local server and playing public servers.  Both are fun for me...

- Community: The server you join will make all the difference in terms of your enjoyment.  I've been servers where I was welcomed into a community, given a house, invited in to start working on my skills to be a productive member of that village.  And I've been on servers where people have been complete jerks.  There are hundreds of servers, find one that suits you.

TL;DR: If you're patient and looking for a slow paced, realistic game that is still in development, then this may be your game.  If you're looking for something with wall-to-wall action, keep looking, this ain't it.

reviewText:
Where to begin?

Life is Feudal should ideally be played with a group.
This game is entirely playable for a solo player, but your enjoyment will likely suffer greatly alone.
Most complex building tasks are entirely too grindy when attempted solo, but servers are full of cooperative people willing to show you the ropes.

I reccomend either buying this game to play with friends, or searching out a group to join asap once you get started.
While I am not a roleplayer, this game has a vast potential for roleplaying, and skill caps can be setup to create an economy where every character is forced to specialize rather than max every skill. The social aspect of this game is what makes the grind feel worthwile.

The grind can be partially mitigated by server customization as well. Servers with XP settings between 25-100x the default are common. The learning curve is a bit steep, and crafting can be complex.

This game has a significant PvP component, and allows players to beseige each others lands. This means potentially looting and burning weeks of work in one day, but creates real risk, and winning a battle feels significant.
The times and dates for this can be customized, and PvE servers exist as well for the feint of heart.


In all likelyhood you will either love this game or uninstall it in under 2 hours.
Most of this depends on your choice to play alone or with others.

reviewText:
Luckily I bought this game on sale so I only threw out like $20

Let me make this short and sweet as I can for readers convienance. This game is a hellah grind, both level wise and mental wise meaning if you want that big awesome looking keep then you better be prepared to scoure the land for every little piece of wood, stone, thatch, and oddly shaped animal skin nessicary to build it (Thank almighty God for infinity piles) The developers are being sketchy as ♥♥♥♥ about more then a few things and without a good group of people to play with you might as well not even try.

The combat system in this game is a joke, It is literally faster and easier to kill people just running around bare ♥♥♥ naked with zweihanders, you cant see arrows in flight both from archer or victims perspective. Dont even bother building wooden walls and lastly you wont do much else from beating a stick against a rock without investing some SERIOUS time into your server. It seems almost everyone is out for you just for the hell of it and there is really no proper usage of horses yet and player animations are SUPER exploited.

Do I think this is a bad game? Certainly not....oddly kinda fun and satisfying

Could it possibly be more than a time sink one day? Absolutely

Does it need a nerf and rework in many areas? Oh hellah yes

All I am trying to say is that it might be a good game one day and is fun in the short-term but until the developers actually buckle down on it and start having more and better updates and add some MAJOR patches to this thing and desperately needed content this wont be much more than just another regret.

Simply put, dont bother logging hours in this game until it gets alot further along in development and actually gets polished out alot more to the point where it is playable beyond something of a trolls breeding ground.

Guess it is true what they all say, Life is Feudal

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ALPHA REVIEW: I understand the game is in Alpha, but I'm just pointing on my thoughts on the current state of the game. I would recommend this game to help support the developers as I really like the game and it looks as though is has a bright future with a lot of playablility, especially when enjoyed with a group of friends.


A few people have asked for my opinions on this game, so here they are.

The Good:
1. The visuals of the game are really nice. The whole thing looks atmospheric, deep forests, rich villages and nice vistas give the player a nice experience from just walking around. 8/10

2. The Ideas that the game portrays are very good. There's a very in-depth crafting system and a good building placement system which have little floors but there could be a bit more done to liven them up a bit. 7/10

3. The general gameplay is very nice. Being able to enjoy it with your friends is great and the contact currently in the game is brilliant! There's a lot of fun to be had here!


The bad:
1. Performance. I run this game with a 3.4GHz i5 processor and a GTX780 NVIDIA graphics card. If I bump the settings up a bit from the defaults, maybe I increase the tree/terrain detail a bit, my FPS drops a large amount, heading down towards 20FPS. But the game is ENTIRELY playable on the default settings and still looks really good, I'm just not sure how it will run on lower processors/cards.

2. Terrain interaction. The way that you interact with terrain/rocks/trees in this game is very bulky. You look at a tree/terrain segment and are faced with about a dozen options, which for a new player is quite overwhelming. Everything is based on: Look down at terrain" -> "Click" -> "Select option" -> "Animation plays" -> "You get things". There is currently no real player interaction with the environment around you.


The Ugly:
1. The UI. Some elements of the UI
date:
mainly linked with the terrain interaction above don't look or feel very nice. But this is an Alpha and that can change VERY easily.


I will certainly be playing more of this game with a few friends of mine. If you think this game has a bright future like I do then grab a copy
recommended: test the bejeebus out of it and send those bug reports flying in!"
hoursPlayed: September 27, 2014

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grown men chopping wood, cleaning out chicken coops, leveling ground, making soup and hunting moose sound like fun?  Well, it is in Life is Feudal!  Actions build skills, skills are necessary to aquire the ability to do more.  Castles need building, you don't just get to walk up to your own pre-built structure.  There are dangers in the forest and apples to find to keep you alive.

The resource and tech tree in this game is perhaps the most detailed I have ever seen in a game.  There is drudge work, but the reward is seeing a castle that you are building come to life.  With enough armor, weapons, skills and friends, it will then be time to find a few serfs to do the drudge work for you.

My best wishes to the developers of this game to work out the bugs, create an ingame economy, an inplement all the cool features that are still in development.  This game has ALL the potential to be one of the all time great ones!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Read before you buy!

First off, this game has mixed reviews. So I would just like to remind those reading, that this game is still in very early access. With the engine the game uses, it's advancements, and everything the devs are trying to do, it will take time for full release, possibly even a year or 2. With that in mind, don't judge this game based on everything currently in it, things can and will change.

Now that that's out of the way, let me start by saying yes, this game is a grind (as of now). Why? Because this game was built for realism. Rome wasn't built in a day, nor will you build your small shack in one. This game is realistic in almost every aspect, between it's physics based combat system which doesn't require you to aim at someone, to its resource gathering, and construction system. Even its mining system requires you to use supports otherwise you risk a cave in. And while it may be a graphics hog, that's because it's still not very optimized, but as I have said it's only an alpha. However, you can't deny that the game looks really good. Can you guys imagine on the full release, with around 1000 people on one world, what the game will look like in a month? Think about it, you start in an area with nothing but trees and such, along with 999 other people. One month later, you have huge medieval cities with giant walls, lined with trebuchets and ballistas. Huge wars going on between player factions. We can literally recreate historical events in this game with how well it's been designed and planned.

So, if you're still reading, then you know this game is a very realistic game. So please, don't judge this game just because it's realistic. Judge it for it's aspects, judge it for it's gameplay. If you don't like realism, don't judge it at all. Besides, if you don't like realism, why would you be playing a game like this? What it all boils down to is if you like realism like I do, and billions of others do as well, then this game may just be for you. However that depends on what degree of realism you like. If you don't like the grind (which may or may not be fixed later on and shortened) then you may not like this.

So TL;DR, if you like realism, but don't like a grind, this isn't for you. If you like realism, it might be for you. This game is highly based on realism, so if you don't like realism at all, why are you here? It's still alpha, so don't judge based on how the game works now, base your reviews and judgements off of the actual gameplay.

On another note, even bringing up the topic of suicide is a warning sign in itself. If your having thoughts or feelings about this we strongly recommend speaking to someone you trust about these thoughts or feelings.

That sounds good. However, what really matters in this kind of game is resources and territory.

You want to have a real player driven world, with incentives both to conquer and to defend, giving value to virtual stuff and, eventually, making gameplay emerge ? Then you have to have a simulation of RL economics and resource management.

A river, a strategic point, a source of easy income, etc… should be things to fight for, and not giving access to everything to everyone is what creates the need for player interaction, be it conquest, trading, theft, agreements…

Most sandbox RPGs failed because they tried to focus on other aspects of gameplay before laying this groundwork, ultimately creating a giant with clay feet which would clumber as soon as the hype faded, or as soon as something came unbalancing the fragile balance of the more refined gameplay systems.

On the other hand, take the example of a successful sandboxe like EvE : it survived through to good and the bad versions, through the hard drive erasing patches, through the Goons (mad props), through the watergate-like revelations, etc… because everytime remained the incentive to play, to fight, to interact.
If you take player interaction from EvE, it’s a very boring game. And if you erase resource scarcity and territorial value, there’s no player interaction to that game.
