reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time of this review I have put about six hours into the game.

When I picked my first server I started facing the beach, the sea was beautiful and the land surrounding me felt realistic and rugged. As I turned around a man was standing before me holding an axe. I backed off him and he spoke to me, he asked me to leave his camp as he did not trust strangers near his territory. I kindly agreed to give him distance and moved about my way.

Not long after I met up with two other strangers who were looking for a place to settle. They were kind and friendly and we scoured the land for the perfect place to build our home. Once we found our ideal location we shaped the earth for hours, sowed the lands with crops and build our homes togeather. Three people, with no history of knowing each other dividing the labor of the land equally. It was a beautiful and magical friendship that was formed.

As night approached we built a campfire and lit it. We all stood around in envy of the beautiful flames and as we stared at eachother in awe of our accomplishments thats when the server crashed and kicked all of us off the game. I was never able to find these players again and honestly I am really dissapointed to lose such great companions.

Do I think this game is worth $40? Yes, as long as you realize that this game is VERY buggy. The crashes happen often and it takes forever to load. I also found that pushing buttons in certain combinations will result in a crash.

Despite all this, this game has amazing potential. It nothing like DayZ where you will get PK on sight. While I ran into a few sticky situations with other playesr I managed to fend them off or successful run away from my attackers. I found that a majority of players are willing to work with you rather than just kill you for all of your loot.

I really cant wait until this game works out its glitches. Because when it finially does, I feel that it would be the perfect middle age simulator for anyone to enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Cool concept, but painfully slow to play using the default world settings. It's still in alpha [as of this writing] so there are a few things to keep in mind:  1) A number of things don't make sense on the skill tree (which isn't fully implemented yet) and additional tweaking is needed.  2) It hasn't been optimized for typical consumer PCs.  3) It also has the occasional freeze or crash to desktop.

Thankfully, alpha-isms aside, you can adjust a number of the world settings on the private server to let things progress at a rate suitable to your play style.  You'll probably need to fiddle with these to find conditions you like.  If you enjoy hard core PVP and are looking for more realism, you should certainly consider adding this game to your watch list.  If, however, you find PVP about as appealing as finger-painting with cat poop, fear not!  LiF:YO lets you enjoy the crafting and trade aspects on your own server with only the people you know.  That's not to say they won't betray you at some point, but you can ban them from the server if you want to go that far.

On a final note, I am hopeful that support and development for LiF:YO will continue after the MMO version is released since the MMO does not interest me in the least.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first saw this game (I forget where) I thought it was the game of dreams. An open world sandbox MMORPG set in a a medeival setting. Then I noticed the steep price of £25 (or your regional equivalent). However after seeing the trailer and some streams of the game in action I was convinced.

For an alpha it runs quite well with the expected bug here and there but hey, its an alpha. Most the the games terraforming and building mechanics are pretty much to point but could do with some polishing. With frequent updates and bug fixes it gives me a good reason to trust the devs behind this game.

After playing for hours alone I realised I needed to either find some friends to join me on my adventure though the world and increase chances of survival. Or find a friendly group of players who will accept me into their community. (Dont expect everyone to be friendly, this is the medeival ages). As I mentioned after hours of play with friends we finally have a little lake side village which is progressing nicely. A farm, some houses and soon to be a forge.

We hope to gain some weapons soon and either :

TAX THE PEASANTS (other players)
or
Hunt down criminals (Bad rep players)

However.
The combat for ranged weapons is very clunky and can be unreliable. Melee is more reliable at the current moment but could really do with some work.

Final opinion 8/10
Pros:
-Sandbox
-Will soon be an MMORPG
-Player driven
-Strong sense of community
-Highly addictive

Cons:
-Steep alpha price
-Clucky combat in the current build

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine Wurm Online (or Haven & Hearth) with a working and modern interface, combined with Mount & Blade style combat and Ultima Online's skill system. That is essentially what this game is.

This is a stand-alone alpha version of Life is Feudal, and is *not* the MMO that is planned to come out sometime next year, though buying this means you will have a free copy of the MMO when it does come out. What this means is that you are limited to 64 player privately hosted servers and a 1 km square island instead of 10,000 players on a 32 km square continent, and that none of the guild territory control stuff is activated.

That said, it's still a blast, and is worth your time and money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not fun, but you still play it. When you're in a community its like your duty to play this game. After mining for 3 days, mining for gold it clicked... this sucks. ....but they need this gold!! I must continue. You constantly stare at a green progress bar, everything you do you must stare at that green bar. You can't make macros either, no simple ones anyways.

Before you invest your money into this fairly expensive early access game you'll need to know a few things. Don't plan to play this alone, this game is definitely for you and at least 2 other people if you want to get anywhere. It is a great game and most of its current features are solid, but as you play you'll realise that even to build the smallest house you'll need a few different professions first. With limited skill points you must specialize and so will your friends all depending on each other.

I recommend this game as a temporary thing for a big group of friend. Minimum 3 people to play this game. If you play alone don't buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very promising - There is a surprising amount of content to explore given that this is an early access game.

PROS:

- Many of the complex systems are already in place (such as terraforming, construction, logging, etc.) which is good as this is a crafting game at  heart.
- The huge crafting and skill systems require specialization as you have a finite number of skill points to allocate (on most servers).
- This is great for encouraging player interaction and community building. The idea of having a town blacksmith that you need to go to for swords and armor, a logger to cut your trees, etc. is a lot of fun and not something a lot of games like to encourage. You're not a god, you can't do everything on your own.

CONS:

- Combat is promising and deep but not very satisfying at the moment.
- Long server load times (seriously, be patient).
- The engine needs optimization. This isn't up to the Life is Feudal dev team but it does affect their game.
- Occasional bugs and some people experience frequent crashing.

CONCLUSION:

If the dev team can continue building on what they have without falling into the typical early access pitfalls then this game will be the next big thing. All it will need is a promotion from a YouTuber to blow up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played just over 10 hours of this game and from what i have gathered i find this a very enjoyable game.So i will start with the settings for the sanbox mode.The setting can change from how many animals spawn,the time smelting/logs you need to use to smelt Iron Copper Gold or Silver.There are also time set on how long trees grow and many more it is a bit weird to use when you jump in but is quick to work out.The User-Interface is very hard to understand but i have figured out the basics to what most do.You have the stamina bar which is the green bar,The purple bar which im am pretty sure is the health bar and a small bar that is your hunger bar.hunger is a task in its self to do. You can search the floor for food and eat what you can find but if you dont want to do that you can go the farming root and make carrots onions wheat and more.I have made my character more of a miner so i have not did much in farming.but the small part i took in was very easiy to understand. Construction is very easy to do collet a certain amount of items and build with the tools you need.I will state that this game if played with the standerd settings will take you around 5-6 hours just to build your first house.When you figure things out the game is much simpler and faster.I could go on for hours about this game but what i will leave here is my final score.

I give this game a  8.5/10  -ArranGaming

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Alpha, People, ALPHA!

I love this game, I've been looking for an off-line Wurm for some time, and this doesn't disappoint. I host my own server, just for me, with x2 skill gain and am really enjoying building up my little 'community' bit by bit, a potters house, a miners house, a farmers house, a ranchers house, and so on.

It is an early access game, in Alpha - that is it is un-optimised (optimisation would ideally be finished in beta stress testing), it is not full of content yet (there is content but it's more to test the mechanics) and even not all the mechanics are in game yet (an alpha should start with the core mechanics, test them through content, then add more content/mechanics, test those, and so forst). If this is not the sort of game you want to play, with possible roll-backs, world-breaking bugs, crashes - then don't buy this game. Certainly don't buy it, then whinge about the state of it - the fact that it is Alpha is smeared everywhere! If you want to play the game, but not in the alpha state, then buy the game to support the developers to finish it then go away for a year!

Early Access Review

This game is everything I wanted in a Medieval game. The creativity it allows is amazing, It truly is a sandbox inwhich anything is possible. This is very early days for this game and so it has its bugs and issues but that was expected. The game itself plays well and looks reasonable.

You begin with absolutely nothing except the clothes on your back and you have to start from scratch to make a name for yourself. It gives you no hints and just throws you out there to work it out on your own which I feel is great. Everything is done logically so you just have to think what you would need to do IRL and it is likely how you do it in game.

Words cannot describe how happy I am that this game is being developed and I have high hopes for its future. Definetly worth the buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have approximatley 30 hours of actual gameplay, and I love this game! Its a great sandbox/terraform game. It has an awesome military mix in with it.

Pros-You can make the game more difficult or easier based on the skill leveling multiplier. You can also change how fast things grow, smelt etc. The terrain when terraforming has a great reaction based on a more real life scale. The weapons and armors are a harder thing to make so it takes a lot of time for a group of people to turn in to pvp maniacs.

Cons- The BIGGEST con right now is the launcher. It needs a lot of work. If I leave a server or want to change characters I actually consider not playing, because the launcher is incredibly slow and there are times it doesn't want to cooperate at all. I also have had a hard time hosting a server. There are some small bugs related to it being a new game, i.e. some terrain issues where you can see through the map or trees look like they hover.

Conclusion- I would give this game in total a 6.8/10. For a BRAND new game I would give it a 8.8/10. The game has GREAT potential! I would highly recommend giving it a try, right now I think its worth the $40 and with the reaction we have seen fromt he developers I think in a couple months it would be worth more!

Early Access Review

medival survival game ( realistic! ) thats total hardcore in it base ... the graphics are not the world best.. but there are more than ok .. you over see the graphical quality realy fast when you get into the game ...

at this early stage the game isent easy with you .. no form of telling you how and what to do ... some bugs here and there .. but nothing major i have discoverd yet ( tho my friends complain over usb audio devices wont work for them .. i have a g930 wireless headset that works perfect )  but its early access so be prepared for BUGS  =)


This game is quite hard to learn .. its already a big puzzel on  finding out why you cant do this or this .. the game lacks good feedback .. lacks aym anny way of telling you how it works ( you should watch youtube videos to learn the basics of the game !!!)

therefor this game is as hard to learn as eve online is ... but it has hardcore gaming mecanics like eve too....

first of is it worth the mony?

it realy depents on the developer .. well he complete his game? ( have seen many project stop latly after a short while )
will they improve on how things work and maybe change some gaming mekanics here and there to make the game easyer?
will they expand content?
fix console commands and so on ?(for admins and gms)

if the awnser is eas to most of my question ... then yes its worth every penny you pay.


let me start off with .. survival gamesa are quite in atm .. most of them have zombies and monsters that fight you almost nonstop .. this game says ♥♥♥♥ that ... lets make a realistic survival game ... and thats good .( ofcourse you need to like this type of a game)
the game evolves around players on the enviroment. you make your own story .. faction? and so on you say what happens. it takes a ♥♥♥♥ amount of time to even build your first house ..  the look of like its now you use at least a year befor you have a castle ... the skill system is realy good and simple .. tho as mentiont the crafting system is hard to understand from one time to a nother becouse of the lac of feedback and information ( som minor bugs don make it easyer )

i love tho how you can play together and build .. work as a team and so on ..

so i recoment this game if you like medival faction coop based( there is no faction system in the game... so this is kind of role play !) dont care about fancy graphics , fancy voxel system like minecraft and so on .. the game has is own quality the way id does stuff =) build an empire out of dirt  =)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Very Early Alpha Build Reviewed, I will update as patches come out*

Update: A few patches have fixed up a lot of the issues with stability and (finally) added a proper server browser. A lot of skills/build trees remain broken at the moment by some odd choices in the order things were implemented, but if you're willing to have a generally fun (if simple) experience of Rust with Swords"
date: this is a decent buy.\n\nLiF has an incredible amount of promise. For an early alpha build
recommended: I'd call the game nearly feature-complete. A great deal of the crafting is already in the game and ready to go. There's no lack of things to do right now
hoursPlayed: and the steady progression from shoeless caveman to hardscrabble dirt farmer comes at an engaging pace.\n\nThe main problem (and the reason I am not recommending it) is that while they have done a lot of work on the crafting system and modelling
voteText: even the most basic functionality of the game itself is missing. It's highly unstable
helpfulPercent: the game crashes frequently
votesHelpful: and getting the game to load at all can be a challenge. At the moment
votesTotal: there are a number of quality of life features missing that make the game seem to actively resist being played. You cannot disconnect from servers
votesFunny: you must exit the game entirely to connect to another one
commentsCount: and the favorites/history tab does not work
column16: meaning you can lose hours of work if you get disconnected (something that happens quite often) and are unable to find your server again.\n\nIt's interesting to see an early access title have the opposite problem that most have (big on features
column17: low on basic functions)
column18: but I really can't recommend it at the moment. Future builds may improve stability and quality of life
column19: but right now it's simply not worth the 40 dollars."
column20: October 1, 2014
column21: true

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Out of any of the sandbox survival, player economy, player skills, PvP elements, crafting, etc. This one shows the most promise.

The Your Own version has smaller servers (64 max I've seen) on a fairly large map with a variety of landscapes, resources, flat locations for towns (but you can flatten any terrain enough to build on it), all that jazz.

Everyone is a lot more friendly, but this could be to the limited combat elements so far. The combat is similar to Mount & Blade in terms of attacking direction, but with combos for the weapons (not seen them, MIGHT be implemented now... not sure :P) and options to yeild in the hopes of no more violence.

I've gone on to a server and seen players flock to civilisation to help build the town, sow crops for everyone's food, mine the hills for the smelters and blacksmiths to make tools to better everyone. Lumberjacks clearing the surrounding area and bringing back the wood for construction and fuel. Foragers out getting herbs, fruits and even animals to bring food back. It's a beautiful experience.

There are still a lot of features to be implemented and I have really really high hopes for the game.

At full release I believe there will be a far larger scale world with far more players, a lot more terrain, etc. and buying now secures you a place for this. It has a pay-monthly feel to it (my opinion, not a bad thing considering how much you would get) for the full one, but you'd be paying for a lot of content.

I'll be sure to comment more once I've played a bit longer and there's more juicy bits :)
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Badass game. If you're looking for an open world survival MMO, this is it.

This is my first experience on a new server with everything brand new.

You start off this game with basically a handful of cookies. Your first job, build a tool. So you walk over to a tree, snap off a twig. Alright now I got my base, let's find a rock and some string to put this thing together. Gather stone from a stone surface randomly on the ground and make some twine from grass. Sweet got my axe crafted.

Eventually I get all my tools and started looking for a couple of people to group with. All the reviews said there were friendly people and to my surprise, there were ♥♥♥♥ tons of them. I play a lot of Rust so I'm use to the Kill on sight attitude, but I felt guilty trying to smack someone with my axe and they couldn't even techically fight. Without a tool you have nothing, you can't even punch. I don't know if that will be fixed, but I like it. There is never a reason to kill one unless you're an ♥♥♥, really. So I tagged up with that guy and we got a campfire going. Started talking to people in global to see who had a base. Turns out no one really even had a settlement, we were in the very beginning of the game. So we sent out the word where we were and people started flooding into our group. We had a couple lumberjacks cutting down trees, two guys fishing for food, another two looking for berrys and gubs, and a handful of guys up the the mountain mining some ore.

Then we started to build up a town. Eventually I had to log out, but it was pretty awesome that we all came together to get a base going. We heard of other big settlements popping up on the other end of the island. Already we were planning war.

8/10. I would say 10/10, but plenty of bugs still. It is early access so I'm sure my score will change.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

8/10. I would say 10/10, but plenty of bugs still. It is early access so I'm sure my score will change.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes it is early access, but advertisement and and screenshots make this game look alot more developed than it really is.  After purchase you find the graphic quality and overall smoothness is horrible, and it takes a huge toll on your computers performance even at low graphic settings..., and the overall direction of going about game life is confusing and tedious.  At the games current state, it is almost pointless to play due to servers going up and down on a constant basis, so you lose all of your production on a daily basis and have to start over.  For the hefty price tag, and mis-leading state of the game, I currently cannot recommend this game to my fellow steam-mates.

Edit:

After a few months I decided to give Life is Feudal a try again to see if any improvments have been made.  And to my surprise this was in fact the case.  The game runs very smooth now even with the graphics quality turned up to max.  I have enjoyed playing the last few days and frankly have become somewhat addicted to its game play.  I think it would do some good if they implimented a better beginers tutorial though, as it get can confusing on how and what to start doing, but with thier online wiki things are manage-able and can be figured out.  Find a good server to play on and you may find yourself having some fun.  At this time I will be changing my rating to positive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've logged some time both in multiplayer and single player and I've definitely had some fun with this. I personally love the sandbox high-realism gameplay and the slow pacing of everything makes the game a real marathon to achieve what you want, but it's extremely fun to see all the progress you've made as you build your first shack and then an actual home and tools.

This game, like most in this style, really depends on outside sources to learn the mechanics. I spent hours trying to flatten terrain for a house only to realise that I didn't understand how the flatten action worked. Prospecting for minerals makes my brain hurt, and tracking confused the heck out of me for quite awhile, but once you know the rules, it's all accessible.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Damn... This is a role playing paradise. I've sunken thirty hours into this game and I already have the reputation of Okravaaz Draaf the revolutionist. Wow... Off to the review :D!
====================================================================================
Gameplay: The gameplay is not molded by the developers but rather the community. My most memorable moments were of course not staring at a green bar, but they were about meeting new people and speaking to old friends. I even started a revolution against the almighty leader of the server. That was fun. (4/4)
Graphics: The game doesn't look very pleasing, but it isn't terrible either. (2/4)
Preformance: The game preforms almost horrible. I guess it is playable, but it certaintly isn't pleasing on the eyes. (1/4)
Realism: The description of this game basicaly sums it up. The most god damn realistic mmo I have ever seen. While its graphics may not be good and it may not preform great, the game is so realistic I think I've been blinded. The game basicaly reflects on what it would ACTUALY be like in the wilderness. I would say you would need the help of five or ten people just to get new CLOTHING. (4/4)
This game scored a total of 55%. I know you think that's a terrible score, because it is, but the only real downsides to this are its graphics and preformance. So as long as you have relatively strong eyes and a decent computer, you should be able to enjoy this game.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NOTES
*The game is relatively slow moving, and you're going to want a day or two of free time to actualy enjoy the game.
-SharkTurd, C.E.O. SharlBird Inc.

Early Access Review

Lots to do, but a 'building' game. More focused on the community and working together (or against one another) than an FPS. There's a LOT of content here, for the patient person who wants a challenge. This is early access alpha, so I'm excited to see what they come up with next... can't wait!

Early Access Review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I will say the game is a fun concept and has alot of potential I would suggest staying away for the current moment. At this time the game suffers from many issues.

The first and foremost is the bugs. Mines cause lag, every in game morning the game lags, crashes are constant during fights, and in all progression can be a tad weird.

Another thing to note is the combat plays like a buggy mount and blade. Blocking doesnt stop an attack only mitigates it, and that only works a part of the time itself. Shields are difficult to use and most of their features are planned or promised. Armors seem useless with weapons like the warsythe that can kill you in one hit through armor.

If you have the excess money I guess you could buy this game but I would suggest waiting for more features to be implemented and bugs to be worked out. But what can you expect from an Alpha?

6.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beautiful game. I had reservations about buying it at first, given it was A: Early access, B: Several concerning reviews about how dry and monotonous it was and C: Sporadic updates in the news section (though Elite Dangerous might be spoiling me in that regard).

But I genuinely have been enjoying myself. It is a very complex game, requiring a lot of patience and a willingness to ask questions and learn. It's not something you just jump into to waste an afternoon like WoW, CoD, or even Minecraft might be. Additionally, when you start playing, look for a server that has recently gone through a wipe, or look for a group of players that are just starting their base. Do not try this game solo when you start out, find a group.

Let me say that again, do not play this game solo. No. Don't.

But Valo

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is feudal is way to early in development to give any accurate fullscale ''review''.
However I can give it my thoughts, and in the end Ill only recommend it or not.
So pros;
An amazingly detailed crafting system
(imo) Non targetting combat
Visuals are satisfying
Gameplay*
Soundtrack

Cons;
Sounds, (not all of them, but alot of them)
Crafting system will limit your progress when you are playing solo
Half of the skills not Implemented yet
Alot of time will be spent looking at a progress bar
Alpha feel to the game (chunky, some stuff dont work, a few bugs and crashes)

Conclusion;

So if you can get your friends together, and you can get past the alpha feel of the game, and dont care to much about progress bar. If you punch through those cons you will be greeted by some great settings and if you got your friends to come along with you, then youll have hours after hours of gameplay.

Personally I have to recommend this early alpha to fans of the genre, its not amazing, not claiming that, however there certainly are some great potential.
For more info about the game features, see, ''Life is Feudal'' website

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by all the negative reviews. Life is Feudal is a really wonderful game.

It is not an EASY game by any means. I do not reccomend playing it alone. Get four or five good friends to play with you or join a server. Life is Feudal is a cooperative game. You can scrape by on your own, sure, but you won't advance past the Stone Age. If you think you can log on, build a castle in two hours, and log off, you've got another thing coming. LiF doesn't hand you goodies on a silver platter.

If you've got a hardworking team of people, though, you can accomplish some really awesome stuff. For example: my boyfriend and I joined a server and started working toward building a house of our own. We felt insanely accomplished when we managed to build two hovels and kill a stag. It was an enormous rush! LiF makes you work for every single thing you get. As a result, the rewards matter a lot more. We eventually joined up with a bigger town and became Master Armorsmiths. It was amazing to see our hard work pay off. It gave me a sense of accomplishment unlike any other game I've played.

LiF is hard and can be pretty punishing. But the difficulty makes your rewards that much more awesome. You understand the value of an item because you worked hard to get it.

Here are the bad parts: the games crashes frequently and load times are awful. Except to spend 5-10 minutes per load screen. Plus, it's a memory hog. Buyer beware if you're running it on a laptop or an older PC.

reviewText:
Probably the most potential for any early release title I've ever owned.
I picked this up as part of a humble bundle after having it on my wishlist for a year or so, and I regret not buying it outright sooner.
Progression is slow and painstaking, but in a way that is highly rewarding and meaningful.
MMO beta is just about under way now, which I am anticipating more than BF1 or Civ6 for 2016 releases.
There are a fair share of growing pains in the 'your own' hosted server community, and some less than admirable server admins out there, but none the less this is an awesome game that you should play if you have any interest in RPGs or survival games.
Highly recommend

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is Feudal: Your Own is definitely a product of our ongoing craze and love for the survival, sandboxy, constructive and destructive genre, while taking another step towards its logical extremes. The game is a beautiful one, the graphics and the lighting do not fail to impress, which helps bring life to a vast world filled with trees, mountains, swamps, beaches and the ocean itself. Although at the time of writing the game is clearly an Early Access one with plenty of missing features, what's there is evidently plenty to hook people in.

The game gives you plenty of options on how you'd like to play it. You can set how fast or how slow your skills level up, from a glacial crawl to rocketing into masteries. You can set skill caps, either letting the player master every profession, or give them just enough to master one and dabble in one or two others. The latter adds an incredible amount of flavour, where you see farmers who are actual farmers, carpenters who are actual carpenters. They've specialized, they've mastered their trade, and although they may have the ability to help out here and there, they'll never become the town's second blacksmith. To some this may sound bad, but look at it this way: this is Life is Feudal. You're building a town, and in this town everyone, every player, has a purpose. They become gears in a grander machine, where everyone relies on everyone else.

In that kind of game, on that kind of server, you won't find that one guy that's a master blacksmith, carpenter, architect, herbalist, and so on. You won't find a massive castle built by a single person, vast and full of every imaginable thing, but equally lonely. During my play I was invited to join a town. A small one, admittedly, but immediately the community became evident and clear. You had farmers with their plots outside the walls. You had the blacksmith with his shop, a herbalist with another. I was lucky enough to be apprenticed as a carpenter, witnessing wood cutters at work, hauling timber to their newest farmhouse.

That doesn't mean it has to be though. If you're the kind of person that prefers the Minecraft approach, worry not! As I mentioned before, the skill rates are completely up to you. If you want to master the art of logging from peeling the bark off a tree, you can set those settings up and just jump in. You'll be able to master every skill and build your own little kingdom. This goes in multiplayer as well, meaning you can have a small group on a high skill rate server that'll be able to rival a low skill rate server's larger community.

Nothing is perfect however, and this goes doubly for early access. I don't fault the game for any of its bugs or glitches, but it helps that I honestly didn't run into many. The only thing that actually showed up was that sometimes items wouldn't load in and I had to restart the game. No crashes, no memory leaks, no massive frame drops out of nowhere. The frame rate, admittedly, was pretty awful even on the lowest settings, but that's par for the course during early development. It can only get better. Yet this doesn't leave me with a lot of complaints! The UI is a little clunky, but that tends to be cleaned up during development. Wolves are a bit deadly when you're starting off as well, making running into one early on a deadly affair -- and honestly, that's about it.

There's already a good selection of servers out there with a modest but dedicated population, too. For anyone who's been seeking a game like this, I find it easy to recommend. Just be warned; this may be a little too hardcore for a jump directly from Minecraft, at least for some players. For the rest, that's most definitely a good thing!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm giving some faith to the devs for my recommended status. It's a beautiful game, but after 9 hours I'm bored. Crafting system is in depth but the controls... THE CONTROLS! Want to build something? Don't look to anything in game to guide you through even the most simplistic of tasks. I chose the private server route as I wanted to see what the game has to offer without having to watch my back. That was fun to set up, you will need additional downloads if you run into the non responsive (private) server.

I think 8 of my 9 hours I spent hacking away at trees, watching a crafting bar run it's meandering course, and alt-tabbing to try and find a user made youtube video while I ground my teeth in frustration. I wanted to do something that looks really cool in game and having no clue how to even start. I should add that I only knew something cool was there because of said walkthroughs.

The desolation was incredible as well, I felt like I should have run accross a few peasants on the road to harass, maybe a highway robber, but alas nothing was there to even make me worry about obtaining a decent weapon. I even cranked up the animal population to max and it took me a half hour (real time) to wander my lonely island till I found what appeared to be a deer and wolf grunting in the bushes doing god knows what. 4 slingshot projectiles later (after firing 20 shots at close range) I watched my preys back side dissapear into the woods, I gave chase but tripped on the wolf and was promptly devoured as I tried to switch my weapons (STUPID G DAM ANIMATION) because the sling takes one weapon slot and the shots sit in the other.

Pros: Sweet idea, excellent presentation, the game of my dreams. Controls are responsive.

Cons: Nothing to do, and the things you can do are too complicated and not really a big payoff after grinding for hours. Controls are confusing. The Island is disturbing and lonely in it's beauty. I'd rather be a part of a continent cut off by a mountain range, that would feel immersive.

I could keep going, but this is an ALPHA build and I want to see it make it to completion. My recommendation is to support the Dev, maybe wait for it to go on sale if you can't drop the $40 (really? Why is it so much?) but I would at some point pick up this game because it looks like good things will be coming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the current state of the game, you can do some sandbox survivaley things (gather stuff, craft stuff, walk around, build stuff), however although the basics are there, the game lacks content and gets boring very quickly.

What I mean is that:
-The game world is uniform. Water, trees and rock at different elevations. Abandoned player villages with the same basic buildings in each. Random bags of loot of unknown origin laying all around.
-The game world is static. It seems there IS weather and a day/night cycle of some kind, but their effects on the world are undetectable. It feels as if its a summer day 24/7. And no other kinds of events to drive the game of course.
-The game world is too small, safe, scarcely populated and boring to make village building seem like there is a purpose. You can survive just fine without a village, so why build one? To make shinier weapons you dont need?

Basically there is no incentive to do anything other than boredom. Needs more content, needs more dynamic world, needs more environmental pressure to survive. Something to force you to find or create shelter and keep advancing to stay ahead whatever threat there is.

However, Im sure these problems will be addressed when all the basic game mechanisms are in place.

The sandbox survival crafting aspect is deep and clearly aims for realism (if we ignore alchemism...). Raw materials need to be gathered from different sources in different ways, possibly processed in certain ways and then products can be crafted out of them. Its not oversimplified but not confusing either. Craft an axe out of a stick, rock and some plantstuffs to tie them together, all easily collectable by right clicking the right things. Use axe to cut down trees and slash at people for 5 minutes without them dying and losing all their hard work no matter how hard you try.

The game seeks to simulate all aspects (resources and production, building and terraforming, fighting, nature...) in a reasonably realistic and interesting way, avoiding the use of oversimplified models for anything.

The graphics seem like they will look great with some polish (some gaps in terrain, grass isnt rendered very far which shows, buildings could be rendered further away using impostors or similar...)

UI is fine, some lack of 'smoothness' with switching between free mouse and FPS mode. (since this switch needs to happen all the time for working with the menus and clicking on items). It just feels clumsy in a way.

I cannot say I enjoy the game in the current state (since the lack of content and incentive to progress makes it get boring soon), but after theyve worked some more on the resource/crafting/building aspect, made the world more dangerous and overall more 'alive', it will be a great game.

An aspect I like particularly is that it seems more social than some other similar games. Success requires cooperation (building a village yourself is difficult), and PvP/dying have been made not so lethal (you are stunned before you die), unlike in other games where someone is likely die when two persons meet.

I recommend the game not because it would be that fun to play in the current state for prolonged periods (if you play with friends it will probably be fun), but because it clearly has potential to become great and its halfway there already, and the devs seem like they know what theyre going for and seem to have been successful so far.

Price seems decent since the game is going forward at a steady pace so I dont see it as a 'risky investment' in any way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is actually quite amazing. Granted it's a lot like Wurm, but that's because it's in a genre. There's so much more to this game. My only gamebreaking issue right now is that the preformance on it for my rig is heavier than Battlefield 3, or any CryEngine game.

My assumption for this is that it's being ran through Torque, and it doesn't have a lot of optimization.

If you have a rig that can run Battlefield 3, around medium to low graphics, then you'll probably have issues with this game.

Gameplay is great, preformance is not so great (on my end). When this game get's optimized and I can play it without any tree lag, I'll write a more thurough review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would write a deep and truly inspiring review of this game but I will let the numbers speak for me.
85.2 hours of Life is Feudal: Your Own.

It's an ambitious game and still needs some refinement but if the vision of what Bobik has planned comes to fruition this game could shake some things up in the gaming world.

Pro's: *Rich crafting system even in this early access stage.

*There isn't a KOS fest everywhere.

*Good Community. People actually banding together and working on villages.

*Immersive. Even in this early stage of the game it is highly immersive.

*GM Mode: This allows you to toy with all of the buildings and also console in items.

Con's:*The combat system is bit off at the moment.

*Some crashes but much less since the recent patch.

*No character customization currently.


It's a great game already I say help the game get furthered and get it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLife is Feudal: Your Own is well done game, despite the bugs and lack of optimization. Yeah there's bugs here and there like freezing in place and not being able to move (well at least for me) and that the game takes a large amount of RAM. But those are minor in just how in depth and amazing this game is, and it's only in Early Access! Life is Feudal is a medieval sandbox game that likes to be like DayZ, but it does it so much better. Instead of mindlessly killing people (where you lose alignment and lose more skill points upon death), the game tries a more peaceful approach with the implementation of a yield command that gives all your stuff to the combatant, but you get to live on. This would be more like the Codes of Chivalry in being that you protect the honor of another knight. I love that this game does things so well and I cannot wait to see what it's like in the full release, which is by no means close to even being finished.  All in All, this game does an excellent job, despite the problems it has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Life is Feudal... Life is Short, especially in the medieval times. Also in modern times too. Currently, as I am writing this I have about 8 hours logged. About Two of those eight hours are actually playing time.

Rant aside, this game has super potential, and yes, I know, its in Alpha.

What I will add to give the review some diffrence to other reviews is -
-Mentioning that whenever you play on a diffrent server you have to restart. From scratch. (Try and stay on the same server)

-There is NO offline mode (the Mines of Moria have better internet than myself) so you can play without server crashing then re-logging and losing another half hour of your life)

-Primitive weapons are useless. I used my primitive axe  (Made from a snapped tree branch, some plant fiber from the ground and a piece of flint picked up from a rocky patch)  to attack a Wild Grouse, as my charecter was on the verge of starvation  (I had eaten all 5 of my free cookies, and apples only add 5 to your hunger bar, and the ground roots, once you find them, your pretty much back to the hunger you started on)  So, axe in hand, i approached from behind, axed raise expecting a kill... WHAM!... it survived. And fluttered off and nestled a few yards away. It carried on squaking. I ran up again after letting it settle in.. Whack!! It ran again. Two hits with an axe and it still lives? Hopefully theres no Dragons here. As it took 15 hits to eventually slay the mighty Grouse of Fedual times. Each hit registering 1.5 damage - 2.5 for a head shot.
Finally i skin my pray. Collect the one feather from it. Carry it to my nearby camp fire like its some heavy tree trunk. But wait.. i cant do anything with this object. WHY??? IM STARVING HERE!!! Are my skills to low? What have I done wrong??
So i give up and gather more apples. Make a fishing rod.. and try to catch fish on an empty stomach. Where are the fish??? I fished for ten minuits... not a bite. More apples. Apples... Their driving me mad!!! Then.. You cant find any apple trees.. or have over harvested them.. So you revert to a dirt digger, looking for roots to eat. Its a negative frustrating cycle. Somewhat feudal.

-When you meet someone new, they're likely new to the game too. They boast how they have made a primitive axe also. You made one half an hour ago. and thier bragging makes you want to show them your own axe up close to their face. Yet, you are a good patient person and give them a simple well done" keeping your penalty bar neutral. (Penalty bar is a bar which kinda measures your deeds. Basically if it goes into the minus side
